alphabetical letter Z *
The seventeenth letter of the alphabet: called ZaA='N [and ZaA]. (TA.) It is a letter peculiar to the Arabic language; and is one of the letters termed majohuwrap [or vocal, i. e. pronounced with the voice, not with the breath only]; and of the letters termed livawiy~ap [or gingival], like v and *. (TA.) As it does not exist in the language of the Nabathæans, they change it into T. (IF, TA.) [It is substituted for the t in the measure AifotaEala and the forms inflected therefrom when immediately following Z; as in AiZ~alama, for AiZoZalama, for AiZotalama:] and it is substituted for *; as in tarakotuhu waqiy*FA and waqiyZFA; as is related on the authorities of ISk and Kr; and as in A^aroDN jilo*aA='N and jiloZaA='N, as is mentioned in the Nawádir el-Aaráb. (TA.) -A2- [As a numeral, it denotes Nine hundred.]

R. Q. 1 ZaA^oZaA^a * , inf. n. ZaA^oZaA^apN (L, K) and ZaA^oZaA='N, (K, TA, [in the CK ZaA^owA',]) the latter allowable in the case of a R. Q. verb, as in the instances of wasowaAsN and the like, (MF, TA,) [accord. to some, but wswAs and the like are generally held to be inf. ns. if with kesr, and simple substs. if with fet-h,] He (a goat) made a [rattling] sound, or cry, when excited by lust, or at rutting-time; syn. nab~a. (AA, L, K.) ― -b2- And ZA^ZA^, (M, K,) inf. n. ZaA^oZaA^apN, (M,) He (a person whose upper lip was slit, M, K, and one whose fore teeth were broken at the roots, K, * TA) spoke unintelligible speech, and with a nasal sound. (M, K.)

1 ZaA^arahaA * , (S, Mgh, K,) or ZaA^arahaA EalaY waladi gayorihaA, (M,) aor.
ZaAa^a , (M, K,) inf. n. ZaA^orN (S, M, K) and Ziy^oArN, (M, K,) He made her (a camel, S, Mgh) to incline to, or to affect, a young one not her own, (S, M, Mgh, K,) and to suckle it; (M, K;) as also ↓ A^aZoA^arahaA, and ↓ ZaA='arahaA: (K:) and [it is also said that] Ziy^aArN signifies the making a she-camel to incline to, or to affect, and suckle, the young one of another, by the application of a gimaAmap in her nose, (S, * K, * TA,) i. e. by stopping her nose, and also her eyes, (TA,) and by the insertion of a durojap [q. v.] composed of rags into her vulva, (raHim, T, TA, or HayaA=', S), and closing its [i. e. the vulva's] edges by means of two pointed pieces of wood stuck through, and putting upon her a gimaAmap covering her head, and leaving her in this state until it distresses her, (T, TA,) and she imagines herself to be in labour; (TA;) when the drjp is pulled out from her vulva (HayaA='), and the young one of another is brought near to her, having its head and skin bedaubed with what has come forth with the drjp from the lower part of the vulva; (T, * TA;) then they open her nose and her eyes; (TA;) and when she sees and smells the young one, she imagines that she has brought it forth, and yields it milk: moreover, when the drjp is inserted, the space between the two edges of her vulva is closed by a thong [passed round the extremities of the two pointed pieces of wood]. (T, TA.) It is said in a trad., of 'Omar, (T,) or Ibn-'Omar, (S, TA,) that he purchased a she-camel, and, seeing in her the laceration on the occasion of Ziy^oAr, returned her. (T, S, * TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] ZaA^arahu EalaY A^amori ka*aA, and ↓ A^aZaA^arahu, and ↓ ZaA='arahu, (tropical:) He made him to incline to such a thing: (Lth, T, TA:) and ZaA^araniY EalaY AlA^amori, (so in the CK,) or ↓ ZaA='araniY Ealayohi, (M, TA, and so in some copies of the K,) inf. n. muZaA='arapN, (TA,) he endeavoured to turn me, or to entice me, to do the thing; (M, K, TA;) it not being in my mind: (TA:) or he compelled me to do the thing, against my will; (K, TA;) I having refused to do it. (TA.) It is said in a prov., AlT~aEonu yaZoA^aru, meaning, Thrusting, or piercing, with the spear inclines [one's enemies] to peace: (As, T, A, K:) J says yaZoA^aruhu, as also IKtt, which F disapproves; but others approve it: or the reading of the S is ↓ yuZoy^iruhu. (TA.) The Arabs also said, AlT~aEonu Ziy^aAru qawomK (M, K) Thrusting, or piercing, with the spear is a means of inclining a people to peace; (K;) meaning, make people to fear, that they may love thee. (M, K.) It is also said, in a trad. of 'Alee, A^aZoA^arukumo A_ilaY AlHaq~i waA^anotumo tafir~uwna minohu, [perhaps a mistake for ElY AlHq~,] I incline you [or I endeavour to turn you] to the truth, and ye flee from it. (TA.) -A2- ZaA^arato, (S, K,) [of which Zuw^uwrapN, q. v., appears to be an inf. n.; or you say ZaA^arato EalaY waladi gayorihaA, and EalaY baw~K;] and ↓ AiZ~aA^arato; (T, M, K; in one copy of the K AiZoA=r~ato;) She (a camel, T, S, M) inclined to, or affected, a young one not her own, (T, M, K,) and suckled it: (K:) or inclined to, or affected, the stuffed skin of a young camel. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence,] ZaA^ara EalaY Eaduw~ihi (tropical:) He returned against his enemy. (A, TA.) -A3- And ZaA^ara, aor.
ZaAa^a ; (Msb;) or ↓ ZaA='ara, inf. n. muZaA='arapN. (AZ, S;) He took to himself a Ziy^or [or nurse]. (AZ, S, Msb.) [See also 8.]

3 ZaA~a^a see 1, in four places. ― -b2- One says also, ZaA='arato, (inf. n. muZaA='arapN, T, A,) She took to herself a child to suckle. (T, M, A, K.) ― -b3- And bayonahumaA muZaA='arapN There is between them two that relation which consists in each one's being the Ziy^or [or rather the fosterer of the child] of the other. (M, K.) -A2- ZaAwiro occurs in a trad. for ZaAy^iro. (TA.) [But in what sense is not explained.]
4 A^aZoAa^a see 1, in three places.

8 A_iZotaAa^a see 1, near the end. ― -b2- AiZ~aA^ara liwaladihi Ziy^orFA, (S, and so in some copies of the K,) or AiZoTaA^ara, (M, and so in some copies of the K,) the former being similar to AiZ~alama, (S,) means He took a nurse for his child. (S, M, K.)

10 AstZA^rt *
She (a bitch) desired the male: (K:) mentioned by AM; but he says, “ I hesitate respecting it. ” (TA.) [I think it is probably a mistake for AstTArt, mentioned in art. Tyr. See also Zuw^oraY.]

ZaA^orN * Anything accompanied by the like thereof: thus applied to a run (EadowN): (As, T, TA:) in the K, and in the Tekmileh, Eaduw~N is erroneously put for EadowN: (TA:) and EadowN ZaA^orN is used by the poet El-Arkat, in describing [wild] asses, as meaning a run not unsparingly performed. (T, TA.)

Ziy^orN * One that inclines to, or affects, the young one of another, and suckles [or fosters] it; applied to a human being, (M, A, K,) and to a camel, (M,) or other [animal]; (A, K;) to a female and to a male: (M, A, K:) or a she-camel that inclines to, or affects, the young one of another;
(Msb;) as also ↓ Zaw^uwrN: (S:) and hence applied also to a strange woman that nurses, or fosters, the child of another: and likewise to a man who fosters the child of another: and also pronounced ZiyrN, with the ' suppressed: (Msb:) and the epithet Ziy^orapN is also applied to a female: (A:) the pl. [of pauc.] is A^aZow^urN (M, K) and A^aZoA=rN, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) [which latter is also used as a pl. of mult., accord. to an ex. given in the A;] and [the proper pls. of mult. are] Zuw^uwrN and ↓ Zuw^aArN, (S, M, K,) which last is an extr. form, (M,) and ↓ Zuw^orapN, (M, K,) or, accord. to Sb, this is a quasipl. n., (M,) and Zuw^uwrapN, (M, K,) like fuHuwlapN and buEuwlapN: (M:) or the pl., applied to camels, is ↓ Zuw^aArN; and to women, Zuw^uwrapN: (M:) or to women, Ziy^aArN and ↓ Zuw^aArN: (Msb:) ↓ Zuw^uwrapN also signifies a nurse: (IAar:) and ↓ Zaw^uwrN signifies the same as Ziy^orN: (TA:) or a she-camel made to incline to, or affect, the young one of another; (M;) as also ↓ maZow^uwrapN: (S:) or that keeps close to the young one, or to the stuffed skin of a young one. (M.) ― -b2- [The pl.] ↓ Zuw^aArN is also applied (by a poet, M, TA) to (tropical:) The three stones upon which the cooking-pot is placed: (S, M, K, TA:) likened to camels; (M, TA;) because of their inclining (S, M, TA) towards, (S,) or around, (M, TA,) the ashes. (S, M, TA.) ― -b3- And Ziy^orN signifies also (tropical:) An angle, or a corner, of a qaSor [or pavilion, &c.]. (K.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) A buttress built against a wall; (K, * TA;) likewise called ↓ Ziy^orapN. (TA.)
Zuw^orapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
Ziy^irapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
Zuw^oraY * A cow desiring the male: (K:) mentioned by Az, on the authority of AHát; and said to have no verb. (TA. [But see 10, above.])
Zuw^aArN * : see Ziy^orN, in four places.

Ziy^aArN *
A gimaAmap [q. v.] that is put into the nose of a she-camel to make her to incline to, or affect, the young one of another, in order that she may not perceive the smell of her young one. (A.) [See also 1.]
Zaw^uwrN * : see Ziy^orN, in two places.

Zuw^uwrapN *
Inclination to, or affection for, the young one of another: (M, K:) it may be an inf. n., as well as a pl. [of Ziy^orN]. (M.) ― -b2- Also [The relation in which one stands by being a Ziy^or, or nurse:] like EumuwmapN and xuw^uwlapN &c. (TA.) ― -b3- See also Ziy^orN, latter half.
maZow^uwrapN * : see Ziy^orN, latter half.

huwa muZaAy^irN lahaA *
He is the father of the child which she is nursing. (T, TA. *)

ZubapN * The Had~, (T, M, Msb, K,) or Taraf, (S,) [both of which mean the end, or extremity, but the former means also the edge,] of a sword, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) or of a spear-head and the like, (K,) or also of a spear-head and of an arrowhead and of a dagger and the like; (M;) or the part next to the Taraf [or extremity] of the sword; also called its *ubaAb: (T:) or the ZubataAni are the parts of the two edges that are on either side of the *ubaAb [by which last word is here app. meant the point] of the sword: (AZ, T and TA voce *ubaAbN, q. v.:) [for the swords of the Arabs, in the older times, were generally straight, twoedged, and tapering to a point:] or, accord. to Aboo-Riyásh, the Zubap of the sword is the part that is four digits' measure below, or within, (duwna,) the *ubaAb thereof; and is the strikingplace thereof: and it is also its Had~; and the Zubap of the spear-head is likewise its Had~: (Ham p. 48:) the p in ZubapN is a substitute for w, which is the final radical, (S, M, Msb, K,) the word being originally ZubawN: (S, TA:) the pl. is A^aZobK, (S, K,) a pl. of pauc., (S,) and ZubaAtN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and ZubaApN [which is originally ZubawapN] (S, * TA) and Zubuwna (T, S, M, Msb, K) and Zibuwna and ZubFA or ZubFY. (M, K.) In the saying of EsSemow-al Ibn-'Ádiyà,
tasiylu EalaY Had~i AlZ~ubaAti nufuwsunaA
walayosato EalaY gayori AlZ~ubaAti tasiylu
[Our bloods flow upon the edge of the ZbAt, and upon other than the edge of the ZbAt they flow not], by the ZbAt may be meant the swords, altogether, or the striking-places of the swords. (Ham p. 52. [See also a similar ex. in p. 48 of the same.]) -A2- Also A kind of mazaAd [or leathern water-bag]. (M.) -A3- And A place of bending, or turning, of a valley; like ZaboyapN [which belongs to art. ZbY]: pl. of the former ZubaA='N, a pl. of a rare form. (M in art. ZbY.)
5 tZb~Y * , if used, means He acted like the ZaboY, or gazelle; being similar to ta*aA^~aba and tanam~ara &c.: its part. n. is mentioned in the first paragraph of art. rbD.]

ZaboYN *
A certain animal, (TA,) well known; (S, Msb, K, TA;) the gazaAl [or gazelle; to which the former word is applied when used unrestrictedly, and which is app. here meant by the latter word, though this seems properly to signify “ a young gazelle ”]; (M;) [it is the gazella dorcas, also called antilope dorcas, of which the ariel, or antilope Arabica, is said to be a variety; or, accord. to some, each is a distinct species of gazelle: the name seems to be properly, but not always (as is shown by an explanation of riy^omN), applied only to the true antelope of Arabia and adjacent countries, as distinguished from the cervine and bovine antelopes:] it is a name for the male; which is also called tayosN, when he has become what is termed a vaniY~ [q. v.], which he continues to be termed until he dies: (AHát, Msb, TA:) the female is called ZaboyapN, (AHát, T, M, Msb, K, TA,) and EanozN and maAEizapN: (AHát, Msb, TA:) the dual is ZaboyaAni: (Msb, TA:) and the pl. is A^aZobK, (S, M, Msb, K,) originally A^aZobuYN, (S, Msb,) a pl. of pauc., (S,) and ZubiY~N and ZibaA='u, (S, M, Msb, K,) which last is of the masc. and fem., (M, Msb,) and ZabayaAtN, (S, M, Msb, K,) which is of the fem. (M, Msb.) One says, bihi daA='u ZaboYK [lit. In him is the disease of a gazelle]; meaning in him is no disease; as there is [said to be] no disease in the ZbY. (AA, T.) And laka EinodiY miAy^apN sin~a AlZ~aboYi [To thee I owe a hundred camels of the age of the gazelle], i. e., all of them vunoyaAn [pl. of vaniY~N, q. v.], because the ZbY does not exceed what is termed A_ivonaA='N. (M.) [See also a verse cited voce sin~N; in which the phrase fajaA='ato kasin~i AlZ~aboYi means And they came; like the age of the gazelle was the age of every one of them.] It is said in a prov., ↓ laA^atorukan~ahu taroka ZubaY~K Zil~ahu [I will assuredly forsake him as a little gazelle forsakes the place of its shade]; because the ZbY, when it leaves its covert, does not return to it: it is said in confirming the relinquishing of anything. (T. [See Zil~N, where other relations of this prov. are mentioned.]) And in another prov., AlZ~ibaA='a EalaY Albaqari, said when the tie of relationship and friendship between two men is severed, and it was used in the Time of Ignorance as a form of divorce: AlZbA' is in the accus. case by reason of Aixotarotu, or AixotaAra, understood, [so that the meaning is I have preferred, or he has preferred, the gazelles to the wild cows,] by the bqr being meant the women: whence the saying, jaA='a yajur~u baqarahu [expl. in art. bqr]. (Meyd. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 61.]) And one says, A^atayotuhu Hiyna $ad~a AlZ~aboYa Zil~uhu i. e. [I came to him when its shade] confined the ZbY [or gazelle] by reason of the vehemence of the heat: or, as some relate it, Hiyno na$ada AlZ~aboYu Zil~ahu, meaning Talabahu [i. e., when the gazelle sought its shade]. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., A_i*aA A^atayotahumo faA@robiDo fiY daArihimo ZaboyFA [expl. voce rabaDa]. (T, TA.) bihi laA biZaboYK, (S, TA,) or bihi laA biZaboYK A^aEofara, a prov., meaning May this accident befall him, (liyanozilo bihi h`*ihi AlHaAdivapu,) not a white antelope, (Meyd,) is said on an occasion of rejoicing at another's affliction, (S, Meyd, TA,) by way of imprecation, i. e. may God make that which has befallen him to cleave to him. (S, TA. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 148.]) ― -b2- [AlZ~ibaA='u and A^awolaAdu AlZ~ibaA='i are mentioned by Freytag as names of Certain stars: in relation to the former of which he refers to Ideler's “ Unters. ” pp. 20-21; and in relation to the latter, to the same work p. 21.] ― -b3- And AlZ~aboYu is the name of A brand, or mark made with a hot iron, peculiar to some of the Arabs. (T, K.)

ZaboyapN * fem. of ZaboYN [q. v.]. (AHát, T, &c.) ― -b2- Also a name for (assumed tropical:) A woman; [or, app. a young
woman;] and so A^um~u ZaboyapK. (Msb, TA.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) A man who is stupid, dull, wanting in intel-ligence, inert, or wanting in vigour. (K, TA: but not in the CK.) ― -b4- And accord. to the K, i. q. $aApN: and baqarapN: but this is a great mistake, caused by a misunderstanding of what is cited in the passage here next following from the M. (TA.) ― -b5- Also The vulva of a woman: (Lth, T, S, M, K:) and, (M,) accord. to As, (T, S,) of any solid-hoofed beast: (T, S, M:) accord. to some, (M,) or accord. to Fr, (T, S,) of the bitch: (T, S, M:) and accord. to Lth, of the she-camel: (T:) IAar makes it to be peculiarly of the she-ass, and of the ewe or she-goat, and of the cow; (M;) meaning that it signifies the vulva of these: (TA:) and it signifies also the vagina of the mare. (M.) ― -b6- Also 1 [bag for travellingprovisions &c., such as is called] jiraAb: (M, K:) or peculiarly a small jiraAb: (M, K: *) or one made of the skin of the ZaboY [or gazelle]: (M:) or a thing [i. e. a pouch] like the xariyTap and the kiys: dim. ↓ Zubay~apN: and pl. ZibaA='N. (T.) ― -b7- And A [tent such as is called] xibaA='. (TA.) ― -b8- And A place of bending, or turning, of a valley; (M, K;) as also ZubapN [mentioned in art. Zbw]: pl. of the former ZibaA='N. (M.) -A2- Zaboyapu is one of the names of The well Zemzem. (TA.)
ZubaY~N * : see ZaboYN [of which it is the dim.].
Zubay~apN * dim. of ZaboyapN, q. v.

A^aroDN maZobaApN *
A land abounding with ZibaA=' [or gazelles]. (M.)

1 Zar~a *
He cut [or split off] a miZar~ap [i. e. a fragment of hard stone, with a sharp edge, to be used as a knife]. (Lth, T, M, K. [In some copies of the K, maZr~p; and in one place, in a copy of the M, maZir~p: but correctly miZar~ap, as is said in the TA.]) This the pastor does for the purpose of cutting off therewith a thing resembling a wart within the belly of a she-camel, (Lth, T, M,) at the orifice of the womb, when she is affected by a disease occasioned by lusting for the male. (Lth, TA.) ― -b2- And He slaughtered a she-camel, (K, TA,) or, as in the “ Tekmileh, ” an animal, with the [stone called] Zurar. (TA.)

4 A^aZir~iY faA_in~aki naAEilapu * (M, K) is a prov., meaning Tread thou upon the Zurar [for thou art furnished with leathern shoes or sandals]: (M:) but the phrase commonly known is with the unpointed T [i. e. A^aTir~iY: see 4 in art. Tr]. (M, K.)
Zir~N * : see the next paragraph.

ZurarN *
A sharp-edged hard stone: (As, T, Mgh, TA:) a stone having an edge like that of the knife: (S:) or a [kind of] smooth and broad stone which a man breaks and with which he slaughters a camel; (ISh, T, Mgh, * TA;) and it is of any colour; and is also thus called before it is broken: (ISh, T, TA:) and the n. un. is ↓ ZurarapN: (T:) or, as also ↓ ZurarapN and ↓ Zir~N, a stone, (M, K,) in a general sense: (M:) or a round stone: (TA:) or a round sharp-edged stone: (M, K:) or a piece of stone having a sharp edge: (M:) the pl. is ZiraArN and Zir~aAnN; (As, T, S, Mgh;) or the pl. is Zir~aAnN and Zur~aAnN; (Th, M, and so in the K accord. to the TA; [in the CK ZiraArN and Zir~aArN;]) and Th says that the former of these is pl. of ZurarN, or both may be pls. of Zir~N; (M;) and another pl. is A^aZir~apN, (T, TA,) [a pl. of pauc.,] occurring in a trad.; (TA;) or, accord. to ISh, ↓ ZiraArN [mentioned above as a pl.] is a sing., and A^aZir~apN is its pl.: (Mgh:) and ↓ A^uZoruwrN and ↓ ZuroZuwrN and ↓ muZoruwrN, of which last the pl. is maZaAriyru, (Sgh, K, TA,) and all of which are with damm, thus in the handwriting of Sgh, (TA,) signify the same [as ZurarN &c.]. (Sgh, K, TA.)
ZurarapN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
ZiraArN * : see ZurarN: and see also miZar~apN.

ZariyrN * : see maZar~apN. ― -b2- Also A sign set up whereby one is guided to the right way: pl. A^aZir~apN (M, K) and Zur~aAnN: (TA, and so in the CK: [in some copies of the K ZiraArN, which is said in the TA to be wrong:]) A^aZir~apN signifies signs set up whereby one is guided to the right way, like the Amr~p [thus in a copy of the T, a mistranscription for A^amarap]; some of which are extended and hard, and millstones are made from them. (T.)
ZiraArapN * : see miZar~apN.
ZuroZuwrN * : see ZurarN.
A^uZoruwrN * : see ZurarN.

A^aroDN maZar~apN * , (S, M, K,) thought to be thus by AAF; (M;) or maZir~apN, (T, M,) with kesr to the Z, accord. to Th; (M;) Land containing, (T, S,) or abounding with, (K,) stones of the kind called Zurar: (T, S, K:) or stony land: (Th, M:) and ↓ ZariyrN also has the former meaning: (K:) or this latter is an epithet applied to a place as meaning rugged, or rugged and hard: (S:) or meaning a place abounding with stones: (M:) and its pl. is A^aZir~apN and Zur~aAnN. (S.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph.

miZar~apN *
A stone with which one strikes fire. (TS, K.) ― -b2- And also, (TS, TA,) or, accord. to the K, with fet-h, [i. e. ↓ maZar~apN,] but this requires consideration, (TA,) Fragments [or a fragment, agreeably with an explanation in the Mgh, in my copy of which maZir~apN is erroneously put for miZar~apN,] of sharp-edged stone: (TS, K, TA:) pl. maZaAr~N: (TS, TA:) or miZar~apN signifies a piece split off from Zir~aAn [pl. of ZurarN or Zir~N], (Sh, TA,) or [simply] a stone, (M, TA,) with which one cuts: (Sh, M, TA:) as also ↓ ZiraArN, (M,) or ↓ ZiraArapN. (TA.)
muZoruwrN * : see ZurarN.

1 Zariba bihi * , aor.
Zaraba , He, or it, stuck, adhered, or clave, to him, or it. (K.)
2 Zur~ibati AlHawaAfiru * , inf. n. taZoriybN, The solid hoofs became hard and strong. (T, K.)

ZaribN *
A stone projecting (Lth, T, M, Msb, K) from a mountain or from rugged ground (Lth, T) and having a sharp point: (Lth, T, M, K:) or an expanded mountain, (M, K, TA,) accord. to some, that is not high: (TA:) or a small mountain: (M, K:) or a small hill: (T, S, Msb:) pl. ZiraAbN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and A^aZorubN, (Nh, TA,) [the latter a pl. of pauc.,] the former pl. of a rare kind, for by rule it should be A^aZoraAbN, and it seems as though they had imagined the sing. to be ZarobN, and so made the pl. like sihaAmN, pl. of sahomN: (Msb, TA:) or, accord. to En-Nadr, ZaribN signifies the smallest of [hills such as are termed] A=kaAm, and the sharpest in stones, all its stones being sharp like knives, the white thereof and the black and of every colour: and the pl. is A^aZoraAbN. (T.) [See also this pl. below.]

Zurub~N *
Short, and thick, (M, K, TA,) and fleshy: (Lh, TA:) or a short and fleshy man. (S.)
ZarobaY * and ZirobaY: see ZaribaAnN, in three places.
ZirobaA=' * and ZiaribaA=': see the next paragraph, in four places.

ZaribaAnN * (S, M, Msb, K, &c.) and ZirobaAnN (AA, AZ, Msb, TA) and ZarobaAnN (IJ, TA) and ↓ ZirabaA='u (M, CK, TA, or ↓ ZirobaA=' or ↓ ZiribaA=' accord. to two different copies of the K) A small, stinking beast, (AZ, S, M, Msb, K,) resembling a cat, (AZ, S, M, K,) or resembling a short Chinese dog, (Msb,) or resembling an ape or a monkey, (AA, T, M, TA,) or above the whelp of a dog, (El-Mustaksee, TA,) that often emits a noiseless wind from the anus; (M, Msb, * TA;) said by Az, on the authority of the handwriting of AHeyth, to be a beast that has small legs, their length being that of half a finger, but which is broad, its breadth being equal to the space measured by the extension of the thumb and the little finger, or of the thumb and the fore finger, and its length being a cubit, having a compact head, and its ears [for AdnAh, in my original, I read A^u*unaAhu] being like the cat's; (TA;) it is small and short in the ears, (A^aSolamu AlA^u*unayoni, M, Msb,) or having a stoppage of the ears, (A^aSam~u AlA*nyn, TA,) its earholes [only] hearing a confused, or humming, or ringing, sound; (M, TA;) long in the snout, [but El-Farezdak speaks of it as having a short nose, as is shown in the S,] black in the back, white in the belly; (M, Msb, TA;) it is said that its back is [or rather contains] one single bone, without any qafaS
[or cage-formed structure of ribs, &c.], and that the sword has no effect upon it by reason of the hardness of its skin, unless striking its nose: (TA:) the pl. is ZaraAbiynu, (M, K,) or ZaraAbiY~u, (AZ, T, S, Msb,) sometimes, (S,) or this latter also, (M, K,) as though it were pl. of ZirobaA=', (S,) or the first Y is a substitute for the A [of the sing. ZaribaAnN] and the second for the n, (M,) and (quasi-pl. ns., M, K) ↓ ZirobaY (AZ, T, M, Msb, K) and ↓ ZirobaA='u, (M, K,) or ↓ ZirobaY, is a pl. like HijolaY pl. of HajalN, (S, TA,) and these two are [said to be] the only pls. of this measure, (AHei, TA,) and Lth and AHeyth say that ZirobaA='u is incorrect, and is rightly ↓ ZirobaY. (T, TA.) A poet says, (namely, 'Abd-Allah Ibn-Hajjáj Ez-Zebeedee, M, TA,)
A^alaA A^aboligaA qayosFA waxinodifa A^an~aniY
Darabotu kaviyrFA maDoriba AlZ~aribaAni
[Now tell ye Keys and Khindif that I have struck Ketheer in the place of striking of the ZrbAn], meaning that he had struck Ketheer Ibn-Shiháb (S, M, TA) El-Medh-hijee upon his face; for the ZrbAn has a line, or long mark, upon his face; and he likens the blow that he inflicted upon his face to that mark: [see maDoribN:] and the same words of the latter hemistich, except that EubayodFA is substituted in them for kaviyrFA, occur in a verse of Asad Ibn-Nághisah, who slew 'Obeyd by order of En-Noamán. (TA.) One says, fasaA bayonanaA AlZ~aribaAnu, (S,) or bayonahum, (Msb, K,) [lit. The ZrbAn emitted a noiseless wind from its anus among us, or among them,] a prov., (S,) meaning that we, or they, became disunited, and alienated, one from another: [for] when this animal emits a noiseless wind from its anus in the garment of a man, the stink does not go away until the garment wears out: (S, Msb, K:) the Arabs of the desert assert that it does so in the garment of him who hunts it: (S:) and it is said to do so in the hole of the [lizard called] Dab~, which, being stupified by the foulness of the stink, is taken and eaten by it. (M, K, TA.) One says also, ta$aAtamaA fakaA^an~amaA jazaraA bayonahumaA ZaribaAnFA [They reviled each other, and it was as though they slaughtered between them a ZrbAn]: the foulness of their reviling being likened to the stink of that animal. (M, TA.) And yatanaAzaEaAni jiloda AlZ~aribaAni They two contend in pulling at the skin of the ZrbAn, meaning (assumed tropical:) they revile each other: (M, TA:) and yatamaA$anaAni jiloda AlZ~aribaAni They wipe their hands together upon the skin of the ZrbAn, [likewise] meaning (assumed tropical:) they revile each other. (IAar, T, TA.)

AlA^aZoraAbu * [accord. to some] signifies Four teeth behind the nawaAji* [or other grinders; app. meaning, of a horse]: (K:) or the sockets (A^asonaAx) of the teeth: (S, K:) [and it is said that] A^aZoraAbu All~ijaAmi signifies the knots that are at the extremities of the bit. (M, TA.) J cites the following verse, ascribing it to 'Ámir Ibn-Et-Tufeyl,
wamuqaT~iEK Halaqa Alr~iHaAlapi saAbiHK
baAdK nawaAji*uhu Eani AlA^aZoraAbi
[thus in the S, (but in the M and TA EalaY AlA^aZoraAbi,) as though meaning And breaking in pieces the rings of the girth of the saddle, running with the fore legs well stretched forth, his grinders appearing from the sockets]: but IB says, [following the reading in the M and TA,] the verse is by Lebeed; and the poet is describing a horse that breaks in pieces the rings of the saddle by his springing forward, and whose grinders (nawaAji*uhu) appear when he treads upon the [stones, or hills, called] ZiraAb: [see ZaribN, of which both ZiraAbN and A^aZoraAbN are said to be pls.:] also that the right reading is wamuqaT~iEN [and saAbiHN]: and by the nwAj* are meant the DawaAHik [or teeth next behind the canine teeth], accord. to Hr. (TA.)

HawaAfiru muZar~abapN * [accord. to the TA muZar~ibapN, but this is evidently a mistake (see 2),] means [Solid hoofs] that have become hard and strong: (K, TA:) [but] accord. to El-Mufaddal, AlmuZar~abu, like muEaZ~am [in measure], signifies A@l~a*iY qado law~aHatohu AlZ~iraAbu [app. meaning that which the stones, or hills, called ZiraAb have altered, or, perhaps, heated, in its treading upon them]. (TA.)

1 Zarufa * , (T, S, M, &c.,) inf. n. ZaraAfapN, (S, Msb,) or ZarofN and ZaraAfapN, (T, M, Mgh, * O, K,) but the latter is rare, (K,) allowable in poetry, (T, M,) or, as some say, is of frequent occurrence, and confirmed by analogy, (MF, TA,) said of a man, (S, O,) [or only of a young man, and Zarufat of a young woman,] He possessed the quality, or qualities, termed Zarof meaning as expl. below [i. e. excellence, or elegance, in mind, manners, and address or speech; and in person, countenance, or garb, guise, or external appearance; or all of these qualities combined: he was, or became, clever, ingenious, intelligent, or acute in intellect; well-mannered, well-bred, accomplished, or polite; beautiful in person or countenance; elegant, or graceful; or elegant in garb, guise, or external appearance]. (T, S, O, Msb, K.) -A2- See also what here follows.
3 ZaAorafa ↓ ZaArafaniY faZarafotuhu [He vied, or contended, with me in Zarof] and I was more Zariyf (kunotu ↓ A^aZorafa) than he. (IKtt, TA.)

4 AZrf *
He (a man) had many [Zuruwf, or] receptacles [of any kind]. (TA.) ― -b2- And He begat, (S, Mgh, O, K,) or had born to him, (M,) children that were ZurafaA=' (S, M, O, K) or ZiraAf [pls. of Zariyf, q. v.]. Mgh.) ― -b3- AZrf biAlr~ajuli He mentioned the man as possessing Zarof. (M, TA.) ― -b4- And AZrf fiY AlEibaArapi is explainable [as meaning He was elegant, or eloquent, in the expression, or phrase, or speech], if the saying be received from those who are trustworthy: if not, it is correctly A^aTorafa, with the unpointed T; meaning “ he said what was novel and pleasing. ” (Mgh.) -A2- AZrf AlmataAEa, (O,) in the K, erroneously, fulaAnFA, (TA,) He put, or assigned, or made, a Zarof [or receptacle] for the goods. (O, TA.)

5 tZr~f *
He affected Zarof; (S, O, K;) as also ↓ tZArf. (TA.) One says, fulaAnN yataZar~afu walayosa biZariyfK [Such a one affects Zarof and he is not Zariyf]. (TA.)
6 taZaAorafa see the next preceding paragraph.

10 AstZrfhu *
He found him [or held him] to be Zariyf. (O, * TA.)

ZarofN *
A receptacle (Lth, T, S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K) of anything; (Lth, T, M;) [a vessel, or vase;] an A_iboriyq is thus termed as being a Zrf for what is in it: (Lth, T, TA:) and AHn applies it to a seed-vessel, or pericarp, or a cell of a pericarp: (M, TA:) [and it is also applied to a case, or cover, for a book or the like:] the pl. is ZuruwfN: (T, S, * M, Mgh, O, Msb, K:) A^aZoraAfN is a mistake. (Mgh.) [Applying it to a vessel of silver,] Har uses it as meaning “ silver. ” (P. 614 [referring to a phrase in p. 213].) One says, A^axa*otu AlmataAEa biZarofihi [I took the goods with the receptacle thereof]. (A, TA.) And hence, (A, TA,) raA^ayotuhu biZarofihi (tropical:) I saw him himself. (A, O, K, TA.) And huwa naqiY~u AlZ~arofi (tropical:) He is faithful, (O, K, TA,) not treacherous. (M, O, K, TA.) ― -b2- And hence (assumed tropical:) [An adverbial noun of place or of time, implying the meaning of the preposition fY; and also by some applied to a noun of place or of time together with that preposition; i. e.] what are termed Zarofu AlmakaAni and Alz~amaAni, (O,) pl. Zuruwfu Alz~amaAni and AlmakaAni: (S, M: *) the descriptive terms that denote the places [or times] of things are called ZuruwfN: (Lth, T:) they are thus termed by Kh; and by Ks, maHaAl~u; and by Fr, SifaAtN. (T.) ― -b3- Also [Excellence, or elegance, in mind, manners, and address or speech; and in person, countenance, or garb, guise, or external appearance; or all of these qualities combined:] a term denoting a condition that combines the generality of mental and bodily and extrinsic excellences; likened [by reason of its comprehensiveness] to the receptacle thus called: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or cleverness, ingeniousness, intelligence, or acuteness in intellect; syn. kiyaAsapN, (S, O, K,) or kayosN, (Mgh, Msb,) and *akaA='N: (Mgh:) or i. q. baraAEapN, and *akaA='u qalobK; [the former meaning excellence in knowledge, or other qualities; or accomplishment, or perfection, in every excellence, and in goodliness;] ('Eyn, M, O, Msb, K; *) thus accord. to most of the copies of the K [as well as the 'Eyn and M and O and Msb], but correctly bazaAEap, with the letter zAY: (TA:) [if so, these two explanations (bazaAEapN and *akaA='u qalobK) add nothing to others here given:] or
skilfulness (M, K, TA) in a thing (M, TA) is thus termed by the people of El-Yemen: (TA:) or it is in the tongue, (IAar, T, K,) only; (K;) meaning beauty of expression, (M, L, TA,) and eloquence; (L, TA;) and HalaAwapN is in the eyes, and malaAHapN is in the mouth, and jamaAlN is in the nose: (IAar, T:) or beauty of garb, guise, or external appearance: (M:) or beauty of face, and of garb, guise, or external appearance: (O, K:) or it is in the face and in the tongue: (Ks, O, K:) or goodliness, or beauty; and A^adab [as having the meaning first assigned to ZarofN in this sentence, i. e. excellence, or elegance, in mind, manners, or address or speech; or as meaning good breeding, good manners, politeness, or polite accomplishments]: (Msb:) or, as an inf. n., the being elegant, graceful, or beautiful: and the being intelligent, sagacious, or acute in intellect: (KL:) accord. to the author of the 'Eyn, (O,) it is only an attribute of young men and young women (M, O, Msb, * K) that are acute in intellect, clever, or skilful; (M, O, K;) not of elders, nor of lords, or chiefs: (M, K:) but as meaning kiyosN, it is common to young persons and elders: (Msb:) some of those who affect distinctness of speech by twisting the sides of the mouth say that the word is ↓ ZurofN, with damm, to distinguish it from ZarofN meaning “ a receptacle; ” but this is a sheer mistake. (MF, TA.)
ZurofN * : see what immediately precedes.

[
Zarofiy~apN * , a term of grammar, The quality of denoting place, or time, adverbially, by a noun implying the meaning of the preposition fiY; and also, accord. to some, by a noun together with that preposition. One says manoSuwbN EalaY AlZ~arofiy~api, meaning Put in the accusative case as denoting place, or time, adverbially.]
ZuraAfN * : see ZariyfN, near the beginning and near the end.

[
ZaruwfN * perhaps signifies Possessing the quality, or qualities, termed Zarof, in a great, or an extraordinary degree: used alike as masc. and fem.: for I find it stated that] one says qayonapN ZaruwfN [A female slave, or slave-songstress, that is very intelligent or skilful or elegant &c.]. (TA. [But I think it most probable that this is a mistranscripfor qitoyapN ZuruwfN, a phrase which I find in the T, and there expl. as meaning ZurafaA='u.])

ZariyfN *
Possessing the quality, or qualities, termed Zarof; (T, S, M, O, Msb, K;) as also ↓ ZuraAfN, (Lh, M, O, K,) the two being like TawiylN and TuwaAlN, (O,) [or the latter has an intensive signification, (see TuwaAlN, and see also the “ Durrat el-Ghowwás, ” in De Sacy's Anthol. Gramm. Arabe, p. 48 of the Ar. text,)] and ↓ Zur~aAfN, (M, K,) or this last, which is like Tuw~aAlN, denotes more than ZuraAfN without teshdeed: (O:) accord. to Mbr, it is derived from Zarof signifying “ a receptacle, ” as though meaning a receptacle for excellence, or elegance, in mind, manners, or address or speech: (TA:) [it may be rendered, agreeably with explanations of ZarofN, excellent, or elegant, in mind, manners, and address or speech; and in person, countenance or garb, guise, or external appearance: or clever, ingenious, intelligent, or acute in intellect; well-mannered, well-bred, accomplished, or polite; beautiful in person or countenance; elegant, or graceful; &c.:] and is expl. as meaning eloquent; thus by As and IAar: and possessing knowledge and courage: and goodly, or beautiful, in clothing, and in outer apparel: (TA:) and is used by the people of El-Yemen as meaning skilful: (O:) and, as Ks says, it is applied as an epithet to a tongue, and to a face: (TA:) the pl. of ZariyfN is ZiraAfN (S, M, O, Msb, K) and ZurafaA='u (T, S, O, Msb, K) and Zariyfuwna (O, K) and ZurufN, (S, M, IB, K,) a form sometimes used, (IB, TA,) and ZuruwfN, (T, S, M, O, K,) also a form sometimes used, (S, O,) approvable in poetry, (T,) as though formed from ZarofN, or [anomalous] like ma*aAkiyru (S, O, K) accord. to Kh (S, O) and Sb: (TA:) the pl. of ↓ ZuraAfN is ZurafaA='u: (Lh, M, K:) and the pl. of ↓ Zur~aAfN is Zur~aAfuwna: (M, K:) the fem. of ZariyfN is ZariyfapN; and the pl. of this is ZiraAfN, (Sb, T, M, Msb, TA,) like a pl. of the masc., (Sb, M, TA,) and ZaraAy^ifu. (T, M, TA.) It is said in a trad. of 'Omar, mentioned by IAar, (Mgh, O, TA,) and by As, (TA,) A_i*aA kaAna All~iS~u ZariyfFA laA yuqoTaEu, (Mgh,) or lamo yuqoTaEo, (O, TA,) meaning When the thief is eloquent (Mgh, O, TA) and intelligent, (Mgh,) he averts from himself the prescribed punishment by his pleading [so that he will not be, or is not, mutilated by amputation of the hand]. (Mgh, O, TA.)

[
ZariyfapN * , as a subst., A thing, and a saying, that is Zariyf, meaning elegant, &c.: pl. ZaraAy^ifu.]
Zur~aAfN * : see ZariyfN, near the beginning and near the end.

ZaArifN * [is distinguished from ZariyfN like as $aArifN is from $ariyfN, q. v.]. Lh mentions the saying AuZorufo A_ino kunota ZaArifFA [Possess thou Zarof if thou be one who will possess it]: in meaning the actual state, they said A_in~ahu laZariyfN [Verily he is one who possesses Zarof]. (M.)

A^aZorafu * : see 3. Ks allows the saying, interrogatively, maA A^aZorafu zayodK A^alisaAnuhu A^aZorafu A^amN wajohuhu [What is the part that is the more excellent in Zarof (or elegance, &c.), of Zeyd? is his tongue the more so, or his face?]. (TA.)
yaA maZorafaAnu * is an expression similar to yaA malokaEaAnu [and mako*abaAnu &c.; meaning O thou who possessest the quality, or qualities, of Zarof in a great, or an extraordinary degree]. (A, TA.)

1 ZaEana * , (S, Msb, K,) aor.
ZaEana , (Msb, K,) inf. n. ZaEonN (S, Msb, K) and ↓ ZaEanN, (S, K,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Msb,) and ZuEuwnN (TA) [and maZoEanN, occurring in a verse of Zuheyr cited in art. blw, conj. 3], He journeyed, went away, departed, (S, * Msb, K, * TA,) or removed; (Msb;) he journeyed to seek after herbage, or to water; or he removed from water to water, or from one country, or tract of land, to another. (TA. [See also the part. n., ZaAEinN.]) ― -b2- ZaEana bihi: see what next follows.

4 AZEnhu *
He made him to journey, go away, depart, (S, Msb, K,) or remove; and bihi ↓ ZaEana signifies the same [or he journeyed, &c., with him]. (Msb.)

8 AiZ~aEanatohu *
She rode him, (S, K, TA,) namely, a camel: you say, h`*aA baEiyrN taZ~aEinuhu AlmaroA^apu This is a camel that the woman rides (S, TA) in her journeying, and in the day of her departure. (TA.)
ZaEanN * : see 1: -A2- and see also ZaAEinN.

ZuEonapN *
A short journey. (TA.)

ZiEonapN *
A state or condition, or a mode or manner, of journeying or departing. (TA.)

ZiEaAnN *
A rope with which a hawodaj [or woman's camel-vehicle] is bound; (S, K;) or with which a load is bound, accord. to the T: and ↓ ZaEuwnN signifies the same. (TA.)
ZaEuwnN * A camel used for work and for bearing burdens: (S, K, TA:) or, as some say, peculiarly, [like ZaEiynapN,] a camel that is ridden by a woman. (TA.) -A2- See also ZiEaAnN.

ZaEiynapN *
A hawodaj [or woman's camel-vehicle] (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA) in which is a woman, (TA,) or whether there be in it a woman or not: (S, Msb, K, TA:) this is [said to be] the primary signification: (Mgh:) pl. ZaEaAy^inu and ZuEunN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and ZuEonN (S, K) and [pl. of pauc.] A^aZoEaAnN (S, Mgh, K) and pl. pl. ZuEunaAtN. (TA. [But see, in what follows, an assertion of AZ respecting the pl. ZuEunN.]) ― -b2- And A woman, (ISk, Mgh, Msb, TA;) whether in a hawodaj or elsewhere; (ISk, TA;) the word being used in the sense of maZoEuwnapN [for maZoEuwnN bihaA]; because her husband journeys (yaZoEanu) with her: (Msb:) or a man's wife; because she journeys with her husband: (TA:) or a woman as long as she is in the hwdj; (S, Msb, K;) when not in it she is not thus called: (S:) or this is the primary meaning: then it was applied to her though in her tent, because she might become maZoEuwnap [i. e. maZoEuwn bihaA]: (Msb:) it is mostly applied to a woman riding [in a hwdj]: then, to a hwdj without a woman: and to a woman without a hwdj. (TA.) 'Amr Ibn-Kulthoom says,
qifiY qabola Alt~afar~uqi yaA ZaEiynaA
nuxab~iroki Alyaqiyna watuxobiriynaA
[Pause thou before separation, O woman in the
camel-vehicle: we will inform thee of the real truth respecting our case, and thou shalt inform us respecting thy case]: (S:) yaA ZaEiynaA is for yaA ZaEiynapu. (EM p. 185.) ― -b3- And, accord. to Lth, A camel that is ridden by women: [like ZaEuwnN:] and applied to signify a woman because she rides it: or, accord. to IAmb, a camel upon which one journeys: and hence the trad., layosa fiY jamalK ZaEiynapK SadaqapN i. e. [There is no poor-rate in the case of] the camel upon which one journeys; if the phrase be thus: but if it be fiY jamali ZaEiynapK, by the last word is meant a woman: (TA:) AZ says, one should not say HumuwlN nor ZuEunN except as meaning the camels upon which are hawaAdij, whether there be in them women or not. (S.)

ZaAEinN *
Journeying, going away, departing, or removing: (Msb:) [a traveller:] any one going forth on a journey, on pilgrimage, or on a warring and plundering expedition, or journeying from one city [or town &c.] to another: contr. of xaAfiDN [and of muqiymN]: one says, A^aZaAEinN A^anota A^amo muqiymN [Art thou journeying or abiding?]: the pl. is ZaAEinuwna and ZuEunN, and ↓ ZaEanN is a quasipl. n. syn. with ZaAEinuwna. (TA.)
miZoEaAnN * , applied to a horse or mare, and to a she-camel, Easy in pace. (TA.)

maZoEuwnN *
Made to journey, go away, depart, or remove; originally maZoEuwnN bihi; the complement being suppressed because of frequency of usage. (Msb.)

1 Zafarahu * : see 2. -A2- [See also ZafarN. ― -b2- ] Zafirato Eayonuhu, (T, S, O, K,) aor.
Zafara , inf. n. ZafarN (S, O) and ZafaArapN; (O;) and, as some say, Zufirat; (T;) His eye had what is termed a Zafarap or Zufor. (T, S, O, K.) ― -b3- And Zufira He (a man) had upon his eye what is termed a Zafarap or Zufor. (T, O, K.) -A3- Zafira, aor.
Zafara , (Msb,) inf. n. ZafarN, He attained, got, got possession of, or acquired, what he desired, or sough: (Lth, * S, * M, * A, * Msb, K: *) he succeeded, or was successful: (Msb:) he won, was victorious, or gained the victory: (Lth, T:) and ↓ AiZ~afara [originally AiZotafara] signifies the same as Zafira. (S.) You say, Zafira bihi and Ealayohi, and Zafirahu, He attained it, got it, got possession of it, or acquired it; (M, K;) and in like manner ↓ AiZ~afara, of the measure AifotaEala. (K.) And Zafirotu biAlD~aAl~api I found the stray, or lost beast. (Msb.) And Zafira biEaduw~ihi (S, A, Msb) and Ealayohi, (Akh, S, A,) and Zafirahu, (S,) He gained the victory, or mastery, over his enemy; he overcame him. (S, * A, Msb. *) ― -b2- [Hence,] Zafirati Aln~aAqapu laqaHFA (tropical:) The she-camel took, or received, impregnation. (A, TA.) And maA Zafiratoka EayoniY (AZ, T, S, A, K) muno*u HiynK (AZ, T) or muno*u zamaAnKi (S, A) (tropical:) My eye hath not seen thee [for some time]: (AZ, T, S, A, K:) like maA A^axa*atoka. (AZ, T.) -A4- [Zafara in the dial. of Himyer is said by Freytag, on the authority of the Kitáb el-Addád, to signify He sat.]

2 Zf~r fiyhi * , (A, K,) inf. n. taZofiyrN, (S,) He inserted his nail into it; (S, A, K;) namely, an apple, and the like, (S, K,) a cucumber, and a melon: (A:) and [in like manner] ↓ AiZ~afara, of the measure AifotaEala, he stuck, or fixed, his nail [into a thing]; (S, K, TA;) and so AiT~afara, with the unpointed T. (TA.) You say, Zf~r fulaAnN fiY wajohi fulaAnK Such a one stuck his nail into the flesh of the face of such a one, and wounded it. (TA.) And nay~aba fiY laHomihi waZaf~ara He stuck his dog-tooth and his nail into his flesh, and wounded it. (A.) And Zf~r fulaAnN fiY ka*aA wanay~aba (tropical:) Such a one clung to, caught to, or took fast hold upon, such a thing. (A in art. nyb.) Also Zf~rhu; and ↓ Zafarahu, aor.
Zafira ; (M, K;) and ↓ AiZ~afarahu, in the K erroneously written A^aZofarahu; (TA;) He stuck his nail into his face; (M, K;) and so AiT~afarahu, with T. (TA.) And Zf~rhu [He clawed it;] he stuck his nail into it, (namely, anything,) and broke it, or made a mark [or scratch] upon it. (M.) And ↓ AiZ~afara AlS~aqoru AlT~aAy^ira The hawk seized the bird with his talons. (K.) ― -b2- Zf~r said of baqol [or herbs, or leguminous plants,] (tropical:) They put forth what resembled the A^aZofaAr [or talons] of the bird. (M, TA.) And said of the Earofaj, (K, TA,) and of the A^aroTaY, (TA,) (tropical:) It put forth what resembled A^aZofaAr, (K, TA,) when it put forth its [leaves termed] xuwS. (TA.) And said of the naSiY~, and of the wa$iyj, and of the barodiY~, and of the vumaAm, and of the Sil~iyaAn, and of the garaz, and of hadab, (tropical:) It, or they, put forth yellow shoots, resembling the Zufur [or talon], which are the xuwS thereof, that come forth therefrom having a dustcoloured flower. (M, TA.) [Or,] said of a plant, (Ks, T, S,) inf. n. as above, (Ks, T,) (assumed tropical:) It came forth; (Ks, T;) from AlA^aZofaAr: (T:) or it came forth of the measure of the Zufor [or nail]. (S.) And Zf~rt AlA^aroDu (assumed tropical:) The land put forth plants, or herbage, that might be uprooted (yumokinu A@HotifaAw^uhu, so in the M, in the K A@HotifaAruhu,) with the nail, (M,) or with the fingers. (K.) ― -b3- Zf~r vawobahu, (M, and so in a copy of the K,) inf. n. as above, (K,) (assumed tropical:) He perfumed his garment (M, and thus in that copy of the K) with what is termed Zufor: (M:) or Zf~r vawobahu biAlA^aZofaAri he perfumed his garment with what are termed A^aZofaAr. (So accord. to other copies of the K.) ― -b4- And Zf~r Aljiloda, (K,) or Zaf~arotu Aljiloda, (M,) (assumed tropical:) He, (K,) or I, (M,) rubbed the skin in order that its A^aZofaAr (M, K) which means its creased parts (M) might become smooth. (M, K.) -A2- Zf~rhu also signifies, and so ↓ AZfrhu, [He caused him to attain, get, get possession of, or acquire, what he desired, or sought: he caused him to succeed, or to be successful: and] He (God) caused him to be victorious, to gain the victory, or to overcome. (A.) You say, Zf~rhu bihi (S, M) and Ealayohi, (M, TA,) inf. n. as above; (S;) and bh ↓ AZfrhu (S, M, Msb) and Elyh; (M, Msb;) He (God, S, M, or a man, Msb) caused him to gain the victory over him, or to overcome him, (M, Msb,) namely, his enemy. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- And Zf~rhu Ealayohi He declared him to have overcome him: said of one who has been asked which of two persons had overcome. (T.) ― -b3- And Zf~rhu, (M, K,) inf. n. as above, (K,) He prayed for him that he might attain what he desired, or sought; or that he might be successful, or victorious. (M, K.)
4 A^aZofara see the next preceding paragraph, latter part, in two places.

6 tZAfrwA Ealayohi * and tDAfrwA and tZAhrwA all signify the same; so says Ibn-Buzurj; (T, TA;) explaining the meaning to be, They leagued together, and aided one another, against him; i. e. EalaY fulaAnK [against such a one]: (TA in art. Dfr:) the first of these has been said to be incorrect; but it is mentioned also by Sgh, as syn. with the third; and by Ibn-Málik, among words that are with D and with Z. (TA in the present art.)
8 A_iZotafara see 2, in three places: -A2- and see also 1, in two places.
ZaforN * : see the next paragraph.

ZuforN * (T, S, M, A, Msb, K, &c.) and ↓ ZufurN, (Msb, K,) which latter is the most chaste form, and the form adopted by the seven readers in the Kur vi. 147, and the former is a contraction of this, [but is the most common form,] (Msb,) and ↓ ZiforN, which is extr., (M, Msb, K,) and disallowed by IDrd, (O,) and ↓ ZifirN, which is also extr., (Msb,) and ↓ A^uZofuwrN, (T, M, A, Msb, K,) which is erroneously mentioned in the S as a pl. of ZuforN, (Sgh, Msb, K,) by an anticipation of the pen; (Msb;) or, accord. to MF, it si said in most of the copies of the S, (but this is not the case,) ZuforN has for its pl. A^aZofaArN; and A^uZofuwrN [has for its pl.] A^aZaAfiyru; (TA;) [and this, being the reading in most of the copies of the S seen by MF, is probably what J wrote;] A certain wellknown thing; (M;) [i. e. a nail; and a talon, or claw;] pertaining to a human being, (M, Ibn-Es-Seed, Msb, K,) and to others; (M, K;) to the beasts and birds mentioned in the next following sentence, [as well as to man,] accord. to the authorities there cited; (TA;) and to every ruminant, as syn. with ZilofN [i. e. a cloven hoof]: (T and M in art. Zlf:) or to a beast, or bird, that does not prey; [as well as to man;] that of such as preys being termed mixolabN: (M:) [and in the present day applied also to the spur of a cock:] it is of the masc. gender: (Lh, M, Msb:) the pl. (of ZuforN, S, M, Msb, &c.) is A^aZofaArN (S, M, Msb, K, &c.) and sometimes A^aZofurN, (Msb,) [both of which are pls. of pauc., but the former is used as a pl. of mult. also,]. and (of A^uZofuwrN, M, Msb, or
of A^aZofaArN, and therefore a pl. pl., M) A^aZaAfiyru: (M, Msb, K:) that ↓ A^uZofuwrN is a sing. [and not like A^uboquwrN which is a quasi-pl. n.] is shown by the saying of a poet,
maA bayona luqomatihaA AlA^uwlaY A_i*aA A@noHadarato
wabayona A^uxoraY taliyhaA qiysu A^uZofuwri
(K) or qiydu A^uZofuwri (Msb) [i. e. What is between her first morsel, when it descends into her throat, and another that follows it, is the measure of a finger-nail]: or, as some relate it, A_i*aA A@zodaradato [when she swallows]; and it is thus cited [in the T and] in the “ Basáïr ” of the author of the K. (TA.) The phrase kul~a *iY ZufurK in the Kur vi. 147 comprises camels and ostriches; (so in the T and TS and L; but in the K, AlA^anoEaAm is erroneously put for Aln~aEaAm; TA;) because their manaAsim are like A^aZofaAr to them: (T, K, TA:) I'Ab says that it comprises camels; and also ostriches, because they have nails like camels: or any bird that has a mixolab, and any beast that has a solid hoof: or, accord. to Mujáhid and Katádeh, every beast and bird that has not divided toes; as the camel and ostrich and goose and duck. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AlA^aZofaAru is the name of (assumed tropical:) Certain small stars; (S;) certain stars before Aln~asor [meaning Aln~asor AlwaAqiE i. e. the star a of Lyra: app. because regarded as the talons of the nsr]: (K:) or a certain dim star in Al$~aloyaAq [q. v., i. e. the constellation Lyra]. (Kzw.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] A_in~ahu lakaliylu AlZ~ufori, (T,) or A_in~ahu lamaqoluwmu AlZ~ufori, (TA,) (tropical:) Verily he is one who does not slay or wound an enemy: (T, TA:) and A_in~ahu maqoluwmu AlZ~ufori Eano A^a*aY Aln~aAsi (tropical:) Verily he is one who does little hurt to mankind. (T, A, TA.) And huwa kaliylu AlZ~ufori (tropical:) He is weak, or abject, or despicable; (T, S, K, TA;) said of a man; (K, TA;) or so muqal~amu AlZ~ufori: (K: [in the TA, as from the K, muqal~amu AlA^aZofaAri:]) or (tropical:) he is sick, or diseased. (A.) And bihi ZuforN mino maraDK (tropical:) [app. meaning In him is an evil result of a disease, that has clung to him]. (A, TA. [In the A, this immediately follows what here next precedes it; and is immediately followed by the words wa*ubaAbN Zafira minohu, which seem to be added by way of explanation; thus in my copy; but I think that Zafira minohu here is a mistake for Zaf~ara fiyhi, and have assumed this to be the case in rendering the phrase.]) ― -b4- And qar~aHotuhu mino Zuforihi A_ilaY $uforihi (tropical:) [lit. I wounded him much, from his nail to the edge of his eyelid; but mentioned as tropical; app. meaning from toe to head]; like as one says, mino qaronihi. (A.) ― -b5- And maA baAld~aAri ZuforN, (K,) or mA bAldAr ZuforN walaA $uforN, (A, O,) (tropical:) There is not in the house any one. (A, O, K.) And maA tarakati Als~anapu ZuforFA walaA $uforFA (tropical:) The year of drought left not anything: and sometimes they said $aforFA, with fet-h, and in this case they said ↓ ZaforFA, for assimilation. (A in art. $fr.) And raA^ayotuhu biZuforihi (tropical:) I saw him himself. (O, K, TA.) ― -b6- Zuforu Aln~asori is the name of (assumed tropical:) A certain plant, (K, TA,) resembling what is [properly] thus termed [i. e. the talon of the vulture]. (TA.) And Zuforu AlqiT~i is the name of (assumed tropical:) Another plant. (K, TA.) ― -b7- And AlZ~uforu, (M,) or AlA^aZofaAru, (T, M, A, Mgh, O, K, &c.,) for this word in the sense here following has no sing. (T, M, O, K) accord. to the author of the 'Eyn, (M,) but sometimes one said waAHidapN ↓ A^aZofaArapN, which is not allowable by rule, and made the pl. of this to be A^aZaAfiyru, (T, O, K, * [mentioned in the M as a pl. of AlZ~uforu,]) though, if they formed a sing. from it, it should be ZuforN, (T, O, K,) signifies (tropical:) A certain odoriferous substance, (T, Mgh, O, K,) or a sort thereof, (M,) [i. e. unguis odoratus, (called in the present day Zuforu AlT~iybi and Zuforu AlEiforiyti,) or ungues odorati,] black, (T, M, O,) resembling a Zufor [or nail] (T, M, Mgh, O, K) of a man (M) pulled out (in the M and O and K muqotulaf, and in the T muqal~af,) from the root thereof, (T, M, O, K, [but in the M, the words which I have rendered “ pulled out ” &c. immediately follow the words DarobN mina AlEiTori A^asowadu,]) or resembling the A^aZofaAr [or finger-nails], (A,) and put into duxotap [or incense]: (T, M, O:) and, accord. to the K, ↓ ZafaArN, sometimes imperfectly decl., i. e. ↓ ZafaAru, signifies the same; but this is very strange, for [SM says] I have referred to the M and T and O and other lexicons without finding them to have mentioned in this sense any term but AlA^aZofaAru or AlZ~uforu: accord. to the “ Minháj, ” A^aZofaAru AlT~iybi are pieces of an odoriferous substance resembling the A^aZofaAr [properly so called]; they are said by [the Arabic translator of] Dioscorides to be of the nature of the shards of shells, [so I render mino jinosi A^axozaAfi AlS~adafi, supposing AxzAf to be here used tropically,] found in an island of the Sea of India where is the sunobul [or spikenard], a sort whereof is [called] qulozumiY~ [i. e. of El-Kulzum], and another which is [called] baAbiliY~ [i. e. of Bábil], black and small, and the best is that which inclines to whiteness, which drifts to El-Yemen and El-Bahreyn. (TA.) [Forskål, in his “ Descr. Animalium ” &c., mentions what here follows, among the animal substances of the materia medica of Cairo, in page 143: “ Unguis odoratus. (Opercula Cochl.) Dofr el afrît, Dfr AlEfryt i. e. unguis dæmonis. E Mochha per Sués. Arabes etiam afferunt. Nigritis fumigatorium est. ” (Dfr is here written, agreeably with the usual vulgar pronunciation, for Zufor.) See also qusoTN,] ― -b8- A^aZofaArN signifies also (assumed tropical:) Large qirodaAn [or ticks]. (S, O, K.) ― -b9- And (assumed tropical:) The creased parts of a skin. (M, TA.) ― -b10- And the Zufor of a bow is (tropical:) The part in the curved end that is beyond the place where the string is tied, to the extremity: (As, T, S, M, * O, K: *) or the end of the bow: (K:) or each end of the bow, beyond the place where the string is tied: (A:) pl. ZifarapN. (M, TA.) ― -b11- See also ZafarapN.
ZiforN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

ZafarN * , in a man, The quality of having long nails. (ISk, S, O.) [App., in this sense, an inf. n. of which the verb is Zafira; as it is in other senses: see 1.] -A2- See also ZafarapN. -A3- Also Low, or depressed, ground, (S, O, K,) that produces plants, or herbage. (S, O.)

ZafirN *
Sharp in the nail [or having sharp nails]. (A.) ― -b2- And A man having upon his eye what is termed a Zafarap; (A;) and so ↓ maZofuwrN. (T, A, Mgh, K.) ― -b3- And EayonN ZafirapN An eye having what is termed a Zafarap; (T, M, A, K;) as also ↓ maZofuwrapN. (A.) -A2- Also [Successful;] victorious; applied to a man; (S;) and so ↓ ZaAfirN: (Msb, TA:) or ZafirN (IDrd, M, A, K) and ↓ ZafiyrN (IDrd, M, K) and ↓ Zif~iyrN, (IDrd, Sgh, K) but this is said by IDrd to be not of established authority, (TA,) and ↓ muZaf~arN (IDrd, M, A, K) and ↓ miZofaArN, (IDrd, O, K,) all signify a man very, or often, successful or victorious: (IDrd, O, TA:) or (tropical:) one who does not endeavour after a thing without attaining it. (M, A, K.)
ZufurN * and ZifirN: see ZuforN.

ZuforapN *
A certain plant, burning, or biting, to the tongue, (K, TA,) resembling the Zufor [or nail] in its coming forth, (TA,) that has a beneficial effect upon foul ulcers, and warts. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And Zuforapu AlEajuwzi The rounded head of prickles of the [thistle called] Hasak. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- See also the next paragraph.

ZafarapN *
A pellicle that comes over the eye, (T, S, Mgh, O, K,) growing from the side next the nose, (T, S, O,) upon the white of the eye, (S, Mgh, O,) extending to the black: (S, O:) sometimes it is cut off: if left, it covers the eye, and obscures the sight: (T:) or a certain disease in the eye, which causes a tegument like the nail to come over it: or a piece of flesh that grows at the inner angle of the eye, extending to the black, and sometimes encroaching upon the black: (M:) it is also called ↓ ZuforN (A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, Mgh, O, K) and ↓ ZuforapN, (T, Mgh,) these two terms being applied to it by the physicians, (Mgh,) and ↓ ZafarN (TA) and ↓ ZifaArapN, (so in a copy of the T, as on the authority of Ibn-Buzurj,) or ↓ ZafaArapN. (So in the O.)

ZafaArN * and ZafaAru: see ZuforN. -A2- [ZafaAri is well known as the name of a city in El-Yemen; or, accord. to the O, of two cities and two fortresses in El-Yemen. And accord. to the TA, it signifies Any land that is *At maEaz~ap: but the latter of these two words has been altered by an erasure over the second letter, and is perhaps incorrect: if not, it may mean, agreeably with the analogy of many words of the measure mafoEalapN, as maqodarapN and mafolaHapN and manojaApN &c., such as possesses means of overcoming, or withstanding, invaders: and it may be that hence ZafaAri is in two instances the name of a fortress.]
ZafuwrN * [app. syn. with ZafirN and ZafiyrN] is one of the appellations of the Prophet. (MF, TA.)
ZafiyrN * : see ZafirN.
ZafaArapN * or ZifaArapN: see ZafarapN.

jazoEN ZafaAriY~N * [onyx of Dhafári] is so called in relation to ZafaAri, a city of El-Yemen, (T, S, Mgh, O, K,) near SanoEaA=', (K,) two days' journey from the latter. (O.) And in like manner, EuwdN ZafaAriY~N [Aloes-wood of Dhafári]: i. e. the Ewd with which one fumigates: (S:) or qusoT, (O, K, TA,) which means the same, (TA, [but see this word,]) is called [qusoTu ZafaAri and qusoTN ZafaAriY~N] in relation to ZafaAri, another city of El-Yemen, near mirobaAT, (O, K, TA,) described by Yákoot as in the furthest part of El-Yemen, on the shore of the Sea of India, near Al$~aHor; (TA;) because it is brought thither from India. (O, K, TA.)
Zif~iyrN * : see ZafirN.
ZaAfirN * : see ZafirN.

A^aZofaru * A man having long nails: (ISk, S, A:) or having long and broad nails: (M, K:) and in like manner applied to a manosim [or foot of a camel]: ZaforaA='u [the reg. fem.] has not been heard. (M.)
A^uZofuwrN * : see ZuforN, in two places. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) The slender thing [or tendril] that twines upon the branch of a grape-vine. (K.)
A^aZofaArapN * : see ZuforN, latter half.

muZaf~arN * : see ZafirN. -A2- qawosN muZaf~arapN (assumed tropical:) A bow having somewhat cut off from each of its two ends [which are called its ZuforaAni]. (O, K, TA. [In the CK, farasN is erroneously put for qawosN.])
miZofaArN * : see ZafirN. -A2- Also The [instrument called] minoqaA$ [q. v.]. (Fr, O, K.)
maZofuwrN * ; and its fem.: see ZafirN. -A2- maZofuwrN bihi Overcome, or conquered; [as also maZofuwrN Ealayohi, and maZofuwrN alone; (see 1;)] applied to a man. (TA.)

1 Zal~a * , aor. yaZil~u, inf. n. ZilaAlapN: see 4. -A2- Zal~a, (T, M, Msb, K,) first pers. Zalilotu, (T, S, M, O, Msb, K,) [and accord. to SM Zalalotu also, for he says that] the verb is of the class of manaEa as well as of the class of taEiba, (TA,) and Zalotu, (T, S, * M, O, K,) likened to lasotu, (M, K, *) formed by rejecting the former l in Zalilotu, (T, O,) and Zilotu, which is [also] originally Zalilotu, (Sb, T, M, O, K,) formed by transferring to the Z the vowel of the rejected l, (Sb, T, M, O,) anomalously, (Sb, M,) the latter of the dial. of the people of El-Hijáz; (T;) aor. yaZal~u; (S, * M, O, * Msb, K;) imperative AiZolalo and Zalo (T) [and it is implied in the M voce qar~a that one says also AiZolilo and Zilo, which indicates that the aor. is also yaZil~u, but this requires confirmation, which I have not anywhere found]; inf. n. ZuluwlN (T, S, M, O, Msb, K) and Zal~N (M, K) and Zil~N; (thus also in a copy of the M; [but this I think doubtful;]) accord. to Lth, (T,) or Kh, (Msb,) [i. e. accord. to the author of the 'Eyn,] is said only of a thing that is done in the day, or daytimes; (T, S, M, O, Msb;) like as baAta, aor. yabiytu, is said only of a thing that is done in the night: (T:) it is an incomplete [i. e. a non-attributive] verb, relating to a time in which is a shade from the sun, from morning to evening, or from sunrise to sunset: (Esh-Shiháb, TA:) one says, Zal~a fulaAnN nahaArahu SaAy^imFA [Such a one was during his day fasting; or he passed his day fasting]: (Lth, T:) and Zal~a nahaArahu yafoEalu ka*aA [He was in, or during, his day doing such a thing; or he passed his day doing such a thing]: (M, K:) and Zalilotu A^aEomalu ka*aA [I was in the day or daytime, or I passed the day, doing such a thing; or] I did such a thing in the day or daytime. (S, O, Msb. *) In the saying of 'Antarah,
walaqado A^abiytu EalaY AlT~awaY waA^aZal~uhu
Hat~aY A^anaAla bihi kariyma AlmaA^okali
[app. meaning And verily I pass the night in hunger, and I pass the day in it, that I may attain thereby plentiful eating], A^aZal~uhu is for A^aZal~u Ealayohi. (S, O.) And accord. to some, (TA,) Zal~a layolahu occurs in poetry; (M, K, TA;) so that one says, Zal~a layolahu yafoEalu ka*aA [He was in, or during, his night, or he passed his night, doing such a thing]: but it is said that in this case the verb has the meaning next following. (TA.) ― -b2- And it signifies also He, or it, became; syn. SaAra: (Er-Rághib, TA:) being in this sense likewise an incomplete [i. e. a non-attributive] verb, divested of that meaning of time which it radically denotes; as in the phrase in the Kur [xvi. 60 and xliii. 16], Zal~a wajohuhu musowad~FA [His face becomes black]: so says Ibn-Málik: (TA:) or this may mean his face continues all the day black: (Bd in xvi. 60:) and one says also, Zal~a yafoEalu ka*aA meaning He continued doing such a thing: this too is mentioned by Ibn-Málik, and is of the dial. of the people of Syria. (TA.) ― -b3- It is also a complete [i. e. an attributive] verb as meaning He, or it, continued; as is said in the Expos. of the “ Shifè, ” and by Ibn-Málik; and, as Ibn-Málik likewise says, it was, or became, long. (TA.)

2 Zll~`hu Ealayohi * [He made it to give shade over him, or it,] (M,) inf. n. taZoliylN. (O.) It is said in the Kur [vii. 160, and the like is said in ii. 54], waZal~alonaA Ealayohimu AlgamaAma And we made the clouds to give shade over them. (M.) ― -b2- [And Zll~`hu signifies He shaded him, or it. See an ex. in a verse of Jereer in art. rdf, conj. 3.] l`kino EalaY AlA^avalaAti laHomN laA yuZal~alu [But at the tamarisk-trees is flesh that will not be shaded, or, accord. to the reading given by Meyd, biAlA^avalaAti,] is a prov., said by Beyhes, in allusion to the flesh of his slain brothers, on the occasion of persons saying, Zal~iluwA laHoma jazuwrikumo [Shade ye the flesh of your slaughtered camel]. (S, O.) -A2- See also 4. -A3- One says also Zl~l biAls~awoTi, meaning He made a sign with the whip for the purpose of frightening. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

4 AZl~ * , said of a day, It was, (S, O,) or became, (M, K,) shady, or a day having shade: (S, M, O, K:) or it was a day having clouds, or other [causes of shade]: (T:) or it was continually shady; as also ↓ Zal~a, aor. yaZil~u, inf. n. ZilaAlapN. (Msb.) ― -b2- And, said of a thing, [It extended its shade; or] its shade extended; as also ↓ Zl~l. (Msb.) -A2- A^aZal~atoniY Al$~ajarapu [The tree shaded me, or afforded me shade]: and in like manner one says of other things than trees. (S, O.) A^aZal~aka said of a building, or of a mountain, or of a cloud, means It protected thee, and cast its shade upon thee. (Mgh.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AZl~hu (assumed tropical:) He took him into his shelter, or protection: (TA:) or he guarded, or protected, him, and placed him within the scope of his might, or power of resistance or defence. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ― -b3- And A^aZal~aniY (assumed tropical:) It (a thing) covered me: (M, K:) or it approached me, or drew near to me, so as to cast its shade upon me: (K:) or it has both of these meanings: (M:) or A^aZal~aka means he, (T, S,) or it, (O,) approached thee, or drew near to thee, as though he, or it, cast his, or its, shade upon thee. (T, S, O.) And hence one says, A^aZal~aka A^amorN (assumed tropical:) An event approached thee, or drew near to thee: (S, O:) and in like manner one says of a month. (T, S, O.) And AZl~ [alone] (assumed tropical:) It (a thing) advanced: or approached, or drew near. (Msb.) And i. q. A^a$orafa [app. as meaning (assumed tropical:) He, or it, became within sight, or view]. (Msb.)

5 taZal~a3a see the next paragraph. It is also pronounced taZal~aY: (IAar, T:) and signifies He kept to shady places, and to ease, or repose: (IAar, T and K in art. ZlY:) it is like taZan~ayotu from AlZ~an~u. (T in that art.)

10 AstZl~ * , (T,) or AstZl~ biAliZ~il~i, (Msb, TA,) He (a man, T) sheltered, or protected, himself by means of the shade: (T, TA:) or the latter means he inclined to the shade and sat in it. (M, K.) And AstZl~ mina Al$~aYo'i and bihi means ↓ taZal~ala [i. e. he shaded himself (tZl~l being quasi-pass. of Zal~alahu) from the thing and by means of it]. (M, K.) You say, AstZl~ bihi mina Al$~amosi [He shaded himself with it, or by means of it, from the sun]. (T.) And AstZl~ biAl$~ajarapi He shaded and sheltered himself by means of the tree. (Ibn-'Abbád, S, O.) ― -b2- AstZl~ Ald~amu The blood was in the jawof [or belly, or interior of the belly, or the chest]. (T, O, K, TA. [In the CK, mn Aljawofi is put for fiY Aljawofi.]) ― -b3- AstZl~t AlEayonu,
(T, Ibn-'Abbád, O,) or AlEuyuwnu, (K,) The eye, (T, Ibn-'Abbád, O,) meaning that of a she-camel, (Ibn-'Abbád, O,) or the eyes, (K,) sank, or became depressed, in the head. (T, Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) ― -b4- And AstZl~ Alkaromu The grape-vine became luxuriant, or abundant and dense, in its branches whereon were the bunches. (M, K.)

Zil~N * properly signifies Shade; i. e. the light of the sun without the rays: when there is no light, it is ZulomapN, not Zil~N: (S, O:) contr. of DiH~N: (M, K:) or i. q. faYo'N: (K:) so some say: (M:) or so the [common] people say: (IKt, Msb:) or the former is [shade] in the morning; and the latter is in the evening: (M, K:) or, accord. to IKt, the former is in the morning and in the evening; but the latter is only after the declining of the sun from the meridian: ISk says that the former is from the rising of the sun to its declining; and the latter, from the declining to the setting: Th says that the Zil~ of a tree &c. is in the morning; and the faYo', in the evening: (Msb:) Ru-beh says, (M, Msb,) any place, (M,) or any thing, (Msb,) upon which the sun has been and which it has quitted is termed Zil~N and faYo'N; (M, Msb;) but a thing [or place] upon which the sun has not been is termed Zil~N [only]; and hence it is said that the sun annuls, or supersedes, the Zil~, and the faYo' annuls, or supersedes, the sun: (Msb:) AHeyth says, the Zil~ is anything upon which the sun has not come; and the term faYo' is applied only after the declining of the sun; the faYo' being eastwards and the Zil~ being westwards; and the Zil~ being termed Zil~ from the beginning of the day to the declining of the sun; after which it is termed faYo' until the night: (T, TA:) one says the Zil~ of Paradise, but not its faYo', because the sun will never replace its Zil~; but En-Nábighah El-Jaadee has assigned to Paradise faYo' having ZilaAl: (M, TA:) in a verse of Aboo-Sakhr ElHudhalee, Zil~N is made fem. as meaning maniy~ap [i. e. death]: (Ham p. 161:) the pl. [of mult.] is ZilaAlN (S, M, O, K) and ZuluwlN and [of pauc.] A^aZolaAlN. (M, O, K.) The saying of a rájiz,
kaA^an~amaA wajohuka Zil~N mino Hajaro
[As though thy face were a shade of a stone] is said to mean hardness of face, and shamelessness: or the being black in the face: (T, TA:) for the Arabs say that there is nothing more dense in shade than a stone. (TA.) qado DaHaA Zil~uhu [His shade, or shadow, has become sun] is said of the dead. (TA.) mar~a binaA kaA^an~ahu Zil~u *iy^obK [He passed by us as though he were the shadow of a wolf] means swiftly, as does a wolf. (M.) AinotaEalato ZilaAlahaA (assumed tropical:) [They made their shadows to be as though they were sandals to them] is said of camels or other beasts when it is midday in summer and they have no shadow [but such as is beneath them]: a rájiz says,
qado waradato tamo$iY EalaY ZilaAlihaA
wa*aAbati Al$~amosu EalaY qilaAlihaA
[They came to the water walking upon their shadows, and the sun was intensely hot upon the tops of their heads and humps]. (T.) And one says, huwa yatobaEu Zil~a nafosihi (tropical:) [He follows the shadow of himself; i. e. a thing that he will not overtake; for], as a poet says, the shadow that goes with thee thou wilt not overtake by following: and huwa yubaAriY Zil~a nafosihi (tropical:) [He strives to outstrip the shadow of himself], meaning that he walks with a proud and self-conceited gait: so in the A. (TA.) And Ainotaqalotu Eano Zil~iY (tropical:) I left my state, or condition. (TA.) And taraka AlZ~aboYu Zil~ahu: so in the T and S and O: (TA:) but [said to be] correctly, A^atorukuhu taroka AlZ~aboYi Zil~ahu, (K,) or laA^atorukan~ahu, (M, TA,) i. e. [I will forsake him, or I will assuredly forsake him, as the gazelle forsakes] the place of its shade: (O, TA:) [each, however, is app. right; and the former is the more agreeable with the following explanations:] a prov., (M,) applied to the man who is wont to take fright and flee; for the gazelle, when it takes fright and flees from a thing, never returns to it: (S, O, K:) by the Zil~ is here meant the covert in which it shades and shelters itself in the vehemence of the heat; then the hunter comes to it and rouses it, and it will not return thither; and one says, taraka AlZ~aboYu Zil~ahu, meaning the place of its shade: it is applied to him who takes fright and flees from a thing, and forsakes it so as not to return to it; and to the case of a man's forsaking his companion. (Meyd.) [vaqiylu AlZ~il~i as applied to a man, see expl. in art. vql: see also Har p. 250, where it is indicated that it may be rendered One whose shadow, even, is oppressive, and therefore much more so is his person.] In the phrase walaA A@lZ~il~u walaA A@loHaruwru, (M, K) in the Kur [xxxv. 20], Th says, accord. to some, (M,) AlZ~il~u means Paradise; (M, K;) and AlHaruwru, the fire [of Hell]: but he adds, I say that AlZ~il~u is the Zil~ itself [i. e. shade], and AlHaruwru is the Har~ itself [i. e. heat]: (M: [see also HaruwrN:]) and Er-Rághib says that Zil~N is sometimes assigned to anything; whether it be approved, as in the phrase above mentioned; or disapproved, as in waZil~K mino yaHomuwmK in the Kur [lvi. 42, meaning And shade of smoke, or black smoke]. (TA.) And AlZ~ilaAlu means ZilaAlu Aljan~api [The shades of Paradise]: (Fr, T, O, K, TA:) in some copies of the K, waAlZ~ilaAlu Aljan~apu, which is a mistake: (TA:) [but this requires consideration; for] El-'Abbás Ibn- 'Abd-El-Muttalib says,
mino qabolihaA Tibota fiY AlZ~ilaAli wafiY
musotawodaEK Hayovu yuxoSafu Alwaraqu
[Before it t?? wast good in, or in the shades of, Paradise, and in a depositary in the part where leaves are sewed together to conceal the pudenda]; (T, O, TA;) i. e. before thy descent to the earth (to which the pronoun in qblhA relates), thou wast good in the loins of Adam when he was in Paradise. (TA.) Aljan~apu taHota ZilaAli Als~uyuwfi [Paradise is beneath the shades of the swords] is a trad., meaning that fighting against unbelievers is a way of attaining to Paradise. (Marg. note in a copy of the “ Jámi' es-Sagheer.) mulaAEibu Zil~ihi is an appellation of A certain bird; [see art. lEb;] and one says mulaAEibaA Zil~ihimaA; and mulaAEibaAtu Zil~ihin~a: but when you make them indeterminate, you say mulaAEibaAtu A^aZolaAlihin~a. (T, O, K. [But in the TA in art. lEb, it is said that one dualizes and pluralizes both nouns, because the appellation becomes determinate.]) ― -b2- Zil~u All~ayoli means (tropical:) The blackness of the night: (T, S, O, Msb;) metaphorically thus termed; (S;) as in the saying, A^ataAnaA fiY Zil~i All~ayoli [He came to us in the blackness of the night]: (S, O:) or it signifies junoHu All~ayoli [app. as meaning the darkness, and confusedness, of the night; see junoHN]; (M, TA;) or so AlZ~il~u: (K:) or this means the night, (M, K, TA,) itself; (M, TA;) so the astronomers say: (TA:) all the night is Zil~N: and so is all the period from the shining of the dawn to the rising of the sun. (T.) ― -b3- Zil~u Aln~ahaAri is The colour of the day when the sun predominates over it [app. meaning when the light of the sun predominates over that of the early dawn]. (K.) ― -b4- Zil~u Als~aHaAbi means Such, of the clouds, as conceal the sun: or the blackness of the clouds. (M, K.) ― -b5- And ZilaAlu AlbaHori means The waves of the sea; (O, K, TA;) because they are raised so as to shade the ship and those that are in it. (TA.) ― -b6- Zil~N also signifies A xayaAl (M, O, K) that is seen, (M, K,) [i. e. an apparition, a phantom, or a thing that one sees like a shadow, i. e. what we term a shade,] of the jinn, or genii, and of others: (M, O, K:) or the like of a xayaAl of the jinn. (T.) ― -b7- Also Anything that shades one. (TA.) ― -b8- And it is the subst. from A^aZal~aniY Al$~aYo'u meaning “ the thing covered me; ” (M, K;) [i. e. it means A covering;] in which sense Th explains it in the phrase A_ilaY Zil~K *iY valaAvi $uEabK [in the Kur lxxvii. 30, Unto a covering having three parts, or divisions]; saying, the meaning is that the fire will have covered them; not that its Zil~ will be like that of the present world. (M. [See $uEobapN.]) And Zil~u Al$~aYo'i means (assumed tropical:) That which serves for the veiling, covering, or protecting, of the thing; syn. kin~uhu. (M.) [Hence] one says, fulaAnN yaEiy$u fiY Zil~i fulaAnK i. e. (assumed tropical:) [Such a one lives] in the shelter, or protection, of such a one. (T, * S, O, Msb, * K. *) And Als~uloTaAnu Zil~u A@ll~`hi fiY AlA^aroDi, (O, TA,) a saying of the Prophet, (O,) [meaning (assumed tropical:) The sovereign, or ruling, power is God's means of defence in the earth,] because he wards off
harm from the people like as the Zil~ [properly so called] wards off the harm of the heat of the sun: (TA:) or the meaning is, (assumed tropical:) God's means of protection: or God's xaAS~ap [or special servant]. (O, TA.) ― -b9- Also (assumed tropical:) Might; or power of resistance or defence: (M, K, TA:) whence [as some say] its usage in the Kur xiii. 35, and the usage of [the pl.] ZilaAl in xxxvi. 56 and in lxxvii. 41: [but the primary signification is more appropriate in these instances:] and so in the saying, jaEalaniY fiY Zil~ihi [i. e. (assumed tropical:) He placed me within the scope of his might, or power of resistance or defence]: so says Er-Rághib. (TA.) ― -b10- And (assumed tropical:) A state of life ample in its means or circumstances, unstraitened, or plentiful, and easy, pleasant, soft, or delicate. (TA.) ― -b11- Also (assumed tropical:) The beginning of winter. (T, O. [Accord. to the copies of the K, of youthfulness: but I think that Al$~abaAb in this instance, in the K, is evidently a mistranscription for Al$~itaA='.]) And (assumed tropical:) The vehemence (T, O, K) of the heat (T, O) of summer. (T, O, K.) ― -b12- Also (assumed tropical:) The $axoS [as meaning person of a human being, and as meaning the bodily or corporeal form or figure or substance which one sees from a distance, or the material substance,] of anything; (M, K, TA; [in the second and third of which is added, “ or its kin~, ” a signification which I have mentioned above on the authority of the M;]) because of its [apparent] blackness [or darkness, resembling that of a shade or shadow]: (M, TA:) whence the saying, laA yufaAriqu Zil~iY Zil~aka (assumed tropical:) [My person will not quit thy person]; like the saying, laA yufaAriqu sawaAdiY sawaAdaka: and the following exs. have been cited as instances of Zil~ in the sense of $axoS: the saying of a poet,
lam~aA nazalonaA rafaEonaA Zil~a A^axobiyapK
[as though meaning When we alighted, we raised the material fabric of tents], for it is said that they do not set up the Zil~ which is the faYo', but they only set up the tents; and the saying of another,
tatab~aEa A^afoyaA='a AlZ~ilaAli Ea$iy~apF
[as though meaning He followed the shadows of the material objects in the evening]: but Er-Rághib says that the former means, we raised the tents, and so raised the Zil~ thereof; and in the other ex., AlZlAl is a general term, and AlfaYo' [or AfyA='] is a special term, so that it is an instance of the A_iDaAfap of a thing to its kind [i. e. of prefixing a noun to one significant of its kind]. (TA.) [See also ZalaAlapN.] ― -b13- And accord. to Ibn- 'Abbád, (O,) it signifies also The nap, or villous substance, upon the surface of a garment, or piece of cloth; syn. ziy^obirN. (O, K.)

Zal~apN *
i. q. A_iqaAmapN [Continuance, residence, abode, &c.]. (K.) ― -b2- And i. q. SiH~apN: thus accord. to the copies of the K; but this may be a mistranscription; for Az and others mention, among the significations of Zl~p, [in a copy of the T, written in this case, as in others, ↓ Zul~ap,] that of SayoHapN [q. v.]. (TA.)

Zul~apN *
A thing that covers, or protects, [or shades,] one, overhead: accord. to Lth, i. q. ↓ maZal~apN or miZal~apN meaning a thing that shades one from the sun: (T:) see an ex. voce miZal~apN: a covering: and i. q. buroTul~apN: (M, K:) this latter word correctly signifies a miZal~ap for the summer: (TA in art. brTl:) and a thing by which one is protected from the cold and the heat: (M:) anything that protects and shades one, as a building or a mountain or a cloud: (Mgh:) the first portion that shades (AZ, S, K) of a cloud (AZ, S) or of clouds; (K;) accord. to Er-Rághib, mostly said of that which is deemed unwholesome, and which is disliked; whence the use of the word in the Kur vii. 170: (TA:) and what shades one, of trees: (K:) or anything that forms a covering over one, (T, TA,) or shades one: (T:) and [particularly] a thing like the Suf~ap [q. v.], (S, M, O, K,) by which one protects himself from the heat and the cold: (K:) or, accord. to the lawyers, Zul~apu Ald~aAri means the sud~ap [or projecting roof] over the door of the house: or that of which the beams have one end upon the house and the other end upon the wall of the opposite neighbour: (Mgh:) pl. ZulalN (S, M, O, K) and ZilaAlN. (M, K.) [See also ZalaAlN.] One says also, daAmato Zul~apu AlZ~il~i and AlZ~il~i ↓ ZilaAlapu, meaning That whereby one shades himself, (K, TA,) of trees, or of stones, or of other things, (TA,) [continued.] Ea*aAbu yawomi AlZ~ul~api, in the Kur. [xxvi. 189], is said to mean [The punishment of the day of] clouds beneath which was a hot wind (samuwm): (S, O, K:) or an overshadowing cloud, beneath which they collected themselves together, seeking protection thereby from the heat that came upon them, whereupon it covered them, (T, * K, TA,) and they perished beneath it: (T, TA:) or, accord. to some, i. q. Ea*aAbu yawomi AlS~uf~api. (T: see art. Sf.) And lahumo mino fawoqihimo ZulalN mina A@ln~aAri wamino taHotihimo ZulalN, in the Kur [xxxix. 18], means To them shall be above them coverings of fire, and beneath them coverings to those below them; Hell consisting of stages, one beneath another. (T, TA.) Seditions, or conflicts and factions, are mentioned in a trad. as being like Zulal, by which are meant Mountains, and clouds: and El-Kumeyt likens waves of the sea to Zulal. (TA.) And [the pl.] ZulalN is used as meaning The chambers of a prison. (M, TA.) -A2- See also Zal~apN.

Zil~apN *
i. q. ZilaAlN; (T, K, TA;) app. a pl. of ZaliylN, like as Til~apN is of TaliylN. (TA.)

ZalalN *
Water that is beneath a tree, (O,) or beneath trees, (K,) upon which the sun does not come. (O, K.) [See also DalalN.]

ZalaAlN * , like saHaAbN, [so accord. to the K, but in my copies of the S, ↓ ZilaAl,] A thing that shades one, (IAar, S, O, K, TA,) such as a cloud, (IAar, S, TA,) and the like. (IAar, TA.) [See also Zul~apN.]
