ZilaAlN * pl. of Zil~N: (S, M, O, K:) ― -b2- and of Zul~apN. (M, K.) ― -b3- [Also, app., pl. of ZaliylN: see Zil~apN. ― -b4- Freytag has app. understood it to be expl. in the K as syn. with maZal~apN; though it certainly is not.] ― -b5- See also ZalaAlN.

makaAnN ZaliylN *
A place having shade: (M, K:) or having constant shade. (T, S, M, O, K.) And hence Zil~N ZaliylN (M, K) Constant shade: (S:) or extensive shade: (O:) or in this case the latter word denotes intensiveness [meaning dense]; (M, K, TA;) being like $aAEirN in the phrase $iEorN $aAEirN. (TA.) Zil~FA ZaliylFA in the Kur iv. 60 is said by Er-Rághib to be an allusion to ease and pleasantness of life. (TA.) One says also A^ayokapN ZaliylapN A collection of trees tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense. (TA.) In the saying of Uheyhah Ibn-El-Juláh, describing palm-trees,
hiYa AlZ~il~u fiY AlHar~i Haq~a AlZ~ali??
??li waAlmanoZaru AlA^aHosanu AlA^ajomalu
[ISd says] in my opinion, he means Al$~aYo'u AlZ~aliylu Haq~a AlZ~aliyli; [so that the verse should be rendered They are the shade in the heat, the shady thing, the extremely shady, and the most goodly, the most beautiful, thing at which one looks; (see the phrase h`*aA AlEaAlimu Haq~a AlEaAlimi, voce Haq~N;)] the inf. n. being put in the place of the subst. (M.) laA ZaliylK in the Kur [lxxvii. 31] means Not profitable as the shade in protecting from the heat. (TA.)

ZalaAlapN * , (M, TA,) with fet-h, (TA,) the subst. from the verb in the phrase Zal~alonaA Ealayohimu AlgamaAma [expl. above, see 2; as such app. meaning either The making to give shade, like the inf. n. taZoliylN, or a thing that gives shade, like ZilaAlapN]. (M, TA.) ― -b2- And i. q. $axoSN [expl. above, see Zil~N, last quarter]: (O, K:) and so TalaAlapN, with T. (O.)

ZilaAlapN * : see Zul~apN. ― -b2- Also A cloud that one sees by itself, and of which one sees the shadow upon the earth. (K.) ― -b3- And one says, raA^ayotu ZilaAlapF mina AlT~ayori i. e. gayaAbapF [app. meaning I saw a covert, or place of concealment, of birds]. (TA.)

ZaliylapN *
A place in which a little water collects and stagnates in a water-course and the like: (Lth, T:) or a place in which water collects and stagnates in the lower part of the torrent of a valley: (M, K:) or the like of an excavated hollow in the interior of a water-course, such that the water stops, and remains therein: (AA, O:) pl. ZalaAy^ilu. (Lth, AA, T, O.) And A meadow (rawoDap) abounding with collections of trees, or of dense and tangled trees: (AA, T, O, K:) pl. as above. (K.)

Zul~ayolapN *
A thing which a man makes for himself,
of trees, or of a garment, or piece of cloth, by which to protect himself from the heat of the sun: a vulgar word. (TA.)

ZuloZulN *
i. q. suEonN, i. e. A ↓ miZal~ap [q. v.; or as expl. in the L, in art. sEn, a Zul~ap (q. v.), or a thing like the Zul~ap, which is made upon the flat house-tops, for the purpose of guarding against the dew that comes from the direction of the sea in the time of the greatest heat]; on the authority of IAar. (T. [Accord. to the O and K, i. q. sufunN, which is evidently a mistranscription.])

A^aZal~u * [More, and most, dense in shade]. The Arabs say, layosa $aYo'N A^aZal~a mino HajarK [There is not anything more dense in shade than a stone]. (TA.) ― -b2- And A^aZal~, [as a subst., i. e. A^aZal~N accord. to a general rule, or, if regarded as originally an epithet, it may be A^aZal~u,] by poetic license A^aZolal, (S, M, O, K,) signifies The under part, (S, O,) or the concealed part, (M, AHei, K,) of the manosim, (S, M, O, K,) or of the xuf~, (AHei, TA,) [the former app. here used, as it is said be in other cases, in the same sense as the latter, meaning the foot,] of the camel; (S, M, O, AHei, K;) so called because of its being concealed: (AHei, TA:) and, (M, K,) in a human being, (M,) AlA^aZal~u signifies baTonu AlA_iSobaEi; (M, K;) and [ISd says] this is in my opinion the right explanation; but it is said that A^aZal~u AlA_inosaAni signifies buTuwnu A^aSaAbiEihi, which means the portion, of what is next to the fore part [of the bottom] of the foot, from the root of the great toe to the root of the little toe, of the human being: (M:) the pl. is Zul~N, which is anomalous, (M, K,) or formed after the manner of the pl. of an epithet: (M:) or AlZ~ul~u fiY AlA_inosaAni means the roots, or bases, (A^uSuwl) of what are termed buTuwnu AlA^aSaAbiEi, next to the fore part [of the bottom] of the foot. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.) Hence the prov., A_ino yadoma A^aZal~uka faqado naqiba xuf~iY [If the fore part of the sole of thy foot be bleeding, the sole of my foot has become worn through, in holes: see naqiba]: said to the complainer to him who is in a worse condition than he. (AHei, TA.)

mZl~ * [app. maZil~N, being from Zal~a of which the aor. is yaZil~u; A place of shade, or of continual shade]. One says, h`*aA munaAxiY wamaHal~iY wabayotiY wamZl~iY [This is my nightly resting-place for the camels, and my place of abode, and my tent, and my place of shade, or of continual shade]. (TA.)
muZil~N * A thing having shade; by means of which one shades himself; as also ↓ muZal~ilN. (Msb.) And [A cloudy day;] a day having clouds: or having continual shade. (TA.)

miZal~apN * (T, S, M, Msb, K) and maZal~apN, (T, M, Msb, K,) the former with kesr to the m as an instrumental noun, (Msb,) [and the latter with fet-h as a noun of place,] A large tent of [goats'] hair; (S, O, Msb;) more ample than the xibaA='; so says El-Fárábee: (Msb:) one of the kinds of tents of the Arabs of the desert, the largest of the tents of [goats'] hair; next after which is the wasuwT; and then, the xibaA=', which is the smallest of the tents of [goats'] hair; so says AZ: but Aboo-Málik says that the mZl~p and the xbA=' are small and large: IAar says that the xayomap is of poles roofed with [the panic grass called] vamaAm, and is not of cloths; but the mZl~p is of cloths: (T:) or it is of the tents called A^axobiyap; (M;) such as is large, of the A^axobiyap; (K;) and it is said to be only of cloths; and it is large, having a riwaAq [q. v.]; but sometimes it is of one oblong piece of cloth ($uq~ap), and of two such pieces, and of three; and sometimes it has a kifaA=', which is its hinder part: or, accord. to Th, it is peculiarly of [goats'] hair: (M:) see also Zul~apN, and ZuloZulN: the pl. is maZaAl~u; (M, Msb;) and maZaAli or maZaAliY occurs at the end of a verse of Umeiyeh Ibn-Abee-'Áïdh El-Hudhalee, for maZaAl~i; the [latter] l being either elided, or changed into Y. (M.) Eil~apN maA Eil~apu A^awotaAdK waA^axil~apK waEamadi AlmiZal~api AuboruzuwA liSihorikumo ↓ Zul~apN [A pretext: what is the pretext of tentpegs, and of pins for fastening together the edges of the pieces of the tent-cloth, and of the poles of the large tent? go ye forth: he who has married among you has a tent for shade from the sun:] is a prov., and was said by a girl who had been married to a man, and whose family delayed to conduct her to her husband, urging in excuse that they had not the apparatus of the tent: she said this to urge them, and to put a stop to their excuse: (Meyd, TA: *) and the prov. is applied in attributing untruth to pretexts. (Meyd.) ― -b2- Hence, as being likened thereto, (assumed tropical:) A booth, or shed, made of palm-sticks, and covered with [the panic grass called] vumaAm. (Msb.) ― -b3- And The thing [i. e. umbrella] by means of which kings are shaded on the occasion of their riding; called in Pers. Jator. (TA.)
Earo$N muZal~alN * [A booth, or shed, shaded over] is from AlZ~il~u. (S.)
muZal~ilN * : see muZil~N.

musotaZil~N * Blood that is in the jawof [or belly, or interior of the belly, or the chest]. (T, O.) ― -b2- And [Az says,] I heard a man of the tribe of Teiyi apply the term AlmusotaZil~aAtu [so accord. to a copy of the T, but in the TA AlmusotaZil~u,] to Certain thin flesh, adhering to the interior of the two fetlock-joints of the camel, than which there is in the flesh of the camel none thinner, nor any softer, but there is in it no grease. (T.)

1 ZalaEa * , aor.
ZalaEa , inf. n. ZaloEN, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) said of a camel, (S, O, Msb, K,) and of a man also, (Msb, TA,) and, by Aboo-Dhu-eyb, of a horse, (S, TA,) [and likewise said of a dog, (see ZaAliEN,)] He limped, or halted, syn. gamaza fiY ma$oyihi, (S, O, Msb, K, TA,) and Earija; (TA;) or was slightly lame: (Mgh:) what it signifies resembles EarajN [or natural lameness], and therefore it is said to be a slight Earaj. (Msb.) One says, Airoqa EalaY ZaloEika, (S, O, L, K,) a prov., (O, L,) meaning Ascend thou the mountain with knowledge [or because] of thy limping, or slight lameness, not jading thyself: (L:) or deal gently with thyself, and burden not thyself with more than thou art able to do: (S:) or impose upon thyself, of what is difficult, [only] what thou art able to do; for he who ascends a ladder or stair, or a mountain, when he is one who limps, or has a slight lameness, deals gently with himself; i. e. exceed not thy proper limit in thy threatening, but see thy deficiency, and thine impotence to execute it: (O, K: *) and some say AiroqaA^o, with, meaning rectify thine affair first; (O, K;) or as meaning abstain, and restrain thyself; (O;) or, accord. to AZ, abstain thou, for I know thy vices, or faults: (TA:) or the meaning of both is, be silent, because, or in consideration, of the fault that is in thee. (Ks, O, K. *) One says also, Airoqi EalaY ZaloEika, with kesr to the q, [meaning Charm thou thy slight lameness, to cure it,] from Alr~uqoyapu: and it is said in another prov.,
Airoqi EalaY ZaloEika A^ano yuhaADaA
[app. meaning Charm thou thy slight lameness, that it may become mitigated: see art. hyD: the final A in yhADA being what is termed A^alifu AlA_iTolaAqi, not a radical]. (O, K.) And qi EalaY ZaloEika [Be cautious, because, or in consideration, of thy limping]: said when there is a vice, or fault, in a man, and you chide him in order that it may not be called to mind: (O, K: [for ya*okura in the CK, I read yu*okara, as in other copies of the K and in the O:]) and to this he replies, or may reply, waqayotu. (TA. [See also art. wqY.]) And AirobaEo EalaY ZaloEika [Act gently, or with deliberation, or restrain thyself, because of thy limping]; meaning thou art weak; therefore refrain from that which thou art not able to do. (O, K. [See also art. rbE.]) And laA yarobaEu EalaY ZaloEika mano layosa yaHozunuhu A^amoruka, meaning He will not mind thine affair (Hr, O, K) whom thy condition does not grieve: (Hr, O:) or, originally, he will not pause because of thy limping, when thou laggest behind thy companions on account of thy weakness, who does not care for thy case. (Hr, O, K. * [See, again, art. rbE.]) ― -b2- Also, said of a man, (tropical:) He stopped short, and lagged behind. (TA.) ― -b3- ZalaEati AlA^aroDu biA^aholihaA (tropical:) The land became straitened with its inhabitants, by reason of their multitude; (A 'Obeyd, S, O, K;) it would not bear them, by reason of their multitude, like the beast that limps with its load because of its heaviness. (Z, TA.)
― -b4- ZalaEat said of a bitch, (tropical:) She desired copulation. (As, O, K, TA.) And ZalaEa said of a dog, (assumed tropical:) He desired to copulate. (TA.) -A2- ZalaEato EayonahaA She (a woman) contracted and inclined her eye. (TA.)

4 AZlE *
He made his camel, or beast, that he rode, to limp, or become lame. (A, TA.)

5 taZal~aEa In the following saying of a poet,
wamaA *aAka mino juromK A^atayotuhumu bihi
walaA HasadK min~iY lahumo yataZal~aEu
ISd thinks the meaning to be, [And that was not a crime, or an offence, that I committed against them, nor envy on my part] arising in their minds, and occurring hastily to their understandings. (TA.)
ZalaEN * , thus with fet-h to the l, A declining from the truth, or from that which is right; and a sin, crime, fault, or misdeed. (TA.)

ZulaAEN *
A disease in the legs of a beast, not from journeying nor from fatigue, (Lth, K, TA, [in the O inadvertently written DulaAE,]) in consequence of which it limps. (Lth, TA.)

ZaAliEN *
Limping, or halting; [or slightly lame;] applied to a camel, and a horse, [&c.,] (S,) [i. e.,] to a beast, (TA,) to the male and the female alike, (Lth, O, K, TA,) to the former as a part. n., and to the latter as a possessive noun, (TA,) like gaAmizN; (Lth, O, TA;) or the fem. of ZaAliEN is ZaAliEapN, (S, O, K, TA,) but one does not say gaAmizapN: (O, TA:) [pl. Zul~aEN.] One says, laA A^anaAmu Hat~aY yanaAma ZaAliEu AlkilaAbi [I will not sleep until the limping dog sleeps]; (O, K;) a prov., (O,) meaning, until the dogs become still; (O, K;) because the ZAlE, of dogs, waits until there remains none other, and then copulates, and sleeps: (As, O, K:) ― -b2- or the ZAlE is the dog that is lusting for the female; for such does not sleep; and the saying is applied to him who is mindful of his affair, who does not neglect it: ― -b3- or the bitch that is lusting for the male; because the dogs follow her, and will not let her sleep. (O, K.) ― -b4- Also Inclining, or declining: (O, K:) like DaAliEN. (TA.) ― -b5- And [Declining from the truth, or from that which is right; (see ZalaEN;)] committing a sin, crime, fault, or misdeed. (TA.) ― -b6- And Suspected. (S, O, K.) -A2- In the saying of Ru-beh,
faA_ino tuxaAlijona AlEuyuwna AlZ~ul~aEaA
[And if ye women vie with the contracted and inclined eyes], he means AlmaZoluwEapa, [see 1, last sentence,] using the word in the manner of a possessive noun. (TA.)
muZoliEN * , applied to a load, i. q. muDoliEN [i. e. Heavily burdening, or overburdening, &c.; or causing to limp]. (TA.)
miZolaAEN * an epithet applied to a horse [and the like, as meaning That limps, or halts, much]. (TA.)

1 Zalafa AlS~ayoda * , (S, M, O,) or Al$~aApa, (K,) aor.
Zalifa , inf. n. ZalofN, (M,) He hit in his Zilof [or cloven hoof] (S, M, O, K) the animal of the chase (S, M, O) at which he had shot or cast, (S, O,) or the $Ap [a term including the antelope and the like]. (K.) -A2- Zalafa A^avarahu, (S, M, O, K,) aor.
Zalifa and
Zalufa , (M, K,) inf. n. ZalofN, (M, TA,) He made his foot-marks to be unapparent, in order that he might not be tracked: (K:) or he went, or walked, upon hard and rugged ground, in order that his foot-marks might not be visible (S, M, O, K) upon it; (S, O;) as also ↓ AZlfhu; (S, M, L, TA;) in the K, erroneously ↓ ZAlfh. (TA.) ― -b2- And Zulifa It (a herd of camels driven together) was taken along ground such as is termed Zalaf, (which means rugged ground, such as does not show foot-marks, M,) in order that the foot-marks thereof might not be followed. (S, O.) ― -b3- And Zalafahumo, (M, K,) aor.
Zalufa , (M,) or
Zalifa , (TA,) inf. n. ZalofN, (M, TA,) He followed their foot-marks. (M, K.) -A3- Zalafa nafosahu Eanohu, (T, S, M, O, K,) aor.
Zalifa , (S, O, K,) inf. n. ZalofN, (S, O,) He withheld himself from doing it, or coming to it; (S, O, K;) namely, a thing: (S, O:) or he restrained himself from it; (T, K;) namely, a thing that would disgrace him: (T:) or he withheld himself from the love, or blamable love, of it; namely, a thing. (M.) And Zalafahu Eanohu, (T, M,) aor.
Zalifa , inf. n. ZalofN, He withheld him from it; namely, an affair: (M:) or he made him to be, or become, far, or aloof, from it; or to avoid it; namely, a thing; as also ↓ AZlfhu. (T, TA.) And Zalafahu [alone] He withheld him from that in which was no good. (M.) -A4- Zalifati AlA^aroDu, (M, K,) [aor.
Zalafa ,] inf. n. ZalafN, (S, * M, TA,) The ground was rugged, not showing a foot-mark. (S, * M, K.) And Zalifato maEiy$atuhu, inf. n. ZalafN, His means of subsistence became hard, strait, or difficult. (TK.) -A5- Zalifato nafosiY Eano ka*aA, aor.
Zalafa , inf. n. ZalafN, My mind, or soul, abstained, or refrained, from such a thing. (S.) -A6- [And accord. to the KL, ZalafN as an inf. n. signifies The being ineffectual (i. e. unretaliated, or uncompensated by a mulct, as expl. below); said of blood; and so ZalofN (which is also expl. below): ― -b2- and the being concealed].

2 Zl~f Ealayohi * , (IAar, T, O, K,) inf. n. taZoliyfN, (O,) He exceeded it; (IAar, T, O, K;) i. e. [a certain number of years in age, as, for instance,] Als~itiyna [sixty], (T,) or Alxamosiyna [fifty]: (O:) and so Tal~afa and Tal~ava and *ar~afa &c. (T, TA.)
3 ZAlfhu * : see 1, former half: it is a mistake, in the K, for AZlfhu. (TA.)

4 AZlf * , said of a man, (IAar, T, O,) or of a company of men, (M,) He, or they, became, or came to be, (IAar, T, M, O, K,) in, or upon, a hard place, (IAar, T, O,) or in, or upon, what is termed A^uZoluwfap (M, K) and Zalaf. (M.) -A2- AZlfhu: see 1, in two places.

ZalofN * , of ground, or land, Such as is rugged, that will not show any foot-mark; (M;) as also ↓ ZalafN: (S, * M:) or so ↓ ZalifapN (S, K) and ↓ ZalufapN and ↓ ZalafapN: (K:) and ↓ ZalafN signifies ground such as horses like to run upon: (T:) or (i. e. the last) a place elevated above the water and the mud; and so ↓ ZalifN; (K;) this last thus expl. by Ibn-'Abbád: (O:) or this last and ↓ ZalifapN, accord. to ISh, (TA,) or ↓ ZalafN and ↓ ZalafapN, (so accord. to a copy of the T, in which the authority is not mentioned,) signify ground, or land, in which the foot-mark will not appear, and which is high and rugged: and accord. to Fr, ↓ ZalifN and ↓ ZalifapN signify ground, or land, that will not show a foot-mark; as though it were prevented from doing so: (T, TA:) and ↓ ZilofN, (so in a copy of the T,) or ↓ ZalifN, (so in the TA,) accord. to Fr, signifies such as is soft, of ground, or land: but accord. to IAar, such as is hard, and does not show a foot-mark; in which is no softness, so as to be difficult to him who walks upon it; nor sand, so that the camels would have their feet burnt upon it; nor stones, so that they would be chafed, or abraded, in the soles of their feet, upon it: and it is also expl. (by IAar, TA) as meaning such as is rugged and hard, of ground, or land: (T, TA:) and ↓ ZalifapN signifies high ground, or land, that will not show a foot-mark. (M.) [See also ZaliyfN.] ― -b2- [In the CK, AlZ~alofu is erroneously put for AlZ~alafu as relating to the means of subsistence.] -A2- ZalofN also signifies Ineffectual, null, or void: and allowable. (TK.) One says, *ahaba damuhu ZalofFA, (AA, S, M, O, K,) and ↓ TalafFA, (AA, T, S, M, O, K,) and ↓ ZaliyfFA, (M,) as also TalofFA and TalafFA (AA, O) [and TaliyfFA], His blood went for nothing; as a thing of no account; ineffectually; or in vain; unretaliated, or uncompensated by a mulct. (AA, T, S, M, O, K.)

[
AlZ~ulofu * in Har p. 312, there said to be used as meaning Continence, and disdain of base actions, is app. a mistake for AlZ~alofu, inf. n. of 1 in the phrase Zalafa nafosahu.]

ZilofN * The Zufor [meaning cloven hoof] of any ruminant (T, M) of the bovine kind and the like; (T;) [i. e.] it is an appertenance of the bovine kind and of the sheep and goat (S, O, Msb, K) and of the gazelle or antelope (S, O, K) and the like, (O, Msb, K,) which is to them like the Zufor to man, (Msb,) or like the qadam to us: (K:) one says the rijol and qadam of a man, and the HaAfir of a horse, and the xuf~ of a camel and of an ostrich, and the Zilof of a bovine animal and of a sheep or goat [and the like]: (ISk, T, TA:) pl. A^aZolaAfN (S, M, O, Msb, K) and ZuluwfN: (S, O, K:) and
A^aZolaAf is applied, by 'Amr Ibn-Maadee-kerib, to the hoofs of horses, (S, M, O,) as is said by Lth and Az and IF, by poetic license, (O,) metaphorically: (S, O:) and by El-Akhtal, metaphorically, to the feet of men. (M, IB, TA.) [Its dual is used in the K, in explanations of the words $aEirapN and A^a$oEaru, in the latter instance on the authority of Lh, as meaning The two halves of a cloven hoof.] And one says, maA ja$imotu A_ilayoka ZilofFA [app. meaning I have not had the trouble of bringing to thee so much as the hoof of a gazelle or the like]. (AZ, TA in art. j$m, q. v.) And huwa yaA^okuluhu biDirosK wayaTaw^uhu biZilofK [He eats it with a lateral tooth, and treads it with a cloven hoof; app. meaning, vehemently]. (TA.) ― -b2- It is sometimes used as meaning (tropical:) Cloven-hoofed animals. (TA.) One says, maA lahu xuf~N walaA HaAfirN walaA ZilofN (tropical:) [He possesses not camels, nor horses or asses or mules, nor sheep or goats or other cloven-hoofed beasts]. (TA in art. xf.) ― -b3- It also signifies [or implies] The making consecutive progressions in walking and in other actions, (T, K,) or, accord. to the L, in a thing. (TA.) One says, jaA='ati AlA_ibilu EalaY ZilofK waAHidK (T, A, O, TA) i. e. The camels came following one another. (A, TA. [See also a similar phrase voce xuf~N.]) And ganamu fulaAnK ZilofK waAHidK and waAHidK ↓ ZalafK The sheep, or goats, of such a one, have all of them brought forth [app. one after another]. (M.) ― -b4- Also A thing that is suitable to the requirements of a man, and of a beast: (M:) and an object of desire: (M, O, K:) and an object of want. (T, K.) One says, A^aSaAba fulaAnN Zilofahu Such a one attained what was suitable to his requirements, and what he desired: and sometimes one says the like of any beast that finds, or lights on, or meets with, that which he likes. (M.) wajadati Ald~aAb~apu ZilofahaA is a prov., (M, O,) applied to him who finds the means of attaining that which he seeks; (Meyd;) meaning [The beast found what was suitable to its requirements; or,] what withheld it [from other things] and prevented its desire [thereof]. (A, TA. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov., ii. 807.]) And one says, wajadati Al$~aApu ZilofahaA The sheep, or goat, found suitable pasturage, and therefore did not quit it: (K, TA:) a prov. mentioned by Fr; applied to him, of men and of beasts, that finds what is suitable to him. (TA.) And baladN mino Zilofi Alganami A country of such as are suitable to sheep or goats. (M.) And wajada Zilofahu He found what he loved, (O,) or what he desired, (K,) and what was suitable to him; (TA;) said of a man. (O.) And maA wajadotu Einodahu ZilofiY I did not find with him the object of my want. (TA.) -A2- See also ZalofN, near the middle of the paragraph. ― -b2- [In some copies of the K, AlZ~ilofu is erroneously put for AlZ~alafu as relating to the means of subsistence. And in the CK ZilofuhaA is erroneously put for ZalifuhaA as meaning Zalifu Aln~afosi.]

ZalafN * [as an inf. n.: see 1, last quarter. ― -b2- Also] Hardness, or difficulty, (S, O, K,) or coarseness, (M,) in the means of subsistence: (S, M, O, K:) thus the word is correctly written: not Zilof, as we find it written in [copies of] the K: [nor Zalof, as in the CK:] and Zalafu AlEayo$i occurs in a trad., (O, TA,) meaning straitness, and hardness or difficulty, and coarseness, of the means of subsistence. (TA.) -A2- See also ZalofN, in three places, near the beginning of the paragraph. -A3- And see the last sentence of that paragraph. ― -b2- Also Anything that is easy, or of light estimation, paltry, or despicable; [as also TalafN;] syn. kul~u hayonK, (M,) or kul~u hay~inK. (TA.) -A4- See also ZilofN, latter half. ― -b2- And see Zaliyfap.

ZalifN * : see ZalofN, former half, in three places. -A2- Zalifu Aln~afosi, [accord. to the CK Zalofu Aln~afosi, but this is a mistranscription,] and Aln~afosi ↓ Zaliyfu, (M, O, K,) A man who withholds himself from the love, or blamable love, of a thing: (M:) or one who abstains from that which is indecorous; syn. nazihu Aln~afosi. (O, K.) And AimoraA^apN Zalifapu Aln~afosi i. q. EaziyzapN Einoda nafosihaA [app. A woman strong to resist, in her own estimation; and therefore meaning one who abstains from that which is indecorous: Golius renders it mulier pudica, et de honore suo sollicita]. (S, TA.) -A3- See also ZalifapN.

[
AlZ~ulafu * in Har p. 623, there said to mean The restraining the soul from its desire, or blamable inclination, is app. a mistranscription for AlZ~alafu, inf. n. of Zalifati Aln~afosu.]
ZalofapN * : see ZalofN. -A2- Also A certain brand, or mark made with a hot iron, upon a camel; and so ↓ ZalifapN. (O, K.)

ZalafapN * : see ZalofN, in two places, near the beginning. ― -b2- [Hence, perhaps,] one says, A^aqaAmahu A@ll~`hu, EalaY AlZ~alafaAti, (TA, [there said to be muHar~akap,]) or AlZlifAt, (so in a copy of the T, [i. e. ↓ AlZ~alifaAti,]) meaning [God made him to keep to] a state of hardship and straitness. (T, TA.)

ZalifapN * : see ZalofN, in four places: ― -b2- and see ZalafapN: -A2- and ZalofapN. -A3- Also The [lower] end of the [curved piece of wood called the] Hinow [that lies against the side, at the fore part and at the hinder part,] of the [kind of saddle called] qatab, and of the [kind called] A_ikaAf, and the like; being in what is next to the ground, of the sides thereof: (Lth, T, TA:) or its pl., which is ZalifaAtN (S, M, O, K) and ↓ ZalifN, (O, K, [or rather the latter is a coll. gen. n.,]) signifies the four pieces of wood, (S, M, O, K,) of the [saddle called the] raHol and of the [saddle called the] qatab, (S, O,) that are upon the two sides of the camel, (S, M, O, K,) the lower ends of which touch the ground when they are put down upon it; in the waAsiT [or fore part of the saddle] are two (i. e. ZalifataAni), and so in the muw^ax~arap [or hinder part], and they are the lower portions of the HinowaAni; (S, O, K;) for the parts above them, next to the [pieces of wood called the] EaraAqiY, are [called] the EaDudaAni, and the elongated pieces of wood upon the sides of the camel are the A^aHonaA=' [pl. of HinowN]: (S, O:) AZ says that the upper portions of the ZalifataAni, [a mistake for the HinowaAni, as is shown by what follows,] next to the EaraAqiY, are [called] the EaDudaAni; below them being the ZalifataAni, which are the lower parts of the HinowaAni of the waAsiT and of the muw^ax~arap. (T, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence] one says, qaAmuwA EalaY ZalifaAtihimo, meaning EalaY A^aToraAfihimo (tropical:) [They stood upon their extremities, i. e. their feet]. (TA.) ― -b3- And naHonu EalaY ZalifaAti A^amorK (tropical:) We are on the verge of an affair, or event. (TA.) ― -b4- See also Zaliyfap.

ZalofaA='u *
A smooth stone or rock, or a hard, smooth, large stone, (SafaApN,) even with the ground, (T, O, K,) round (mdwrp), (so in a copy of the T, [i. e. mudaw~arap,]) or extended (mamoduwdap). (O, K.)

Zul~afN * [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned: accord. to general analogy, the sing. should be ZaAlifN]. ZuluwfN Zul~afN means Hard Zuluwf [or divided hoofs]: (S, O, K:) the latter word being a corroborative. (S, O.)

ZaliyfN * A rough, or rugged, place, (S, M, O, K, TA,) in which is much sand. (M, TA. [See also ZalofN.]) ― -b2- And A man (S, O) evil in condition (T, S, M, K) in respect of his means of subsistence: (T:) and low, abject, or abased, and weak. (M, O, K.) ― -b3- And An affair that is hard, or difficult: (K:) anything difficult to one to seek: (IDrd. M, O:) and evil hard to be borne, or severe. (S, O.) ― -b4- See also ZalifN. -A2- Also Hardship, or difficulty. (O, K.) -A3- *ahaba bihi ZaliyfFA He went away with it, or took it away, without compensation, or without price: (T, S, M, K:) and so TaliyfFA. (Yoo, TA in art. Tlf.) And *ahaba bigulaAmiY ZaliyfFA He went away with, or took away, my young man, or slave, without price. (AZ, S, O.) ― -b2- See also ZalofN, last sentence. -A4- A^axa*ahu biZaliyfi raqabatihi He took him by the base of his neck. (O, K, * TA.) ― -b2- See also what here follows.

A^axa*ahu biZaliyfatihi * , (S, M, O, L,) or ↓ biZaliyfihi, (K,) and ↓ biZalafihi, (S, O, K,) ↓ biZalifatihi, (T, M, L,) He took it altogether, or wholly, (T, * S, O, K,) or with its root, or base, and wholly, (M, L,) not leaving of it anything: (T, S, M, O, L, K:) so says AZ. (S.)

A^uZoluwfapN *
A piece of rugged, or rough, ground: (T:) or ground, (S, O, K,) or hard ground, (TA,) in which are sharp stones, as though its composition were that of a mountain: (S, O, K, TA:) pl. A^aZaAliyfu. (T, S, &c.)

maZoluwfN * An animal of the chase, at which one
has shot or cast, hit in his Zilof [or cloven hoof]. (Yaakoob, S.)

1 Zalama * , aor.
Zalima , has for its inf. n. ZalomN, (M, Msb, K, and so in some copies of the S,) or ↓ ZulomN, (so in other copies of the S,) or both, (T,) or the latter is a simple subst., (T, M, Msb, TA,) which is put in the place of the inf. n., (TA, [and the same is indicated in the T and K by the saying that the proper inf. n. is with fet-h,]) and ↓ maZolimapN, (S, TA,) or this is likewise a simple subst., (Msb,) and ↓ maZolamapN, [or this also is a simple subst.,] and ↓ ZilaAmN also is said to be an inf. n. like ZulomN, these two being like libaAsN and lubosN, [or it is a simple subst. like as ZulomN is said to be, or it is an inf. n. of 3, as such occurring in the middle of this paragraph,] or, accord. to Kr, it is pl. of ZulomN [like as rimaAHN is pl. of rumoHN]: (TA:) [Zalama when intrans. generally means He did wrong; or acted wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically: and when trans., he wronged; or treated, or used, wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically; or he misused:] accord. to most of the lexicologists, (Er-Rághib, TA,) primarily, (As, T, S, Msb,) ↓ AlZ~ulomu signifies the putting a thing in a place not its own; putting it in a wrong place; misplacing it: (As, T, S, M, Er-Rághib, Msb, K:) and it is by exceeding or by falling short, or by deviating from the proper time and place: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or the acting in whatsoever way one pleases in the disposal of the property of another: and the transgressing the proper limit: (El-Munáwee, TA:) [i. e.] the transgressing the proper limit much or little: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or, accord. to some, it primarily signifies Aln~aqoS [as meaning the making to suffer loss, or detriment]: (MF, TA:) and it is said to be of three kinds, between man and God, and between man and man, and between a man and himself; every one of which three is really liln~afosi [i. e. a wrongdoing to oneself]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) [when it is used as a simple subst.,] the pl. of ZulomN, accord. to Kr. is ZilaAmN, as mentioned above, and ↓ ZulaAmN, with damm, is said to be syn. with ZulomN, or a pl. thereof, [of an extr. form, commonly regarded as that of a quasi-pl. n.,] like ruxaAlN. (TA.) One says, mani A@sotaroEaY Al*~iy^oba faqado Zalama [He who asks, or desires, the wolf to keep guard surely does wrong, or puts a thing in a wrong place]: a prov. (S, Msb.) And mano A^a$obaha A^abaAhu famaA Zalama, (As, T, S,) a prov., meaning [Whoso resembles his father in a quality, or an attribute,] he has not put the likeness in a wrong place. (As, T. [See art. $bh.]) walamo taZolimo minohu $ayoy^FA, in the Kur [xviii. 31], means walamo tanoquSo [i. e. And made not aught thereof to suffer loss, or detriment]: (M, K:) and in like manner Fr explains the saying in the Kur [ii. 54 and vii. 160], wamaA ZalamuwnaA wal`kino kaAnuwA A^anofusahumo yaZolimuwna And they made not us to suffer loss, or detriment, by that which they did, but themselves they made to suffer loss, or detriment: (T, TA:) in which sense it seems to be indicated in the A that the verb is tropical. (TA.) ― -b2- It is also trans. by means of bi; as in the phrase in the Kur [vii. 101 and xvii. 61] faZalamuwA bihaA, because the meaning is kafaruwA [i. e. And they disbelieved in them], referring to the A=yaAt [or signs]; (M, TA; *) the verb having this meaning tropically or by implication; or being thus made trans. because implying the meaning of Alt~ako*iyb: or [the meaning is, and they wronged themselves, or the people, because of them; for], as some say, the b is causative, and the objective complement, i. e. A^anofusahumo, or Aln~aAsa, is suppressed. (TA.) ― -b3- And it is doubly trans. by itself: (TA:) one says, Zalamahu Haq~ahu [He made him to suffer loss, or detriment, of his right, or due; or defrauded, or despoiled, or deprived, him of it]; and Haq~ahu ↓ tZl~mhu: (M, K:) [and] you say, fulaAnN ↓ taZal~amaniY, [as well as tZl~mnY maAliY, occurring in a verse cited in the M,] meaning ZalamaniY maAliY [i. e. Such a one caused me to suffer loss, &c., of my property]. (S.) It is said in the Kur [iv. 44], A_in~a A@ll~`ha laA yaZolimu mivoqaAla *ar~apK, for laA yaZolimuhumo mivoqaAla *ar~api, and the verb is made doubly trans. because the meaning is laA yasolubuhumo [i. e. Verily God will not despoil them, or deprive them, of the weight of one of the smallest of ants, or a grub of an ant, &c.]: or mivoqaAla *ar~apK, may be put in the place of the inf. n., for ZalomFA HaqiyrFA kamivoqaAli *ar~apK [i. e. with a paltry spoliation or deprivation, such as the weight of one of the smallest of ants, &c.]. (M.) ― -b4- One says also, A^araAda ZilaAmahu and muZaAlamatahu, [these two nouns being inf. ns. of ↓ ZaAlamahu, or the former, as mentioned above, is, accord. to some, an inf. n. of Zalama,] meaning Zulomahu or Zalomahu [i. e. He desired the wronging, &c., of him]. (M, K.) ― -b5- Zalamahu, inf. n. ZulomN [or ZalomN?], also means He imposed upon him a thing that was above his power, or ability. (TA.) And yuZolamu He is asked for a thing that is above his power, or ability. (S.) ― -b6- And one says, Zalama AlbaEiyra (tropical:) He slaughtered the camel without disease. (S, K, TA.) And Zulimati Aln~aAqapu (assumed tropical:) The she-camel was slaughtered without disease: or was covered without her desiring the stallion. (M.) And Zalama AlHimaAru AlA^ataAna (tropical:) The he-ass leaped the she-ass (K, TA) before her time: (TA:) or when she was pregnant: (K, TA:) so in the A. (TA.) ― -b7- And Zalama AlwaToba, (S, K,) inf. n. ZulomN [or ZalomN?], (S,) (tropical:) He gave to drink of the milk of his skin before its becoming thick (S, K, TA) and its butter's coming forth. (TA. [And the like is said in the T and M.]) And Zalama Alqawoma (assumed tropical:) He gave to drink to the people, or party, (T, M, K,) milk before it had attained to maturity, (T, K,) as related on the authority of A 'Obeyd, (T,) or [milk such as is termed] Zaliymap: (M:) but this is a mistake: it is related on the authority of Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà [i. e. Th] and AHeyth that one says, Zalamotu Als~iqaA='a, and All~abana, meaning I drank, or gave to drink, what was in the skin, and the milk, before its attaining to maturity and the extracting of its butter: accord. to ISk, one says, Zalamotu waTobiYa Alqawoma, [but I think that it is correctly Zalamotu waTobiY liloqawmi, agreeably with a verse cited in the T and M,] meaning I gave to drink [to the people, or party,] the contents of my milk-skin before the thickening thereof. (T.) And Zalamotuhu is said of anything as meaning (assumed tropical:) I did it hastily, or hurriedly, before its proper time, or season. (M, TA.) ― -b8- Zalamotu AlHawoDa means (assumed tropical:) I made the watering-trough in a place in which watering-troughs should not be made. (ISk, T.) And Zalama AlA^aroDa means (tropical:) He dug the ground in what was not the place of digging: (M, K, TA:) or when it had not been dug before. (M.) And, said of a torrent, (assumed tropical:) It furrowed the earth in a place that was not furrowed. (T.) And Zalama AlbiTaAHa, said of a torrent, (tropical:) It reached the bTAH [or wide water-courses containing fine, or broken, pebbles, &c.], not having reached them before. (A, TA.) And Zalama AlwaAdiY (tropical:) The water of the valley reached a place that it had not reached before. (Fr, T, S, K, TA.) ― -b9- When men have added upon the grave other than its own earth, laA taZolimuwA (tropical:) [Transgress not ye the proper limit] is said to them. (TA.) ― -b10- And one says, laA taZolimo waDaHa AlT~ariyqi (assumed tropical:) Turn not thou from the main part, or the beaten track, of the road. (M.) And laA taZolimo Eanohu $ayoy^aA (assumed tropical:) Turn not thou from it at all. (T.) And lazima AlT~ariyqa falamo yaZolimohu (assumed tropical:) [He kept to the road, and] did not turn from it to the right and left. (TA.) ― -b11- And maA Zalamaka A^ano tafoEala (T, K, TA) (tropical:) What has prevented thy doing (K, TA) such a thing? (TA.) A man complained to Abu-l-Jarráh of his suffering indigestion from food that he had eaten, and he said to him, maA Zalamaka A^ano taqiYo'a (assumed tropical:) [What has prevented thy vomiting?]. (Fr, T.) And one says, maA Zalamaka Eano ka*aA (assumed tropical:) What has prevented thee from such a thing? (T.) Respecting the saying
qaAla balaY yaA maY~a waAlyawomu Zalamo
[addressed by a man to a woman who had invited him to visit her], Fr says, they say that the meaning is Haq~FA [Truly, or in truth; i. e. He said, Yes, O Meiya, truly, or in truth, I will visit thee]; and it is a prov.; (T;) or Alyawomu Zalama, or balaY waAlyawomu Zalama, is a prov.; (Meyd;) and thus it was expl. by IAar, as used in the manner of an oath: but Fr says, in my opinion the meaning is, and a day in which is a cause of prevention shall not prevent me: [so that the words of the hemistich above may be rendered, he said, Yes, O Meiya, though the day present an obstacle, for I will overcome every obstacle]: (T:)
accord. to Kr, qadima fulaAnN waAlyawomu Zalama means Such a one came truly, or in truth: [or it may be rendered such a one came though the day presented an obstacle:] but in the saying
A_in~a AlfiraAqa Alyawoma waAlyawomu Zalamo
the meaning is said by some to be waAlyawomu ZalamanaA [i. e. Verily separation is to-day, and the day has wronged (us)]: or, as some say, Zlm here means, has put the thing in a wrong place: (M:) accord. to ISk, the phrase waAlyawomu Zalam means [And, or but, or though,] the day has put the affair in a wrong place. (T.) [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 911.] -A2- Zalima, said of the night: see 4.

2 Zl~mhu * , inf. n. taZoliymN, (T, S, &c.,) He told him that he was ZaAlim [i. e. doing wrong or acting wrongfully &c., or a wrongdoer]: (T:) or he attributed, or imputed, to him Zulom [i. e. wrongdoing, &c.]. (S, M, Msb, K.) ― -b2- And He (a judge) exacted justice for him from his wronger, and aided him against him. (T.)
3 ZaAolama see 1, in the middle of the paragraph.

4 AZlm * , said of the night, (Fr, T, S, M, Msb, K,) and ↓ Zalima, (Fr, T, S, K,) the latter with kesr, (S,) like samiEa, (K,) [erroneously written in the TT as from the M Zalama,] It became dark; (S, K;) or it became black; (M;) or it came with its darkness. (Msb.) It is said in the Kur [ii. 19], waA_i*aA A^aZolama Ealayohimo qaAmuwA [And when it becomes dark to them they stand still]; the verb being intrans.: or, accord. to the Ksh, and Bd follows it, it may be trans. [so that the meaning is, and when He makes their place dark &c.]; as is shown by another reading, which is A^uZolimuwA: accord. to AHei, it is known by transmission as only intrans.; but Z makes it to be trans. by itself; Ibn-Es-Saláh affirms it to be trans. and intrans.: and Az [so in the TA, but correctly ISd, in the M,] mentions the saying, takal~ama faA^aZolama EalayonaA AlbayEta (assumed tropical:) [He spoke, and made dark to us the house, or chamber, or tent], meaning he made us to hear what we disliked, or hated, the verb being trans. (TA.) ― -b2- And A^aZolamuwA They entered upon the ZalaAm [or darkness, or beginning of night]: (S, M, Msb, K:) or, as in the Mufradát [of Er-Rághib], they became in darkness. (TA.) ― -b3- And they said, maA A^aZolamahu and mA A^aDowaA^ahu [How dark is it! and How light, or bright, is it!]; which is anomalous. (S, TA.) -A2- And AZlm Alv~agoru The front teeth glistened. (T, K.) Hence the saying [of a poet],
A_i*aA maA A@jotalaY Alr~aAy^iY A_ilayohaA biTarofihi
guruwba vanaAyaAhaA A^aDaA='a waA^aZolamaA
[as though meaning, When the beholder of her with his eye looks at the fineness, or sharpness, (but guruwb is variously explained,) of her central teeth, it shines brightly, and glistens: but Az plainly indicates another meaning; i. e., he sees (lit. lights on, or finds,) brightness and lustre; for he immediately adds, without the intervention of wa or A^awo, evidently in relation to this verse,] A^aDaA='a A^aYo A^aSaAba Dawo'FA waA^aZolama A^aSaAba ZalomFA: (T:) [and ISd cites the verse above with the substitution of biEaynihi for biTarofihi and of A^anaAra for A^aDaA='a immediately after saying that] A^aZolama signifies he looked at the teeth and saw lustre (AlZ~aloma). (M.) [In the K, next after the explanation of AZlm Alv~agoru given above, it is added that AZlm said of a man signifies A^aSaAba ZalomFA: thus, with fet-h, to the Z, accord. to the TA: in my MS. copy of the K and in the CK, ZulomFA, which is doubtless a mistranscription.]

5 taZal~ama
tZl~m minohu (T, S, M, K, [but in some copies of the S, mnh is omitted,]) He complained of his Zulom [or wrongdoing, &c.], (S, M, K,) A_ilaY AlHaAkimi [to the judge]: (T:) in some copies of the S, tuZul~ima. (TA.) ― -b2- And tZl~m signifies also He transferred the responsibility for the Zulom [or wrongdoing, &c.,] upon himself, (M, K,) accord. to IAar, who has cited as an ex.,
kaAnato A_i*aA gaDibato EalaY~a taZal~amato
[as though meaning She used, when she was angry with me, to transfer the responsibility for the wrongdoing upon herself; which may mean that she finally confessed the wrongdoing to be hers]; but [ISd says] I know not how that is: the taZal~um in this case is only the complaining of AlZ~ulom; for when she was angry with him, it was not allowable [to say] that she attributed the Zulom to herself. (M.) ― -b3- See also 1, former half, in two places.

6 tZAlm Alqawomu * (S, M, Msb) The people, or company of men, treated, or used, one another wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically (Zalama baEoDuhumo baEoDFA). (M, Msb.) ― -b2- And [hence] taZaAlamati AlmiEozaY (tropical:) The goats smote one another with their horns by reason of their being fat and having abundance of herbage. (IAar, M, TA.) One says, wajadonaA A^aroDFA taZaAlama miEozaAhaA (tropical:) We found a land whereof the goats smote one another with their horns by reason of satiety and liveliness. (T, TA.)
7 A_inoZalama see the next paragraph.

8 AiZ~alama * (T, S, M, K) and AiZoTalama and AiT~alama, (S, M,) which last is [said to be] the most usual, (S,) [but I have mostly found the first to be used,] of the measure AifotaEala, (S, M,) He took upon himself [the bearing of] Zulom [or wrong, &c.,] in spite of difficulty, trouble, or inconvenience: (S, TA:) or he bore AlZ~ulom [or wrong, &c.,] (T, M, K, TA,) willingly, being able to resist; (T, TA;) and ↓ AinoZalama signifies [thus likewise, or] he bore AlZ~ulom. (S, M, K.)

ZalomN * The lustre, and brightness, of gold. (Z, TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (Z, TA,) The lustre (lit. running water) upon the teeth; (Lth, T, Z, TA;) the lustre (maA=', S, M, K, and bariyq, S, K) of the teeth, (Lth, T, S, M, Z, K, TA,) from the clearness of the colour, not from the saliva, (Lth, * T, * M,) like blackness within the bone thereof, by reason of the intense whiteness, (S, K,) resembling the firinod [q. v.] of the sword, (S, K,) or appearing like the firinod [of the sword], so that one imagines that there is in it a blackness, by reason of the intense lustre and clearness: (M:) or, accord. to Sh, whiteness of the teeth, as though there were upon it [somewhat of] a blackness: or, as Abu-l-'Abbás ElAhwal says, in the Expos. of the “ Kaabeeyeh, ” lustre (lit. running water) of the teeth, such that one sees upon it, by reason of its intense clearness [app. meaning transparency], what resembles dustcolour and blackness: or, accord. to another explanation, fineness, or thinness, and intense whiteness, of the teeth: (TA:) pl. ZuluwmN. (S, M.) ― -b3- Also Snow: (M, K:) it is said to have this meaning: and the phrase mu$orabapi Alv~anaAyaA bimaA='i AlZ~alomi, used by a poet, may mean [Having the central teeth suffused with the lustre termed Zalom, as is indicated in the T and S, or] with the water of snow. (Lth, T.)

ZulomN * [as a simple subst. generally means Wrong, wrongdoing, injustice, injuriousness, or tyranny]: see 1, first sentence, in two places. ― -b2- [Zulomu AlArDi in the CK is a mistranscription for Zalama AlA^aroDa. ― -b3- And AlZulomu in one place in the CK, as syn. with AlZ~alomaA='u, is a mistake for AlZ~ulomapu.]

laqiytuhu A^adonaY ZalamK * , (S, M, K,) or A^adonaY *iY ZalamK, (K, TA, [in the CK Aaw~ala *iY ZalamK,]) means (tropical:) I met him the first of everything: (S, K, TA:) or the first thing: (M:) or when the darkness was becoming confused: (M, K:) or A^adonaY ZalamK means near; (El-Umawee, S, M, K;) or nearness: (M, K:) and one says, huwa minoka A^adonaY *iY ZalamK [app. He is near thee], and raA^ayotuhu A^adonaY *iY ZalamK [app. I saw him near]: (M:) and ZalamN is also syn. with $axoSN [as meaning an object seen from a distance, or a person]; (K;) or, as some say, it has this meaning in the phrase A^adonaY ZalamK [so that laqiytuhu A^adonaY ZalamK may mean I met him the nearest object seen from a distance, or the nearest person]: (M:) and accord. to Kh, one says, ↓ laqiytuhu A^adonaY ZulomapK, or A^aw~ala *iY ZulomapK, (as in different copies of the S,) meaning I met him the first thing that obstructed my sight. (S.) ― -b2- ZalamN signifies also A mountain: and the pl. is ZuluwmN. (M, K.)

ZulamN * an appellation of Three nights (T, S, K) of the lunar month (T, S) next after the three called duraEN; (T, S, * K; *) so says A'Obeyd: (T:) thus called because of their darkness: (S:) the sing. is ↓ ZalomaA='u; (T, S;) so that it is anomalous; for by rule it should be ZulomN; (S;) and the sing. of duraEN is daroEaA='u: so says A'Obeyd: but accord. to AHeyth and Mbr, the sings. are ↓ ZulomapN and
duroEapN, agreeably with rule; and this is the correct assertion. (T. [See more in art. drE, voce A^adoraEu.])
ZilamN * : see Zil~aAmN.

ZulomapN * (T, S, M, Msb, K) and ↓ ZulumapN (S, M, K) [accord. to the CK ZulomN and ZulumN, both of which are wrong,] and ↓ ZalomaA='u (S, M, Msb, K) Darkness; contr. of nuwrN: (S, Msb:) or nonexistence of nuwr [or light]: or an accidental state that precludes the coëxistence therewith of nuwr: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or the departure of light; as also ↓ ZalaAmN; (M, K;) which last has no pl.; (T, TA;) or this last signifies the beginning, or first part, of night, (S, M, Msb,) even though it be one in which the moon shines; and is said by Sb to be used only adverbially; one says, A^atayotuhu ZalaAmFA, meaning I came to him at night, and maEa AlZ~alaAmi i. e. at the time of the night: (M, TA:) the pl. of ZulomapN is ZulamN and ZulumaAtN and ZulamaAtN (T, S, Msb) and ZulomaAtN, (S, Msb,) or, accord. to IB, the first of these pls. is of ZulomapN and the second is of ZulumapN. (TA.) One says, ↓ huwa yaxobiTu AlZ~alaAma [or fiY AlZ~alaAmi, expl. in art. xbT], and AlZ~ulomapa [which means the same] and ↓ AlZ~alomaA='a [which is also expl. in art. xbT]. (TA.) ― -b2- ZulomapN is also [tropically] used as a term for (assumed tropical:) Ignorance: and (assumed tropical:) belief in a plurality of gods: and (assumed tropical:) transgression, or unrighteousness: like as nuwrN is used as a term for their contraries: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and it is said in the A that AlZ~ulomu is ZulomapN, like as AlEadolu is nuwrN. (TA.) ZulumaAtu AlbaHori means (assumed tropical:) The troubles, afflictions, calamities, or hardships, of the sea. (M.) -A2- And one says layolapN ZulomapN, [using the latter word as an epithet, (in the CK, erroneously, ZalimapN,)] and ↓ layolapN ZalomaA='u, both meaning A night intensely dark; (M, K;) or the latter means muZolimapN [i. e. dark, or black]: (S:) and ↓ layolN ZalomaA='u also, (M, K,) which is anomalous, (K,) mentioned by IAar, but [ISd says] this is strange, and in my opinion he has put layolN in the place of layolapN, as in his mentioning layolN qamoraA='u [q. v.]. (M.) ― -b2- See also ZulamN: ― -b3- and see the paragraph next preceding it.
ZilomapN * sing. of ZilamN: see Zil~aAmN.
ZulumapN * : see ZulomapN.
ZalomaA='u * : see ZulomapN, in four places: and see also ZulamN.
ZalaAmN * : see ZulomapN, in two places.
ZulaAmN * : see 1, in the first quarter of the paragraph.

ZilaAmN * : see 1, near the beginning: -A2- see also Zil~aAmN. -A3- It signifies also Little, or small, in quantity: or mean, contemptible, paltry, or of no weight or worth: ― -b2- whence the saying, naZara A_ilaY~a ZilaAmFA, meaning $azorFA [i. e. He looked at me from the outer angle of the eye, with anger, or aversion]. (K.)

ZaluwmN * : see Zal~aAmN. ― -b2- [Hence,] one says AimoraA^apN ZaluwmN lils~iqaA='i (assumed tropical:) [A woman wont to give to drink the milk of the skin before its attaining to maturity and the extracting of its butter: see Zalama AlwaToba, and what follows it, in the first paragraph]. (M.)

ZaliymN * [as syn. with maZoluwmN in the primary sense of the latter I have not found: but as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates it signifies] (tropical:) Milk that is drunk before its becoming thick and its butter's coming forth or being extracted; (S, * M;) as also ↓ ZaliymapN, (T, S, M,) and ↓ maZoluwmN. (T, S.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) A place that is ↓ maZoluwm [i. e. dug where it should not be dug]: (M, TA:) used in this sense by a poet describing a person slain in a desert, for whom a grave was dug in a place not proper for digging [it]. (M.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) The earth of land that is ↓ maZoluwmap (S, K, TA) i. e. dug, (TA,) or dug for the first time. (S.) And (assumed tropical:) The earth of the laHod [or lateral hollow] of a grave; which is put back, over it, after the burial of the dead therein. (T, TA.) -A2- Also The male ostrich: (T, S, M, K:) said (by IDrd, TA) to be so called because he makes a place for the laying and hatching of the eggs (yudaH~iY, inf. n. tadoHiyapN,) where the doing so is not proper: (M, TA:) or, accord. to Er-Rághib and others, because he is believed to be deaf: (TA:) pl. ZilomaAnN (T, M, K) and ZulomaAnN (M, K) and A^aZolimapN, (T, M,) which last is a pl. of pauc. (T.) ― -b2- And AlZ~aliymaAni is an appellation of Two stars; (M, K, * TA;) the two stars of Alqawos [or Sagittarius] that are on the northern curved end of the bow [i. e. λ and μ, above the nine stars called Aln~aEaAy^im, or “ the ostriches ”]. (Kzw in his descr. of Sagittarius.) And AlZ~aliymu is the name of The bright star [ α] at the end of Aln~ahor [i. e. Eridanus]: and A star upon the mouth of AlHuwt [i. e. Piscis Australis] (Kzw in his descr. of Eridanus.) [It seems to be implied in the K that AlZ~aliymu is the name of two stars; or it may be there meant that each of two stars is thus called. Freytag represents the sing. as “ a name of stars, ” and the dual also as “ a name of stars; ” referring, in relation to the former, to Ideler's “ Untersuch, ” pp. 201, 228, and 233; and in relation to the latter, to the same work, pp. 106 and 184.]
ZulaAmapN * : see maZolimapN.
ZaliymapN * : see maZolimapN: ― -b2- and see also ZaliymN.

Zal~aAmN * (TA) and ↓ Zil~iymN (S, TA) [and ↓ ZaluwmN, mentioned in the M and K with ZaAlimN, as though syn. therewith, but it is an intensive epithet,] One who acts wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically, much, or often; i. q. kaviyru AlZ~ulomi. (S, TA.) ― -b2- Zal~aAmuwna lilojuzuri occurs in a verse of Ibn-Mukbil [meaning (assumed tropical:) Men often slaughtering camels without disease]. (T, S.) -A2- See also what next follows.

Zil~aAmN * (AHn, T, M, K) and ↓ Zal~aAmN (T) and ↓ ZilaAmN (K) and ↓ ZaAlimN and ↓ ZilamN, (T, K,) the last mentioned by IAar, and its sing. is ↓ ZilomapN, (T,) accord. to AHn, A certain herb, (M, K, TA,) which is depastured; (M, TA;) accord. to IAar, a strange kind of tree; (T, TA;) accord. to As, a kind of tree (T, TA *) having long [shoots such as are termed] EasaAliyj [pl. of EusoluwjN q. v.], (T, K, TA,) which extend so that they exceed the limit of the A^aSol [i. e. either root or stem] thereof; for which reason the tree is called Zal~aAm. (T, TA.)
Zil~iymN * : see Zal~aAmN.

ZaAlimN * [Acting wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically: and wronging; or treating, or using, wrongfully, &c.:] part. n. of Zalama: (M, K:) and ↓ mutaZal~imN signifies the same; as well as complaining of his wrongdoer: (T:) [the pl. of the former is ZaAlimuwna and ZalamapN:] and ZalamapN signifies those who debar men from, or refuse to them, their rights, or dues. (IAar, T, TA.) -A2- See also Zil~aAmN.

A^aZolamu * [More, and most, wrongful, unjust, injurious, or tyrannical, in conduct]. El-Muärrij says, I heard an Arab of the desert say to his companion, A^aZolamiY waA^aZolamuka fafaEala A@ll~`hu bihi, meaning The more wrongful in conduct of me and of thee [may God do to him what He will do; i. e. may God punish him]. (T.) [And] one says, laEana A@ll~`hu A^aZolamiY waA^aZolamaka i. e. [May God curse] the more wrongful in conduct of us. (K. [But in the TA, a doubt is intimated as to the correctness of this latter saying.]) One says also, lahuwa A^aZolamu mino Hay~apK [i. e. Verily he is more wrongful in conduct than a serpent]: because it comes to a burrow which it has not excavated, and makes its abode in it: (Fr, T:) for it comes to the burrow of the [lizard called] Dab~, and eats its young one, and takes up its abode in its burrow. (TA voce Hay~apN.) ― -b2- And AlA^aZolamu is an appellation of The Dab~; because it eats its young ones. (TA.)

muZolimN * [Becoming dark, &c.: see its verb, 4]. ― -b2- [Hence,] $aEarN muZolimN (tropical:) Hair intensely black. (M, K, TA.) And nabotN muZolimN (tropical:) A plant intensely green, inclining to blackness by reason of its [deep] greenness. (M, K, TA.) And yawomN muZolimN (tropical:) A day of much evil: (K, TA:) or a very evil day: and a day in which one finds hardship, or difficulty. (M.) And A^amorN muZolimN (tropical:) An affair such that one knows not how to enter upon it; (AZ, M, K;) and so ↓ A^amorN miZolaAmN: (K:) [or,] accord. to Lh, one says ↓ yawomN miZolaAmN, meaning (assumed tropical:) a day such that one knows not how to enter upon it. (M.)

maZolimapN * and maZolamapN: see 1, near the beginning. ― -b2- Also the former, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) and the latter likewise, mentioned by Ibn-Málik and ISd and IKtt, and maZolumapN, which is disallowed
by several but mentioned on the authority of Fr, and all three are mentioned in the Towsheeh and in copies of the S, (MF, TA,) and ↓ ZulaAmapN, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) and ↓ ZaliymapN, (S, TA,) A thing of which one has been defrauded; (M, K; [in the CK, taZal~amahu is erroneously put for tuZul~imahu;]) a thing of which thou hast been defrauded, (Aal~atiY ZulimotahaA, T,) or a thing that thou demandest, (maA taTolubuhu, S, Msb,) in the possession of the wrongdoer; (T, S, Msb;) a term for a thing that has been taken from thee; (S; [thus, as is said in the M, the first is expl. by Sb;]) a right, or due, that has been taken from one wrongfully: (A, Mgh:) the pl. of mZlmp is maZaAlimu. (Mgh, TA.) In the phrase yawomu AlmaZaAlimi, [meaning The day of the demand of things wrongfully taken, and particularly applied to the great day of judgment,] the prefixed noun [i. e. Talabi] is suppressed. (Mgh.) [Respecting the office termed Aln~aZaru fiY AlmaZaAlimi The examination into wrongful exactions, see De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., see. ed., i. 132.]

muZal~amN * (assumed tropical:) A house, or chamber, decorated with pictures; (M, TA;) as though the pictures were put therein where they should not be: it is related in a trad. that the Prophet, having been invited to a repast, saw the house, or chamber, to be muZal~am, and turned away, not entering: (M:) or adorned with gilding and silvering; an explanation disapproved by Az, but pronounced by Z to be correct, from AlZ~alomu signifying “ the lustre, and brightness, of gold. ” (TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) Herbage spreading (munobav~N [in the CK munobat]) upon the ground, not rained upon. (K, TA.) ― -b3- Also, of birds, (assumed tropical:) The raxam [or vultur percnopterus], and crows, or ravens. (IAar, M, K. *)
miZolaAmN * : see muZolimN, in two places.

maZoluwmN * [Wronged; treated, or used, wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically: ― -b2- and hence used in other senses]: see ZaliymN, in three places. A^aroDN maZoluwmapN is also expl. as meaning (tropical:) Land that is dug in a place not proper for digging: (TA:) or land in which a watering-trough has been dug, not being a proper place for digging it: (ISk, M:) or land in which a well, or a wateringtrough, has been dug, when there had not been any digging therein: (A, TA:) or hard land, when it is dug. (Ham p. 56.) Also (assumed tropical:) Land upon which rain has not fallen. (T.) And baladN maZoluwmN (assumed tropical:) A country upon which rain has not fallen, and wherein is no pasturage for the camels upon which people journey. (T.)
mutaZal~imN * : see ZaAlimN.

div2.head: Quasi ZlY
div2.entryFree: 5 tZl~Y * : see 5 in art. Zl.

1 Zamiy^a * , (T, S, M, &c.,) aor.
ZamaAa , (Msb, K,) inf. n. ZamaA^N (T, S, M, Msb, K) and Zamo'N (TA) and ZamaA='N (T, M, K) and ZamaA='apN, (M, K, TA,) in one copy of the K ZamoA^ap, (TA,) He thirsted, or was thirsty: (S, M, Msb, K:) or as some say, he thirsted in the slightest degree. (M, TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (M,) Zamiy^a A_ilaY liqaAy^ihi (tropical:) He desired, or longed, [or, as we often say, thirsted,] to meet with him. (S, M, K, * TA.)
2 Zam~aAa see the next paragraph.

4 AZmA^hu * , (T, * S, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_iZomaA='N; (T;) and ↓ Zm~A^hu, (T, * Msb, K,) inf. n. taZomiy^apN; (T, S;) He made him to thirst: (S, Msb, K:) [or to thirst most vehemently: or to thirst in the slightest degree: see 1.] ― -b2- And (K) (tropical:) He made him lean, or lank, namely, a horse, (T, * K, TA,) by sweating him. (TA.) [See also 4 in art. ZmY.]

5 tZm~A^ *
He constrained himself to endure with patience a state of thirst. (A, TA.)

Zimo'N * a subst. from Zamiy^a (S, M, K) in both of its senses; (M, K;) [i. e.] it signifies Thirst: (MA:) [or most vehement thirst: or the slightest degree of thirst:] pl. A^aZomaA='N. (MA.) ― -b2- [And (tropical:) Desire, or a longing, (or, as we often say, a thirsting,) to meet with a person. See 1.] ― -b3- And (S, M, K) The time, or interval, or period, between two drinkings, or waterings, (T, S, M, K,) in the coming of camels to water: (T:) and the keeping of camels from the water [during that interval, i. e.] until the extreme limit of the coming thereto: (S:) pl. A^aZomaA='N. (T, S, M.) The shortest Zimo'N of camels is that termed gib~N, i. e., when they come to the water one day and return, and are in the place of pasture a day, and come to the water [again] on the third day; the interval between their two drinkings being termed a Zimo': this is during the greatest heat: but when Suheyl [i. e. Canopus] rises [aurorally, which it did in Central Arabia, about the commencement of the era of the Flight, on the 4th of August, O. S.], they increase the Zimo', so that the camels remain in the place of pasture two days, and come to the water on the fourth; and one says, waradato riboEFA: then follow the ximos and the sidos to the Ei$or: and the interval between their two drinkings is termed Zimo'N, whether long or short. (T.) One says, maA baqiYa mino Eumurihi A_il~aA Zimo'u AlHimaAri, (T, S, * K, * TA,) meaning There remained not of his life save a little; [lit., save the period between the two drinkings of the ass;] (S, K, * TA;) because there is no beast that bears thirst for a shorter time than the ass; (T, S, * K, * TA;) for he comes to the water in summer every day twice. (T, TA.) ― -b4- AlZ~imo'u also signifies (assumed tropical:) The period from birth to death; (K;) or so Zimo'u AlHayaApi. (S, M, TA.) ― -b5- ZimowN is a dial. var. of Zimo'N. (T and M in art. Zmw.)
Zamiy^N * : see the next paragraph.

ZamoA=nu * , (T, S, M, Msb, &c.,) fem. ZamoA^aY, (T, S, M, A, L, Msb,) both imperfectly decl.; (T;) or ZamoA=nN, fem. ZamoA=napN; (K; [but this requires consideration, for its correctness is extremely doubtful;]) and ↓ Zamiy^N, (so in the K accord. to the TA, and so in my MS. copy of the K,) like katifN, [agreeably with analogy as part. n. of Zamiy^a, and therefore probably correct,] (TA,) or ↓ ZamiYo'N, (so in a copy of the M and in the CK,) fem. [of the former] Zamiy^apN, like fariHapN, mentioned by Ibn-Málik, but generally held to be disused; (MF, TA;) and ZaAmK, like raAmK; (TA; [app. for ↓ ZaAmiy^N;]) Thirsty: (S, M, Msb, K:) or most vehemently thirsty: (T, M, K:) or thirsty in the slightest degree: (M, TA:) pl. (of the first, M, Msb, and of the second, M, or of all, mase. and fem., TA) ZimaA='N (T, S, M, Msb, K) and ZumaA='N, which is extr., (K, TA,) being of a form applying to only about ten words, (TA,) mentioned on the authority of Lh, (K, TA,) by ISd in the “ Mukhassas. ” (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, A^anaA ZamoA=nu A_ilaY liqaAy^ika (tropical:) I am desirous, or longing, [or, as we often say, thirsting,] to meet with thee. (A, TA.) ― -b3- And wajohN ZamoA=nu (tropical:) A face having little flesh, (T, TA,) the skin of which adheres to the bone, and the sap of which is little: (TA:) an expression of praise: contr. of wajohN ray~aAnu, which is [said to be] an expression of dispraise. (A, TA.) And farasN ZamoA=nu Al$~awaY (assumed tropical:) A horse having little flesh upon the legs: (T in art. rwY:) and so A^aZomaY Al$~awaY. (T in art. ZmY.) And saAqN ZamoA^aY (assumed tropical:) A lean shank: (T, TA:) and so sAq ZamoyaA='u. (S and M and K in art. ZmY.) And EayonN ZamoA^aY (assumed tropical:) An eye having a thin, or delicate, lid: (M, TA:) and so Eyn ZamoyaA='u. (S and M and K in art. ZmY.) And fuSuwSuhu ZimaA='N (said of a horse, T, S, TA) (tropical:) His joints are [firm,] not flabby, or lax, (T, S, K, TA,) nor fleshy; (S, K, TA;) and are well braced; an expression of commendation: (T:) and mafaASilu ZimaA='N (tropical:) Hard [or firm] joints, without flabbiness, or laxness: (A, TA:) accord, to IB, belonging to art. ZmY; but said in the T to be originally from ZmA^. (TA.) ― -b4- And riyHN ZamoA^aY (assumed tropical:) A wind that is hot, (As, T, K,) thirsty, not gentle, (K,) and without moisture. (As, T.)
ZamiYo'N * : see ZamoA=nu, first sentence.

ZamaA='apN * (assumed tropical:) Evilness of nature, of a man, and meanness of disposition, and deficiency of equity to associates: (En-Nadr, T, K:) originating from the fact that he who is given to drink, if of an evil nature, does not act equitably to his associates. (T.)
ZaAmiy^N * : see ZamoA=nu, first sentence.

maZomaA^N *
A thirsty place of the earth or ground. (M, K.)
miZomaA='N * A very thirsty man. (K.)

miZomay^iY~N *
Watered [only] by the rain: contr. of masoqawiY~N: (K:) and so maZomiY~N: applied to seedproduce. (S and K in art. ZmY.)

ZimaxN * , (K,) or ZimoxN, (AA, TA,) A tree having the form of the dulob [or plane-tree], (AA, T, K,) from which is cut the wood of the beaters and washers and whiteners of clothes, which is buried, [and is used for tanning,] and which is also called EironN, n. un. EironapN, and the spathe, or spadix, (TaloE,) whereof is called safoEN: (AA, T:) and in the dial. of Teiyi, the fig-tree; n. un. with p: or the sing. is ZimoxapN, and the pl. is ZimaxN, sometimes contracted into ZimoxN: (K:) and some say that it is the tree called sum~aAq: (TA, and so in one of my copies of the S, in which it is written Zimax:) it is also called Znx and zmx and Tmx. (TA.)
ZimowN * , relating to the A^aZomaA=' of camels, is a dial. var. of Zimo'N, (M,) signifying The interval between two drinkings in the coming of camels to water. (T.) [See art. ZmA^.]

1 ZamiYa * , [and Zamiyato, aor.
ZamaYa ,] inf. n. ZamFY, He, or it, [and she, or it,] had any of the qualities denoted by the epithet A^aZomaY [and its fem. ZamoyaA='u]. (M, TA. [See A^aZomaY, and see also ZamFY expl. below.])
2 Zam~aYa see the next paragraph.
4 A^uZomiYa * , inf. n. A_iZomaA='N, He (a horse) was made lean, or lank; as also ↓ Zum~iYa, inf. n. taZomiyapN. (T, TA. [See also 4 in art. ZmA^.])

ZamFY * is the inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]: and [it is said that it] signifies The withering, or drying up, of the lip, from thirst: (M:) so says Lth: but it signifies paucity of the flesh and blood of the lip; not the withering, or drying-up, in consequence of thirst: it is a quality that is commended: (T:) or a tawny, or brownish, or dusky, colour, and a withering, or drying-up, in the lip. (S.) ― -b2- And Paucity of the blood of the gum: (Lth, T:) or paucity of the blood and flesh of the gum. (M.) [In the T is added wyEtryh AlHusonu: and in the M, whw yEtrY AlHubosa, in which AlHubosa seems to be evidently a mistranscription for AlHubo$a: I therefore think it most probable that in the T, as well as in the M, the right reading is wahuwa yaEotariY AlHubo$a, meaning and it is incidental to the Abyssinians.] ― -b3- And Tawniness of a spearshaft. (T.)
ZamK * : see A^aZomaY.
ZimaA='N * : see ZamoA=nu, in art. ZmA^.
ZaAmK * : see ZamoA=nu, in art. ZmA^.

A^aZomaY * Anything withering, or withered; or becoming, or become, dried up; from heat; as also ↓ ZamK. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence,] $afapN ZamoyaA='u A lip that is not swollen, [not] having much blood; (T;) accord. to Lth, from thirst; but AZ says that it is not so: (TA: [see ZamFY:]) or a lip in which is a tawny, or brownish, or dusky, colour, and a withering, or lack of moisture: (S:) or a lip withering, or withered, or lacking moisture, inclining to a tawny, or brownish, or dusky, colour. (K.) ― -b3- And livapN ZamoyaA='u A gum having little blood: (S, K:) or, accord. to the M, having little blood and flesh. (TA.) ― -b4- And EayonN ZamoyaA='u An eye having a thin, or delicate, lid: (T, S, M, K:) and so Eyn ZamoA^aY. (M and TA in art. ZmA^.) ― -b5- And saAqN ZamoyaA='u A lean shank: (S, M, K:) and so sAq ZamoA^aY. (T and TA in art. ZmA^.) And A^aZomaY Al$~awaY means A horse having little flesh upon the legs: (TA:) and so ZamoA=nu Al$~awaY. (T in art. rwY.) ― -b6- A^aZomaY is also applied to a man, as signifying Black in the lip: (M:) and so ZamoyaA='u applied to a woman. (T, M.) ― -b7- And the former applied to a man, and the latter to a woman, Having the quality of the gum termed ZamFY expl. above. (M.) ― -b8- Both also, accord. to Lh, signify Tawny, brownish, or dusky; the former as applied to a man, and the latter to a woman: (M:) and thus the former applied to a spear, (As, T, S, M,) and the latter to a spearshaft (qanaAp). (TA.) ― -b9- And A^aZomaY signifies also Black: (T:) thus as applied to shade: (S:) and so the fem. applied to a she-camel: (K:) or the latter applied to a she-camel, and [the pl.] ZumoYN applied to camels, in the colour of which is a blackness. (T.) [See also A^aZomaA^u, in art. ZmA^.]

maZomiY~N * Land, (M,) or [rather] seed-produce (zaroE), (S, K,) watered only by the rain: (S, M, K:) and so maZomiy^iY~N: (K in art. ZmA^:) such as is irrigated by running water is termed masoqawiY~N. (S.)

1 Zan~a * , aor.
Zanu3a , inf. n. Zan~N, (Msb,) [He thought, opined, supposed, or conjectured: and he doubted: and he knew, but not by ocular perception: see Zan~N below:] you say, Zananotu Al$~aYo'a, aor. A^aZun~uhu, inf. n. Zan~N; and ↓ AiZ~ananotuhu and AiZoTananotuhu; and ↓ taZan~anotuhu and taZan~ayotuhu, this last formed by changing the last n into Y: [i. e. I thought the thing, &c:] and Lh mentions, as heard from the Benoo-Suleym, Zanotu *aAka i. e. Zananotu *Ak [I thought that, &c.] like Zalotu and other instances of the dial. of Suleym. (M.) [In the first of the senses expl. above, it governs two objective complements, which are originally an inchoative and an enunciative:] you say, Zananotuka zayodFA [I thought thee Zeyd, originally I thought thou wast Zeyd], and Zananotu zayodFA A_iy~aAka [I thought Zeyd thee, originally I thought Zeyd was thou], denoting by a pronoun what is originally an inchoative [in the former phrase] and what is originally an enunciative [in the latter phrase]. (S, TA.) It is also used [in this sense] in the same manner as a verb signifying an oath, the Arabs giving it the same kind of complement, saying, Zananotu laEabodu A@ll~`hi xayorN minoka [I thought surely 'Abd-Allah was better than thou]. (S in art. drd.) [Zan~a bihi ka*aA means I thought of him, or it, such a thing: and I thought such a thing to be in him, or it: and is used in relation to good and to evil.] It is said in the Kur [xxxiii. 10], wataTun~uwna biA@ll~`hi A@lZ~unuwnaA [And ye were thinking, of God, various thoughts]. (M.) Accord. to Sb, Zananotu bihi means I made him, or it, the place [i. e. object] of my Zan~ [or thought, &c.]. (M.) [In all these exs. the verb denotes a state of mind between doubt and certainty, but the latter is predominant: and hence Zan~a sometimes means He doubted: and sometimes, he knew, by considering with endeavour to understand, not by ocular perception; being more frequently used in this sense than as meaning “ he doubted, ” though not so frequently as it is in the sense of “ he thought, ” whence the meaning “ he knew ” is held by some to be tropical.] A_in~aY, Zananotu A^an~iY mulaAqK HisaAbiyaho, in the Kur [lxix. 20], means Verily I knew [that I should meet with my reckoning]. (T.) And A@l~a*iyna yaZun~uwna A^an~ahumo mulaAquw rab~ihimo, in the same [ii. 43], means Who know [that they shall meet their Lord, lit., be meeters of their Lord]. (Msb.) And Zananotu maA qaAla, occurring in a trad., means I knew [what he meant to say by his making a sign with his hand]. (TA.) ― -b2- Zananotuhu, (M, Mgh, Msb,) aor. as above, (Msb,) and so the inf. n., (M,) signifies also I suspected him; thought evil of him; (M, Mgh, Msb;) and (M) so ↓ AiZ~ananotuhu (S, M, Mgh, K) and AiZoTananotuhu (M, TA) and AiT~ananotuhu. (TA.) [Thus, too, ↓ A^aZonanotuhu accord. to several copies of the S and accord. to the CK; but this is app. a mistranscription.] In the saying of Ibn-Seereen, lamo fiY qatoli EuvomaAna ↓ yakuno EaliY~N yuZ~an~u, (T, S, K, but in the T maA kaAn,) meaning Alee was not suspected [in the case of the slaying of 'Othmán], (T,) yuZ~an~u is of the measure yufotaEalu, originally yuZotan~u: (T, S, K:) so says A'Obeyd: (T:) or, as some relate it, the word is yuT~an~u. (TA.) One says, bika*aA ↓ huwa yuZ~an~u and yuT~an~u, meaning He is suspected of such a thing. (TA in art. Tn.) And Tananotu bizayodK and Zananotu zayodFA I suspected Zeyd: in
this sense the verb has a single objective complement. (TA.)

4 A^aZonanotuhu Al$~aYo'a *
I made him to think the thing. (M, TA.) ― -b2- And A^aZonanotu bihi Aln~aAsa [I made the people to suspect him: or] I exposed him to suspicion; (M, Msb, TA;) [and] so A^aZnanotuhu [alone]. (K.) ― -b3- See also 1, last quarter.

5 Alt~aZan~iY * means The exercising, employing, or using, of AlZ~an~ [i. e. thought, &c.]; originally Alt~aZan~unu. (S, K.) A'Obeyd says, taZan~ayotu is from Zananotu, and is originally taZan~anotu; the n being many, one of them is changed into Y: it is like qaS~ayotu, which is originally qaS~aSotu. (T.) -A2- See also 1, first sentence.
8 A_iZotana3a see 1, first sentence: ― -b2- and again, in the last quarter, in three places.

Zan~N * is a simple subst. as well as an inf. n.; (TA;) and signifies Thought, opinion, supposition, or conjecture: (Er-Rághib, Mgh, TA:) or a preponderant belief, with the admission that the contrary may be the case: (KT, El-Munáwee, TA:) or a preponderating wavering between the two extremes in indecisive belief: (K:) or an inference from a sign, or mark, or token; when strong, leading to knowledge; and when weak, not exceeding the limit of wahom: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or doubt or uncertainty; (T, M;) or it has this meaning also; (Er-Rághib, TA;) contr. of yaqiynN: (Msb:) and sometimes it is put in the place, (S, K,) or used in the sense, (Mgh, Msb,) of EilomN, (S, Mgh, K,) or yaqiynN, (Msb,) [i. e. knowledge, or certainty,] in which sense it is [held by some to be] tropical; (Mgh;) or it signifies also knowledge, or certainty, (yaqiynN, T, M,) such as is obtained by considering with endeavour to understand, not by ocular perception, (M,) or not such as relates to an object of sense: (MF:) and it also means suspicion, or evil opinion: (Er-Rághib, TA: [but in this last sense, Zin~apN is more common:]) as a subst., (TA,) its pl. is ZunuwnN and A^aZaAniynu, (M, K, TA,) the latter anomalous, or (as ISd says, TA) it may be pl. of ↓ A^uZonuwnapN, but this I do not know. (M, TA.) One says, huwa say~iy^u AlZ~an~i bikul~i A^aHadK [He is evil in opinion of everyone]. (M.) [And saA='a Zan~uhu bifulaAnK His opinion of such a one was evil.] And Eilomuhu biAl$~aYo'i ZunuwnN [His knowledge is but opinions]; meaning that no confidence is to be placed in him. (TA.)

Zin~apN *
Suspicion, or evil opinion; (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also Tin~apN; the Z being changed into T, though there is no A_idogaAm in this case, because of their being accustomed to say AiT~an~a [for AiZ~an~a, which is for AiZoTan~a]; an instance like Ald~ikoru, which is made to accord with Aid~akara [for Ai*~akara, which is for Ai*odakara], as mentioned by Sb; (M;) and ↓ ZanaAnapN, (so accord. to a copy of the M,) or ↓ ZinaAnapN, like kitaAbapN, (TA,) signifies the same: (M, TA:) the pl. of Zin~apN is ZinanN. (S, K.) One says, Einodahu Zin~atiY and huwa Zin~atiY, meaning He is the place [i. e. object] of my suspicion. (TA.) ― -b2- And [hence] (assumed tropical:) A little [like the French “ soupçon ”] of a thing. (TA.)
ZunanN * : see Zan~aAnN.

ZanuwnN * A man who thinks evil (S, M) of everyone. (M.) ― -b2- A man possessing little good or goodness: or, as some say, of whom one asks [a thing] thinking that he will refuse, and who is as he was thought to be: (M:) [or] ↓ ZaniynN has this latter meaning. (TA.) ― -b3- A man in whose goodness no trust, or confidence, is to be placed. (M.) And Anything in which no trust, or confidence, is to be placed, (M, TA,) of water, and of other things; (TA;) as also ↓ ZaniynN. (M, TA.) A well (biy^orN) having little water, (S, M, K,) in the water of which no trust, or confidence, is to be placed: (M:) or a well, (S, K,) or a drinkingplace, (M,) of which one knows not whether there be in it water or not: (S, M, K:) or water which one imagines, or supposes, to exist, but of which one is not sure. (TA.) kul~u maniy~apK ZanuwnN A_il~aA Alqatola fiY sabiyli A@ll~`hi is a saying mentioned, but not expl., by IAar; [app. meaning Every death is doubtful as to its consequence except slaughter in the way, or cause, of God; but ISd says,] in my opinion the meaning is that it is of little good and profit. (M.) dayonN ZanuwnN means A debt of which one knows not whether he who owes it will pay it or not: (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, * K:) it is said in a trad. of 'Omar that there is no poorrate in the case of such a debt. (TA.) ― -b4- Also A man suspected in relation to his intellect, or intelligence. (Aboo-Tálib, TA.) And A woman suspected in relation to her grounds of pretension to respect, or honour, on account of lineage &c. (TA.) And A woman of noble rank or quality, who is taken in marriage, (M, K,) from a desire of obtaining off spring by her, when she is advanced in age. (M.) ― -b5- Also A weak man. (K. [See also ZanynN.]) ― -b6- And A man having little artifice, cunning, ingenuity, or skill. (K.)

ZaniynN *
Suspected; (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) applied to a man; (S, M;) i. q. ↓ maZonuwnN, (Mbr, Msb,) in this sense: (Msb:) pl. A^aZin~aA='u. (M, TA.) Thus in the saying in the Kur [lxxxi. 24], wamaA huwa EalaY A@logayobi biZaniynK, (T, M, Msb,) meaning And he is not suspected as to what he makes known from God, of the knowledge of that which is undiscoverable, as is related on the authority of 'Alee: or, accord. to Fr, it may mean weak; for ZaniynN may have this meaning like as ZanuwnN has: (T:) some read biDanynK. (TA in art. Dn, q. v.) $ahaAdapu ZaniynK, which is said in a trad. to be not allowable, is The testimony of one who is suspected as to his religion. (TA.) And nafosN ↓ Zan~aA='u means [A soul, or person,] suspected. (TA.) ― -b2- Also One who treats or regards another, or others, with enmity, or hostility; (T, M;) because of his evil opinion and the evil opinion of which he is an object. (M.) ― -b3- See also ZanuwnN, in two places.
ZanaAnapN * or ZinaAnapN: see Zin~apN.
Zan~aA='u * : see ZaniynN.
Zan~aAnN * One who opines, or conjectures, much [and] in an evil manner; as also ↓ ZunanN. (TA.)

A^aZan~u * [Such as is more, or most, fit that one should think of him to do a thing]. You say, naZarotu A_ilaY A^aZan~ihimo A^ano yafoEala *`lika I looked towards him who was the most fit of them that I should think of him to do that. (M, TA.)
A^uZonuwnapN * : see Zan~N, near the end.

maZin~apN * , (M, Mgh, Msb, TA,) of which maZan~apN, mentioned by Ibn-Málik and others, and miZan~apN, are dial. vars., (TA,) or [rather] maZin~apu $aYo'K, (IF, S, Msb, K, TA,) signifies The place, (IF, S, Msb, K, TA,) and the accustomed place, (IF, S, Msb, TA,) in which is thought to be the existence, (S, K, TA,) of a thing; (IF, S, Msb, K, TA;) [a place] where a thing is thought to be: (M:) or it signifies, (Mgh, Msb,) or signifies also, (S,) a place where a thing is known to be: (S, Mgh, Msb:) [a thing, and a person, in which, or in whom, a thing, or quality, is thought, supposed, presumed, suspected, inferred, known, or accustomed, to be, or exist:] accord. to IAth, by rule it should be maZan~apN: (TA:) [it may therefore be properly rendered a cause of thinking, &c., the existence of a thing; and maZin~apN lika*aA may be well expl. as meaning a thing, and a person, that occasions one's thinking, supposing, presuming suspecting, inferring, or knowing, the existence of such a thing or quality, in it, or in him: and hence, an indication, or evidence, or a symptom, diagnostic, characteristic, sign, mark, or token, of the existence of such a thing or quality:] the pl. is maZaAn~u. (M, Mgh, Msb, TA.) One says, mawoDiEu ka*aA maZin~apN mino fulaAnK i. e. Such a place is a place in which such a one is known [&c.] to be. (S, TA.) And fulaAnN maZin~apN mino ka*aA i. e. Such a one is one in whom such a thing, or quality, is known [&c.] to be. (Lh, T.) And fulaAnN maZin~apN liloxayori i. e. Such a one is one in whom good, or goodness, is thought [&c.] to be. (Ham p. 437.) And En-Nábighah says,
faA_ino yaku EaAmirN qado qaAla jaholFA
faA_in~a maZin~apa Aljaholi Al$~abaAbu
[And if 'Ámir has spoken ignorantly, verily youthfulness is a state in which ignorance is usually found to exist]: (S, Msb: *) or, as some relate the verse, Als~ibaAbu [so that the meaning is, mutual reviling is an act in which &c.]: (S:) or, accord. to another relation, the latter hemistich is
faA_in~a maTiy~apa Aljaholi Al$~abaAbu
(S, * TA;) because one finds it [i. e. youthfulness] to be easy like as he does the beast on which one rides. (TA.) And one says also, Talabahu maZaAn~ahu [He sought him, or it, in the places where he, or it, was thought to be;] meaning, by night and by day. (TA.) And A_in~ahu lamaZin~apN A^ano yafoEala *`lika i. e. Verily he is apt, meet, fitted, or suited, for one to think of his doing that: and in like manner one says of two, and of a pl. number, and of a female. (Lh, M.)

maZonuwnN * [Thought, opined, &c.: see its verb: and] see ZaniynN. Applied to a narrative, or story, it means [Doubted; or] of which one is not to be made to know the real state. (TA in art. rjm.) In lexicology, A word of the class termed A=HaAdN [q. v.]. (Mz 3rd nwE.)
ZinobN * The root, or lower part, or stem, (A^aSol,) of a tree. (IAar, T, K.)

ZunobapN *
A sinew (Eaqabap) that is wound over the extremities of the feathers of an arrow, next the notch. (AHn, M, K.)

ZunobuwbN * The edge of the shin: (K:) or the tough edge of the shin: or the external part of the shank: (M, TA:) or the shin-bone: or the edge of the shin-bone: (M, K:) or the tough bone in the fore part of the shank: (S:) but accord. to AZ, this term is not used in relation to animals that have A^awoZifap: [see waZiyfN:] (T, TA:) pl. ZanaAbiybu. (S, M, K.) EaAriY AlZ~anaAbiybi Without flesh upon the shins (TA) is an epithet applied to a male ostrich.
