(S, TA.) qaraEa Zunobuwba AlbaEiyri means He knocked, or struck, the shin of the camel, that he might lie down, and he might mount him: or qaroEu AlZ~unobuwbi signifies a man's knocking, or striking, the shin of his camel with his stick when he makes him lie down that he may mount him, as one in haste to betake himself to a thing: or striking the shin of his beast with his whip, [in the TA is here added lytrqh, which I can only suppose to be put for liyuborikahu, to make him lie down,] when he desires to mount him. (TA.) [See an ex. voce EuroquwbN. Hence,] qaraEa fulaAnN liA^amorihi Zunobuwbahu (assumed tropical:) [Such a one struck his shin to betake himself to his affair] means such a one applied himself to his affair with diligence, or energy. (T, L, TA.) Selámeh Ibn-Jendel says,
kun~aA A_i*aA maA A^ataAnaA SaArixN faziEN
kaAna AlS~uraAxu lahu qaroEa AlZ~anaAbiybi
[We were (such that), when there came to us one crying aloud, in terror, the clamour (returned) to him was the striking of the shins;] by which he is said to mean that a quick reply was given; calling the striking of the whip upon the leg of the boot, in urging on the horse, “ the striking of the shin. ” (S.) You also say, qaraEa li*`lika AlA^amori Zunobuwbahu meaning (assumed tropical:) He prepared himself for that affair, or thing: and agreeably with this signification the verse of Selámeh cited above has been explained. (M, TA.) And qaraEa ZanaAbiyba AlA^amori (tropical:) He made, or rendered, the affair manageable. (M, K, TA.) A poet, cited by IAar, says,
qaraEotu ZanaAbiyba AlohawaY yawoma EaAlijK
(tropical:) I subdued love, or subjected it to my will, on the day of 'Álij;. as though I struck it on the shins; as a camel's shin is struck when one desires him to lie down, that he may mount him. (M, TA.) ― -b2- ZunobuwbN also signifies A nail that is in the jub~ap of a spear-head, [i. e., in the part into which the shaft enters,] (M, K,) where it is fixed upon the upper extremity of the shaft: and ZanaAbiyb has been said to be the pl. of the word in this sense in the verse of Selámeh cited above. (M, TA.)

div2.head: Quasi ZnY
div2.entryFree: 5 tZn~Y * ; originally taZan~ana: see the latter, in art. Zn.

1 Zahara * , (S, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
Zahara , (Msb,) inf. n. ZuhuwrN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) [It was, or became, outward, exterior, external, extrinsic, or exoteric: and hence,] it appeared; became apparent, overt, open, perceptible or perceived, manifest, plain, or evident; (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA;) after having been concealed, or latent: (Msb, TA:) and ↓ tZAhr signifies the same. (Har p. 85.) Hence the phrase Zahara liY raA^oYN (assumed tropical:) [An idea, or opinion, occurred to me], said when one knows what he did not know before. (Msb.) [And h`*aA maA yaZoharu liY (assumed tropical:) This is what appears to me to be the case, or to be the right way or course; or this is my opinion.] Zahara AlHamolu, inf. n. as above, means Pregnancy became apparent, or manifest: it is said that this is not the case in less than three months. (Msb.) And it is said in a trad. of 'Áïsheh, kaAna yuSal~iY AlEaSora fiY HujoratiY qabola A^ano taZohara i. e. [He used to perform the prayer of the afternoon in my chamber] before it (meaning the sun) became high and apparent: (TA:) or waAl$~amosu fiY HujoratiY lamo taZoharo baEodu i. e. [when the sun was in my chamber,] it not having risen high so as to be on the flat roof [thereof]: referring to the Prophet. (O. [But AlEaSora must be a mistranscription for Alfajora, i. e. the prayer of the dawn.]) The saying in the Kur [xxiv. 31], walaA yubodiyna ziynatahun~a A_il~aA maA Zahara minohaA [which is app. best rendered And that they discover not their ornature except what is external thereof] has been expl. in seven different ways, most correctly as meaning the clothes: (O, TA:) accord. to 'Áïsheh, it means the bracelet (Alqulob) and the ring (Alfataxap): and accord. to I'Ab, the hand and the signet-ring and the face. (TA.) ― -b2- Also He went forth, or out, (Mgh, TA,) to the outside of a place. (O, TA.) ― -b3- And He (a bird) migrated, or went down, from one country or region to another: used in this sense by AHn in relation to the vulture, migrating to Nejd. (L.) ― -b4- Zahara Eanohu, said of a vice, or fault, (O, TA,) or a disgrace, (JK, A, O,) (tropical:) It did not cleave to him; (A, O, TA;) it was remote from him; (TA;) it quitted him, or departed from him. (JK.) ― -b5- Zaharotu bihi, (O, TA,) inf. n. ZahorN, (K,) (assumed tropical:) I gloried, or boasted, by reason of it. (O, K * TA.) [Respecting a meaning assigned to Zahara bifulaAnK in the K, see 4.] ― -b6- A^akala Alr~ajulu A^ukolapF Zahara minohaA ZahorapF means (assumed tropical:) [The man ate some food] in consequence of which] he became fat. (TA.) -A2- Zaharahu He mounted it; went, or got, upon it, or upon the top of it; (S, A, * Mgh, O, Msb, K;) as also Zahara Ealayohi; (O;) namely, a house, (S,) or a house-top, (A, Mgh, O,) and a mountain, (A,) and a wall; (O, Msb;) properly, he became upon its back: (Mgh:) and [in like manner] one says, fulaAnN najodFA ↓ Zah~ara, inf. n. taZohiyrN, Such a one mounted, or went up, upon the high region (Zahor) of Nejd. (O.) ― -b2- Hence, (Mgh, Msb,) Zahara Ealayohi (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K) and bihi, (K,) inf. n. ZuhuwrN (Bd in xxiv. 31) and ZahorN also, (Ham p. 301,) He overcame, conquered, subdued, overpowered, or mastered, him; gained the mastery or victory, or prevailed, over him; (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) namely, his enemy; (Msb;) and in like manner, [he conquered, won, achieved, or attained, it, i. e.] a thing. (O, TA.) [The saying fulaAnN laA yaZoharu Ealayohi A^aHadN is expl. in the L and TA by the words AY lA yasolam, and said to be tropical: but Ibr D thinks that the correct reading is lA yusal~imu, from Alt~asoliymu; and that it is said of one who will not give up, or resign, what is in his hand; so that the meaning is, (tropical:) Such a one is a person whom no one will overcome in respect of that which he holds in his possession.] ― -b3- And [hence also] Zahara Ealayohi, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. ZuhuwrN, (TA,) He knew, became acquainted with, or got knowledge of, him, or it. (Msb, TA.) So in the Kur xxiv. 31, waA@lT~ifolu A@l~a*iyna lamo yaZoharuwA EalaY EaworaAti A@ln~isaA='i [And the young children] who have not attained knowledge of the EwrAt, (Bd, Jel,) meaning [pudenda, or] parts between the navel and the knee, (Jel,) of women, by reason of their want of discrimination: (Bd:) or (tropical:) who have not attained to the generative faculty; (O, Bd, * TA;) from AlZ~uhuwru in the sense of Algalabapu. (Bd.) So too in the Kur [xviii. 19], A_ino yaZoharuwA Ealayokumo If they get knowledge of you. (O, TA.) ― -b4- And [hence] Zahara Ealayohi, (Fr, A, O, TA,) and ↓ AstZhrhu, (S, A, O, K,) (tropical:) He knew it, or learned it, by heart; namely, the Kur-án; (A, O, TA;) and he recited it by heart: (A, * TA; and so in the S and O in explanation of the latter:) or [simply] he recited it by heart; namely, the Kur-án; as also ↓ AZhrhu: (O, K, TA:) in the copies of the K we find A^aZoharotu EalaY AlquroA=ni and A^aZoharotuhu; but the former is a mistake for Zaharotu, aor.
Zahara . (TA.) -A3- For another signification of Zahara Ealayohi, see 3. -A4- Zahara biHaAjatiY, (S, A, K,)
aor.
Zahara , (TA,) inf. n. ZahorN; (TK;) and ↓ Zh~rhA, (K, TA,) in some copies of the K ZaharahaA; (TA;) and ↓ AZhrhA, (K,) inf. n. A_iZohaArN; (TA;) and ↓ AiZ~aharahaA, (K,) of the measure AifotaEala; (TA;) (tropical:) He held the object of my want in little, or light, estimation, or in contempt; (S, A;) [lit.] he put it behind [his] back; (S, K;) as though he put it away, [out of his sight,] and paid no regard to it. (S, TA.) One says also, yaZoharuwna bihimo walaA yalotafituwna A_ilaY A^aroHaAmihimo [They hold them in contempt, and do not pay any regard to their ties of relationship]. (S.) ― -b2- See also 10, in three places. -A5- Zaharahu, (O, K,) aor.
Zahara , inf. n. ZahorN, (K,) He struck, or smote, (TA,) or hit, or hurt, (O, K,) his back. (O, K, TA.) -A6- Zahira, (S, O, K,) aor.
Zahara , (K,) inf. n. ZaharN, (O, K,) He (a man, S, O) had a complaint of his back. (S, O, K.) -A7- Zahura, (JK, O, L,) or Zahara, (K, [but this is app. a mistranscription,]) inf. n. ZahaArapN, (S, O, L, K,) said of a camel, (JK, S, O,) He was, or became, strong (JK, S, O, L, K) in the back. (L, K.)

2 Zah~ara see 1, near the middle: ― -b2- and again, in the last quarter: ― -b3- and see also 3. ― -b4- Zh~r Alv~awoba [and ↓ AZhrhu, contr. of bT~nhu and AbTnhu,] He faced the garment, or piece of cloth; put a facing, or an outer covering, (ZihaArap,) to it. (TA.) -A2- See also 4, last sentence.

3 ZAhrhu * , (A,) inf. n. muZaAharapN, (S, O, Msb,) He aided, or assisted, him; (S, A, O, Msb;) as also Ealayohi ↓ Zahara. (Th, K.) And ZAhr Ealayohi He aided, or assisted, against him. (TA.) ― -b2- ZAhr bihi: see 10. ― -b3- ZAhr bayonahumaA, (K,) i. e. (TA) bayona vawobayoni, (S, A, Mgh, TA,) and diroEayoni, (A, Mgh, TA,) and naEolayoni, (TA,) i. q. TaAraqa bayonahumaA, (S, TA,) or TaAbaqa, (A, K, TA,) i. e. (TA) He put them on, or attired himself with them, [namely, two garments, and two coats of mail, and two sandals or soles, or rather, when relating to two soles, he sewed them together,] one over, or outside, the other: (Mgh, TA:) app. from taZaAhurN in the sense of “ mutual aiding or assisting. ” (IAth.) The phrase ZAhr bidiroEayoni requires consideration; and the b in it should be regarded as meant to denote conjunction; not as a part of the necessary complement of the verb. (Mgh.) ZAhr Ald~iroEa is said to signify laA^ama baEoDahaA EalaY baEoDK [app. meaning He folded over and fastened one part of the coat of mail upon another]. (TA.) And ZAhr Ealayohi jilaAlFA means He threw upon him (i. e. a horse) housings or coverings [one over another]. (TA in art. Hn*.) -A2- ZAhr mini A@moraA^atihi, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. ZihaArN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and muZaAharapN; (JK, TA;) and minohaA ↓ tZAhr, (A, Mgh, O, TA,) and ↓ AiZ~aAhara; (Mgh;) and mnhA ↓ tZh~r, (S, Msb, K,) and ↓ AiZ~ah~ara; (O, TA;) and mnhA ↓ Zh~r, (S, O, K,) inf. n. taZohiyrN; (S;) signify the same; (O;) He said to his wife A^anoti EalaY~a kaZahori A^um~iY [Thou art to me like the back of my mother]; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) [as though he said rukuwbuki HaraAmN EalaY~a;] meaning rukuwbuki liln~ikaAHi HaraAmN EalaY~a karukuwbi A^um~iY liln~ikaAHi; the back being specified in preference to the baTon or faxi* or faroj because the woman is likened to a beast that is ridden, and the act of nikaAH to that of rukuwb: the phrase being a form of divorce used by the Arabs in the Time of Ignorance. (Msb, * TA.) In the Kur lviii. 2 [and 4], some read ↓ yaZ~ah~aruwna; some ↓ yaZ~aAharuwna; and 'Ásim read yuZaAhiruwna. (Bd.) The verb is made trans. by means of min because the man who uttered this sentence estranged himself from his wife. (IAth.)

4 AZhrhu *
He made it apparent, overt, open, perceptible or perceived, manifest, plain, or evident; he showed, exhibited, manifested, displayed, discovered, revealed, or evinced, it; or put it forth: (S, O, K:) [it is also used in relation to a saying, and an action, and the like, as meaning it showed, &c., as above, or it bespoke, it:] and Mtr relates his having heard from one worthy of reliance of the people of Baghdád, that they say ↓ tZAhrtu bihi in the place of A^aZoharotuhu, and scarcely ever employ AZhr in its usual sense. (Har p. 85.) [Hence, AZhr Alt~aDoEiyfa He made the doubling of a letter distinct; as in laHiHato; which, accord. to a general rule, should be laH~ato: opposed to A^adogama. And AZhr lahu ka*aA He showed, &c., to him such a thing: and he made a show of, professed, pretended, or feigned, to him such a thing: as, for instance, love.] ― -b2- A^aZoharotu bifulaAnK means A^aEolayotu bihi [a phrase which I have not found except in this instance, app. I elevated, or exalted, such a one: like A^aEolayotuhu, which has this meaning]: (S, IKtt, L, TA:) or A^aEolanotu bihi [app. meaning I made such a one to be, or become, publicly known]: (So in the O:) [but the former explanation seems to be regarded by SM as the right; for he remarks that,] accord. to all the copies of the K, the explanation is A^aEolana bihi, and refers to Zahara bifulaAnK [instead of A^aZohara]; so that what its author says in this case differs in two points of view from what is found in the “ Kitáb el-Abniyeh ” of IKtt, in which the Y in A^aEolayotu has been marked as correct, and in the L [as well as in the S]. (TA.) -A2- AZhrhu A@ll~`hu EalaY Eaduw~ihi means God made him to overcome, conquer, subdue, overpower, master, gain the victory over, or prevail over, his enemy. (S, A, O, TA.) ― -b2- And [hence] AZhrhu Ealayohi He (God) made him to know it, or become acquainted with it: you say, A^aZoharaniY A@ll~`hu EalaY maA suriqa min~iY God made me to know [or discover] what had been stolen from me. (TA.) -A3- See also 1, last quarter, in two places. -A4- And see 2. -A5- AZhr signifies also He entered upon the time called the Zahiyrap: (A, Msb, K:) or the time called the Zuhor. (Msb.) And He went, or journeyed, in the time called the Zahiyrap; as also ↓ Zh~r, (K,) inf. n. taZohiyrN: (TA:) or the time called the Zuhor. (S, O.)
5 tZh~r * and AiZ~ah~ara : see 3, latter half, in three places.

6 taZaAohara see 1, first sentence: ― -b2- and see also 4, first sentence. ― -b3- tZAhrwA They aided, or assisted, one another. (S, O, * K.) And tZAhrwA EalaY fulaAnK They leagued together, and aided one another, against such a one. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA in art. Dfr.) ― -b4- Also They regarded, or treated, one another with enmity, or hostility; or severed themselves, one from another: (S, Msb, K:) as though they turned their backs, one upon another: (S:) or, because they who do so turn their backs, one upon another. (Msb.) Thus the verb has two contr. meanings. (K.) ― -b5- tZAhr mini A@moraA^atihi and AiZ~aAhara: see 3, latter half, in three places.
8 AiZ~ahara * : see 1, last quarter.

10 AstZhr bihi *
He sought aid, or assistance, in, or by means of, him, or it, (S, O, Msb, K, TA,) Ealayohi [against him, or it]; as also AstZhrhu. (TA.) [In the CK, after the explanation of AstZhr bh, is an omission, to be supplied by the insertion of waqaraA^ahu.] One says, AstZhr biA@loginaY EalaY Aln~awaAy^ibi [He sought aid in wealth against calamities, or afflictions]. (Msb.) And bihi ↓ ZAhr signifies the same as AstZhr [in this sense or in another of the senses expl. in what follows]. (TA.) ― -b2- And AstZhrtu biAl$~aYo'i, and bihi ↓ Zaharotu, and ↓ Zaharotuhu, I put the thing behind my back for protection, or security. (Har p. 265.) ― -b3- And AstZhr He prepared for himself a camel, or two camels, or more, for future need: (T:) and AstZhrhu, and bihi ↓ Zahara, He prepared him, namely, a camel, for future need: (K:) and AstZhr bibaEiyrayoni Zihoriy~ayoni He prepared for himself two camels for future need. (T. [See ZihoriY~N.]) ― -b4- Hence, (T,) AstZhr signifies also He used precaution (T, Msb) with respect to anything: (T:) he secured himself, (Aisotawovaqa,) by using precaution; as, for instance, a woman does by remaining three days, before she performs the ablution termed gusol, and prays, after the usual period of the menses. (T, L.) One says, yusotaHab~u AlAisotiZohaAru bigasolapK vaAniyapK wavaAlivapK The using precaution by a second and a third washing, to make sure of being pure, is approved. (Er-Ráfi'ee, Msb.) And AstZhrtu fiY Talabi Al$~aYo'i I adopted the most fit, or proper, way, and used precaution, in seeking to attain the thing. (Msb.) ― -b5- See also 1, in the middle of the latter half.

ZahorN * The back; contr. of baTonN: (S, A, O, Msb, K:) in a man, from the hinder part of the kaAhil [or base of the neck] to the nearest part of the buttocks, where it terminates: (TA:) in a camel, the part containing six vertebræ on the right and left of which are [two portions of flesh and sinew called the] matonaAni: (AHeyth, T, O:) of the masc. gender: (Lh, A, K:) pl. [of pauc.] A^aZohurN, and [of mult.] ZuhuwrN and ZuhoraAnN. (Msb, K.) ― -b2- rajulN xafiyfu AlZ~ahori (tropical:) A man having a small household to maintain: and vaqiylu AlZ~ahori (tropical:) having a large household to maintain. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- A^anot EalaY~a kaZahori
A^um~iY Thou art to me like the back of my mother: said by a man to his wife. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) [This has been expl. above: see 3.] ― -b4- EadaA fiY Zahorihi (tropical:) He stole what was behind him: (A:) [or he acted wrongfully in respect of what was behind him: for] liS~N EaAdiY ZahorK is expl. by the words EadaA fiY ZahorK fasaraqahu [so that it app. means (tropical:) A thief who has acted wrongfully in respect of what was behind one, and stolen it]. (O, K.) ― -b5- A^aqoraAnu AlZ~ahori (S, O, K) and AlZ~uhuwri (O, TA) Adversaries who come to one from behind his back, in war, or fight. (S, O, K, * TA.) In the copies of the K, yuHib~uwnaka is erroneously put for yajiyw^uwnaka. (TA.) You say also, fulaAnN qironu AlZ~ahori Such a one is an adversary who comes to one from behind, unknown. (IAar, As.) ― -b6- qatalahu ZahorFA He slew him unexpectedly; he assassinated him; syn. giylapN. (IAar, TA.) ― -b7- jaEalaniY biZahorK (tropical:) He cast me off. (TA.) And jaEaltu HaAjatahu biZahorK (tropical:) I cast his want behind my back: (AO, K:) and ↓ jaEalahaA Zihoriy~apF signifies the same: (S:) and ↓ Ait~axa*ahaA Zihoriy~FA, (K,) and ↓ Zihoriy~apF: (TA:) or the former of the last two phrases signifies he held it in contempt; as though Zhry~A were an irreg. rel. n. from ZahorN: (TA:) or ↓ Ait~axa*ahu Zihoriy~FA signifies he neglected, or forgot, (S, O, * Msb,) him, as in the Kur xi. 94, (S, O,) or it, namely, what was said. (Msb.) And laA tajoEalo HaAjatiY biZahorK (tropical:) Forget not thou, or neglect not, my want: (S:) and ↓ jaEalahu Zihoriy~FA signifies he forgot it; as well as jElh biZahorK. (A.) And jaEalotu h`*aA AlA^amora biZahorK, and ramayotuhu biZahorK, (tropical:) I cared not for this thing. (Th, O.) ― -b8- fulaAnN mino waladi AlZ~ahori (assumed tropical:) Such a one is of those who do not belong to us: or of those to whom no regard is paid: (TA:) or of those who are held in contempt, and to whose ties of relationship no regard is paid. (S, TA.) ― -b9- huwa A@bonu Eam~ihi ZahorFA (tropical:) [He is his cousin on the father's side,] distantly related: contr. of dinoyFA [and laH~FA]. (As, A, O, TA.) ― -b10- rajaEa EalaY Zahorihi [He receded, retired, or retreated]. (K in art. vbjr.) ― -b11- huwa naAzilN bayona Zahorayohimo, and ↓ byn ZahoraAnayohimo, (S, A, O, Msb, K, *) in which latter the A and n are said by some to be added for corroboration, (Msb,) and for which one should not say ZahoraAniyhimo, (IF, S, O, Msb, K,) and byn A^aZohurihimo, (Msb, K,) (tropical:) He is making his abode in the midst of them; in the main body of them: (K, TA:) originally meaning he is making his abode among them for the purpose of seeking aid of them and staying himself upon them: as though it meant that the back of one of them was before him, and that of another behind him, so that he was defended in either direction: afterwards, by reason of frequency of usage, it came to be employed to signify abiding among a people absolutely. (IAth, Msb.) You say also huwa bayona Zahorayohi, and ↓ bayona ZahoraAnayohi, meaning It (anything) is in the midst, or main part, of it, namely, another thing. (TA.) ― -b12- laqiytuhu bayona AlZ~ahorayoni, and ↓ bayona AlZ~ahoraAnayoni, (S, O, Msb, K,) (tropical:) I met him during the day, (Msb,) or during the two days, (S, O, K,) or during the three days, (K,) or the days: (S, O, Msb:) from the next preceding phrase. (TA.) And A^atayotuhu mar~apF bayona AlZ~aharoyni (tropical:) I came to him one day: or, accord. to Aboo-Fak'as, on a day between two years. (Fr.) And All~ayoli ↓ raA^ayotuhu bayona ZahoraAnaYi (tropical:) I saw him between nightfall and daybreak. (TA.) And Aln~ahaAri ↓ jiy^otuhu bayona ZahoraAnaYi (tropical:) [I came to him between the beginning and end of the day]. (A.) ― -b13- taqal~aba ZahorFA libaTonK (assumed tropical:) It turned over and over, or upside down, (lit. back for belly,) as a serpent does upon ground heated by the sun. (S and TA in art. qlb.) [Hence,] qalabotu AlA^aroDa ZahorFA libaTonK (tropical:) [I turned the earth over, upside-down]. (A.) And [hence,] qal~aba A^amorahu ZahorFA libaTonK, (O, * TA,) and Zahorahu libaTonK, and Zahorahu libaTonihi, and Zahorahu lilobaToni, which last form is preferred by El-Farezdak to the second, because [as in the third form] the second of the two words is determinate like the first word, (tropical:) He meditated, or managed, the affair with forecast, and well. (O, * TA.) ― -b14- The Arabs used to say, h`*aA Zahoru Als~amaA='i and h*A baTonu Als~amaA='i, both meaning (tropical:) This is the apparent, visible, part of the sky. (Fr, Az.) And the like is said of the side of a wall, which is its baTon to a person on the same side, and its Zahor to one on the other side. (Az.) ― -b15- maA nazala mina AlquroA=ni A=yapN A_il~aA lahaA ZahorN wabaTonN, [part of] a saying of Mohammad, [of which see the rest voce muT~alaEN,] means (assumed tropical:) Not a verse of the Kur-án has come down but it has a verbal expression and an interpretation: (K, * TA:) or a verbal expression and a meaning: or that which has an apparent and a known [or an exoteric] interpretation and that which has an intrinsic [or esoteric] interpretation: (TA:) or narration (K, TA) and admonition: (TA:) or [it is to be read and to be understood and taught; for] by the Zhr is meant the reading; and by the bTn, the understanding and teaching. (TA.) [See also baTonN.] ― -b16- ZahorN signifies also (tropical:) Camels on which people ride, and which carry goods; (S, * A, * O, K, * TA;) camels that carry burdens upon their backs in journeying: (TA:) [or] a beast: or a camel for riding: (Mgh:) pl. ZuhoraAnN. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of 'Arfajeh, fatanaAwala Als~ayofa mina AlZ~ahori And he reached, or took in his hand, the sword from the camels for carrying burdens and for riding: and in another, A^ataA^o*anu lanaA fiY naHori ZahorinaA Dost thou permit us to slaughter our camels which we ride? (TA.) And one says also, huwa EalaY ZahorK (tropical:) He is determined upon travel: (K:) as though he had already mounted a beast for that purpose. (TA.) ― -b17- [Hence, app.,] (assumed tropical:) Property consisting of camels and sheep or goats: (TA:) or much property. (K, TA.) ― -b18- (assumed tropical:) The short side [or lateral half] of a feather: (S, O, K:) pl. ZuhoraAnN: (S, M, K, TA, &c.:) opposed to baTonN, sing. of buTonaAnN, (TA,) which latter signifies the “ long sides: ” (S, TA:) and ↓ ZuhaArN signifies the same as ZahorN, (K,) or the same as ZuhoraAnN, being an irregular pl.; and this is meant by the saying AlZ~uhaAru biAlD~ami AljamaAEapu, mentioned in a later place in the K [in such a manner as to have led to the supposition that ZuhaArN is also syn. with jamaAEapN]: (TA:) AO says that among the feathers of arrows are the ZuhaAr, which are those that are put [upon an arrow] of the Zahor [or outer side] of the Easiyb [app. here meaning the shaft] of the feather; (S, TA;) i. e., the shorter side, which is the best kind of feather; as also ZuhoraAn: sing. ZahorN: (TA:) ISd says that the ZuhoraAn are those parts of the feathers of the wing that are exposed to the sun and rain: (TA:) Lth says that the ZuhaAr are those parts of the feathers of the wing that are apparent. (O, TA.) One says, ri$o sahomaka biZuhoraAnK walaA tari$ohu bibuTonaAnK [Feather thine arrow with short sides of feathers, and feather it not with long sides of feathers]. (S, TA.) [De Sacy supposes that ZuhuwrN and buTuwnN are also pls. of ZahorN and baTonN thus used: (see his “ Chrest. Arabe, ” sec. ed., tome ii., p. 374:) but his reasons do not appear to me to be conclusive.] ↓ ZuhaArN and ZuhoraAnN are also used as epithets: you say, riy$N ZuhaArN and riy$N ZuhoraAnN. (TA.) ― -b19- [Zahoru Alkaf~i and ↓ ZaAhiruhaA mean (assumed tropical:) The back of the hand. And in like manner, Zahoru Alqadami and ↓ ZaAhiruhaA mean (assumed tropical:) The upper, or convex, side, or back, of the human foot, corresponding to the back of the hand, including the instep: opposed to baTon and baATin. And Zahoru All~isaAni means (assumed tropical:) The upper surface of the tongue.] ― -b20- And ZahorN also signifies (tropical:) A way by land. (S, M, O, Msb, K.) This expression is used when there is a way by land and a way by sea. (M.) You say, saAruwA fiY Tariyqi AlZ~ahori (tropical:) They journeyed by land. (A.) ― -b21- And (assumed tropical:) An elevated tract of land or ground; as also ↓ ZaAhirpN: (A:) or rugged and elevated land or ground; (JK, K;) as also ↓ ZaAhirapN: (JK:) opposed to baTonN, which signifies “ soft and plain and fine and low land or ground: ” (TA:) and ↓ ZawaAhiru [pl. of. ZaAhirapN] signifies (assumed tropical:) elevated tracts of land or ground: (S, K:) you say, haAjato ZawaAhiru AlA^aroDi, meaning, (assumed tropical:) the herbs, or leguminous plants, of the elevated tracts of land, or ground, dried up: (As, S, L:) and ↓ ZaAhirN signifies (assumed tropical:) the higher, or highest, part of a mountain; (ISh, L, TA;) whether its exterior be plain or not: (TA:) and ↓ ZaAhirapN, the same, of anything: (L:) when you have ascended upon the Zahor of a mountain, you are upon its ZaAhirap. (TA.) ― -b22- saAla waAdiyhimo ZahorFA means (assumed tropical:) Their valley flowed with the rain of their own land: opposed to duro'FA, meaning, “ from other rain: ” (IAar, O, K: *) or the former signifies their valley flowed
with its own rain: and the latter, “ with other than its own rain: ” (TA:) and some say ↓ ZuhorFA, which Az thinks the better form. (O, TA.) ― -b23- [Hence, probably,] A^aSabotu minohu maTara ZahorK (assumed tropical:) I obtained from him, or it, much good. (Sgh, O, K.) ― -b24- And another signification of ZahorN is What is absent, or hidden, or concealed, from one. (O, K.) ― -b25- It is sometimes prefixed to another noun to give plainness and force to the expression; as in Zahoru Algayobi and Zahoru Alqalobi, meaning nafosu Algayobi and nafosu Alqalobi: (Msb:) or it is redundant in these instances. (Mgh.) Lebeed says, describing a [wild] cow going about after a beast of prey that had eaten her young one,
watasam~aEato riz~a AlA^aniysi faraAEahaA
Eano Zahori gayobK waAlA^aniysu saqaAmuhaA
[And she heard the sound of man, and it frightened her, from a place that concealed what was in it; for man is her malady; i. e., a cause of pain and trouble and death to her]: (TA:) meaning, she heard the sound of the hunters, &c. (TA in art. gyb.) And you say, tanaAwalahu biZahori Algayobi bimaA yasuww^uhu He carped at him behind the back, or in absence, by saying what would grieve him. (TA in art. gyb.) And takal~amotu bihi Eano Zahori Algayobi (A, O) or En Zahori gayobK (TA) [app., (tropical:) I spoke it by memory; in the absence of a book or the like; as one says in modern Arabic, EalaY AlgaAy^ib. See also gayobN.] And qaraA^ahu Eano Zahori Alqalobi (tropical:) He recited it by heart, or memory; without book: (L, K: [in the latter, mino is put in the place of Eano; but the right reading is that in the L: and in the CK is an omission here, to be supplied by the insertion of waqaraA^ahu:]) and ↓ qrA^h ZaAhirFA and qrA^h EalaY Zahori lisaAnihi [signify the same]. (K.) And Hamala AlquroA=na EalaY Zahori lisaAnihi like HafiZahu EalaY Zahori qalobihi (tropical:) [He knew the Kur-án by heart]. (A, * O, TA.) ― -b26- One says also, fulaAnN yaA^okulu EalaY Zahori yadi fulaAnK (tropical:) Such a one eats at the expense of such a one. (A, O, K. *) And in like manner, AlfuqaraA='u yaA^okuluwna EalaY Zahori A^ayodiY Aln~aAsi (tropical:) The poor eat at the expense of the people. (A, TA.) And A^aEoTaAhu Eano Zahori yadK (tropical:) He gave him originally; without compensation. (O, * K; but in some copies of the K we find mino in the place of Eano.) It is said [in a trad.], A^afoDalu AlS~adaqapi maA kaAna Eano Zahori ginFY (tropical:) The most excellent of alms is that which is [derived] from competence; Zhr: (Msb:) or simply Eano ginFY, the word Zhr being here redundant: (Mgh:) or from manifest competence upon which one relies, and in which he seeks aid against calamities, or afflictions: or from what remains after fight: (Msb:) or from superfluous property. (TA.) -A2- See also ZahiyrN -A3- qidoru ZahorK means (assumed tropical:) An old cooking-pot: (O, K: *) pl. quduwru ZuhuwrK: (O:) as though, because of its oldness, it were thrown behind the back. (TA.)

ZuhorN *
Midday, or noon: (IAth, TA:) or the time when the sun declines from the meridian: (Msb, * K, * O, * TA:) or [the time immediately] after the declining of the sun: (S, Mgh:) masc. and fem.; unless when the word SalaAp is prefixed to it, in which case it is fem. only: (Msb:) [pl. A^aZohaArN. See also ZahiyrapN.] SalaApu AlZ~uhori means The prayer [i. e. the divinely-ordained prayer] of midday, or noon: (IAth, TA:) or of the time after the declining of the sun. (S, O.) In the phrases A^aboriduwA biAlZ~uhori [Defer ye the prayer of midday until the cooler time of day] and Sal~aY AlZ~uhora [He performed the prayer of midday], the prefixed noun (SalaAp) is suppressed. (Mgh.) -A2- saAla waAdiyhimo ZuhorFA: see ZahorN, last quarter.

ZahirN * , (S,) or ↓ ZahiyrN, (K,) [the former agreeable with analogy, being derived from Zahira,] A man (S,) having a complaint of the back: (S, K:) or having a pain in the back: as also ↓ maZohuwrN. (O, TA.)
ZuhorapN * : see ZahiyrN, in three places. -A2- Also The tortoise. (O, K.)
ZihorapN * : see ZahiyrN, in six places.

ZaharapN * The goods, or furniture and utensils, of a house or tent; (IAar, S, O, K, TA;) as also A^aharapN: (IAar, TA:) or the former signifies the exterior of a house, or tent; and the latter, the “ interior thereof. ” (Th, TA.) ― -b2- And Abundance of maAl [i. e. property, or cattle]. (TA.) -A2- See also ZahiyrN.

ZihoriY~N * A camel prepared for future need; (T, S, O, K;) taken, by way of precaution, to bear the burden of any camel that may happen to fail in a journey: sometimes two or more unladen camels are taken for this purpose: some say that such a camel is thus called because its owner puts it behind his back, not riding it nor putting any burden upon it: (T, TA:) the word appears to be an irreg. rel. n. from ZahorN: (ISd, TA:) pl. ZahaAriY~N, imperfectly decl., because the rel. Y retains its place in the sing. [inseparably; there being no such word as Zihor: but if it be a rel. n., this pl. is irreg., like mahaAriY~N]. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- See ZahorN, first quarter, in five places, for examples of ZihoriY~N and Zihoriy~apN used tropically.

ZuhoraAn * [app. ZuhoraAnN (which is also a pl. of ZahorN used in several senses), or, perhaps ZuhoraAni, as having a dual meaning,] The upper, thick, pair of wings of the locust. (AHn, TA.) ― -b2- [See also ZahorN.]
bayona ZahoraAnayohimo * , and ZahoraAnayohi, and AlZ~ahoraAnayoni, &c.: see ZahorN, former half, in five places.
ZahaArN * The exterior (K, TA) and elevated (TA) part of a [stony tract such as is called] Har~ap. (K, TA.)

ZuhaArN *
Pain in the back. (Az, O, TA.) -A2- See also ZahorN, third quarter, in two places.

ZahiyrN * : see ZaAhirN. -A2- Also An aider, or assistant; (S, A, O, Msb, K;) and so ↓ ZihorapN (S, K) and ↓ ZuhorapN: (K:) [in one place, in the K, ZihorapN is expl. by Eawon; but by this is meant, as will be seen below, the same as is meant by muEiyn, by which all the three words are expl. in another place in the K, as well as in the S &c.:] and aiders, or assistants; (S, Msb;) as also ↓ ZihorapN and ↓ ZuhorapN and ↓ ZahorN: (TA:) the pl. of ZahiyrN is ZuharaA='u. (O.) It is said in the Kur [xxv. 57], wakaAna AlkaAfiru EalaY rab~ihi ZahiyrFA And the unbeliever is an aider of the enemies of God [against his Lord]. (Ibn-'Arafeh.) You say also, fulaAnN EalaY fulaAnK ↓ ZihoratiY Such a one is my aider (Eawon) against such a one: and EalaY h`*aA ↓ A^anaA Zihoratuka AlA^amori I am thine aider against this thing, or affair. (S, O.) And it is also said in the Kur [lxvi. 4], waA@lomalaAy^ikapu baEoda *`lika ZahiyrN [And the angels after that will be his aiders]: and instance of Zhyr in a pl. sense: (S, O, Msb:) for words of the measures faEuwlN and faEiylN are sometimes masc. and fem. [and sing.] and pl. (S.) You also say, ↓ jaA='a fulaAnN fiY Zihoratihi, (S, A, K,) and ↓ Zuhoratihi, (A, K,) and ↓ Zaharatihi, and ↓ ZaAhiratihi, (K,) Such a one came among his people, (S,) or kinsfolk, (K,) and those who performed his affairs for him, (S, A,) i. e., his aiders, or assistants. (A.) And waAHidapK ↓ humo fiY ZihorapK They aid one another against the enemies. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Strong in the back; (K;) sound therein: (Lth:) and so ↓ muZah~arN: (S, O, K:) applied to a man: (S:) or hard and strong; whether in the back or any other part is not said: (TA:) in this sense, (TA,) or as signifying strong, (S, O,) applied to a camel: fem. with p. (S, O, TA.) ― -b3- Also A camel whose back is not used, on account of galls, or sores, upon it: or unsound in the back by reason of galls, or sores, or from some other cause. (Th.) Thus it has two contr. significations. (TA.) -A3- See also ZahirN.

ZihaArapN * [The facing, or outer covering, or] what is uppermost, (TA,) what is apparent (Msb, TA) to the eye, (Msb,) not next the body, of a garment; (TA;) and in like manner, what is uppermost and apparent, not next the ground, of a carpet; (TA;) as also ↓ ZaAhirapN: (JK:) contr. of biTaAnapN: (S, O, Msb, K:) pl. ZahaAy^iru. (TA.)

ZahiyrapN * The point of midday: (M, A, K:) or only in summer: (M, K:) or i. q. haAjirapN [i. e. midday in summer or when the heat is vehement: or the period from a little before, to a little after, midday in summer: or midday, when the sun declines from the meridian, at the Zuhor: or from its declining until the EaSor]: (S, O, TA:) or the haAjirap, which is when the sun declines from the meridian: (Msb:) or the vehement heat of midday: (IAth, TA:) or i. q. ZuhorN [q. v.]: (Az, TA:)
pl. ZahaAy^iru. (TA.) You say, A^atoyotuhu Had~a AlZ~ahiyrapi [I came to him at the point of midday in summer; &c.]: and Hiyna qaAma qaAy^imu AlZ~ahiyrapi [when the sun had become high, and the shade had almost disappeared: so expl. in art. qwm]. (S, O.) And A^aborido Eanoka mina AlZ~ahiyrapi Stay thou until the middayheat shall have become assuaged, and the air be cool. (L in art. fyH.) And hence, in a trad. of 'Omar, when a man came to him complaining of gout in the feet, he said, ka*abatoka AlZ~ahaAy^iru, meaning Take thou to walking during the heat of the middays in summer. (TA.)

ZuhaAriy~apN *
One of the modes of seizing [and throwing down] in wrestling: or i. q. $agozabiy~apN: (K:) the twisting one's leg with the leg of another in the manner that is termed $agozabiy~ap, and so throwing him down: one says, A^axa*ahu AlZ~uhaAriy~apa and Al$~agozabiy~apa [He seized him and threw him down by the trick above described]: both signify the same: (ISh, O:) or ZuhaAriy~apN signifies the throwing one down upon the back. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) ― -b2- And (hence, as being likened thereto, TA) (tropical:) A certain mode, or manner, of compressing, or coïtus. (O, K, TA.) ― -b3- And A^awovaqahu AlZ~uhaAriy~apa He bound his hands behind his back. (Ibn-Buzurj, O, K, TA.)

ZaAhirN * [Outward, exterior, external, extrinsic, or exoteric: and hence, appearing, apparent, overt, open, perceptible or perceived, manifest, conspicuous, ostensible, plain, or evident: in all these senses] contr. of baATinN: (S, K, TA:) and so ↓ ZahiyrN. (TA.) [Hence, ZaAhirFA Outwardly, &c.: and apparently; &c.: and fiY AlZ~aAhiri in appearance. And AlZ~aAhiru A^an~ahu ka*aA It appears, or it seems, or what seems to be the case is, that it is so, or thus. And ZaAhiru ka*aA for ZaAhirN fiyhi ka*aA, meaning A person, or thing, in whom, or in which, such a quality is apparent, or manifest, &c.: see an ex. in a verse cited in the first paragraph of art. TEn.] See also muZoharN. ― -b2- [Hence also,] EayonN ZaAhirapN A prominent eye; (S, O, K, TA;) that fills its cavity. (TA.) ― -b3- And h`*aA A^amorN ZaAhirN Eanoka EaAruhu (tropical:) This is a thing, or an affair, of which the disgrace is remote from thee: (S, TA:) or does not cleave to thee. (TA.) And h`*aA EayobN ZaAhirN Eanoka (tropical:) This is a vice, or fault, that does not cleave to thee. (A.) A poet says, (namely, Kutheiyir, accord. to a copy of the S, or Aboo-Dhu-eyb, TA,)
waEay~arahaA AlwaA$uwna A^an~iY A^uHib~uhaA
watiloka $akaApN ZaAhirN Eanoka EaAruhaA
(tropical:) [And the slanderers taunted her with the fact of my loving her; but that is a fault of which the disgrace is remote from thee]. (S, TA.) ― -b4- [AlZ~aAhiru also signifies The outside, or exterior, of a thing. You say, nazala ZaAhira Almadiynapi He alighted, or took up his abode, outside the city: comp. ZaAhirapN. Hence,] ZaAhiru Alkaf~i and ZaAhiru Alqadami; and another signification of ZaAhirN: for all of which see ZahorN, third quarter. ― -b5- [Also The external, outward, or extrinsic, state, condition, or circumstances, of a man: and the outward, or apparent, character, or disposition of the mind: opposed to AlbaATinu.] ― -b6- One says also, fulaAnN ZaAhirN EalaY fulaAnK Such a one has the ascendancy, or mastery, over such a one; is conqueror of him, or victorious over him. (TA.) And h`*aA A^amorN ZaAhirN bika This is a thing, or an affair, that overcomes, or overpowers, thee. (TA.) And h`*aA A^amorN A^anota bihi ZaAhirN This is an affair which thou hast power to do. (TA.) [And huwa ZaAhirN EalaY ka*aA He is a conqueror, a winner, an achiever, or an attainer, of such a thing: see an ex. voce garabN, near the end.] And AlZ~aAhiru is one of the names of God, meaning The Ascendant, or Predominant, over all things: or, as some say, He who is known -by inference of the mind from what appears to mankind of the effects of his actions and his attributes. (IAth, TA.) ― -b7- HaAjatuhu Einodaka ZaAhirapN means (tropical:) His want is in thine estimation [an object of contempt, or neglect, as though] cast behind the back. (O, * TA.) ― -b8- qaraA^ahu ZaAhirFA: see ZahorN, towards the end of the paragraph. -A2- $aA='N ZawaAhiru Sheep, or goats, that come to the water every day at noon. (TA.)

ZaAhirapN * as a subst.; and its pl. ZawaAhiru: see ZahorN, in four places, in the third quarter of the paragraph. [Hence,] qurayo$u AlZ~awaAhiri Those, of Kureysh, that dwell in the exterior of Mekkeh, (O,) upon the mountains thereof, (K, * TA,) or upon the higher parts of Mekkeh: (TA:) those who dwell in the lower parts are called qurayo$u AlbiTaAHi; (O, * TA;) and these are the more honourable, (O, TA, *) because they are neighbours of the House of God. (O.) ― -b2- See also ZihaArapN. -A2- And see ZahiyrN. -A3- Also The coming of camels, (S, O, K, TA,) and of sheep or goats, (TA,) to the water every day, at noon. (S, O, K, TA.) One says, of camels, [and of sheep or goats,] taridu AlZ~aAhirapa [They come to the water every day, at noon]: and Sh says that they return from the water at the EaSor. (TA.) And $ariba Alfarasu ZaAhirapF The horse drank every day, at noon. (TA.) ZaAhirapu Algib~i [The coming to the water at noon on alternate days] is for sheep or goats; scarcely ever, or never, for camels; and is a little shorter [in the interval] than what is called [simply] Algib~u. (O, TA.)

maZoharN *
i. q. maSoEadN [i. e. A place of ascent, or a place to which one ascends]; (O, K; in some copies of the latter of which, both words are erroneously written with damm to the m; TA;) and darajapN [as meaning a degree, grade, rank, condition, or station, or an exalted, or a high, grade, &c.]: (O:) used by En-Nábighah ElJaadee as meaning Paradise.
